train.report: Clinical history: Liver mass. Pre-operative diagnosis not given. Specimen types: A) Segment 5 liver lesion, excision. B) Gallbladder, cholecystectomy. C) Additional gallbladder margin, excision. Final diagnosis: A) Hepatocellular carcinoma, clear cell type, moderately differentiated, nodular, 6.0 x 5.0 x 4.5 cm, with angiolyrphatic invasion. B) Chronic cholecystitis, no evidence of malignancy. C) Hepatic parenchyma with chronic hepatitis, negative for malignancy. Additional pathological findings: Moderate interface hepatitis and mild to moderate lobular hepatitis, bridging fibrosis consistent with cirrhosis, macrovesicular steatohepatitis. No lymph nodes identified. Pathologic stage: T2 NX MK. The attending pathologist personally reviewed the entire pathology case and rendered the final diagnosis. Intra-operative diagnosis: Frozen section diagnosis A) Segment 6 liver lesion with surgical margin grossly involved, inked. Gross description: A) Segment 6 liver lesion: moderately firm, grayish-white nodular mass measuring 6.0 x 5.0 x 4.5 cm in size, with approximately 25% necrosis and no remarkable hepatocyte parenchyma. B) Gallbladder: disrupted, congested, with no calculi, thickening or remarkable mucosal surface. C) Additional gallbladder margin: serially sectioned and grossly unremarkable.

The pathology report describes the results of a biopsy of the right axillary sentinel lymph nodes and the right breast tissue of a female patient with invasive ductal carcinoma and ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Metastatic carcinoma was found in one of the sentinel lymph nodes, while the other lymph nodes and a non-sentinel lymph node showed no tumors. Multiple foci of invasive ductal carcinoma were found in the breast tissue, with the largest being 1.3cm, along with high-grade DCIS spanning 8cm in greatest dimension. The excisional biopsy margins were positive for DCIS, with tumor approaching the margins at multiple foci throughout the specimen. Blood vessel and lymphatic invasion were present, and one of four axillary lymph nodes tested positive for metastatic deposit. The tumor was weakly positive for estrogen receptors and negative for progesterone receptors. HER2/neu antigen was amplified. The report provides detailed descriptions of the size and location of calcifications and masses in the breast tissue. No additional masses or lesions were identified in the tissue.
Cervix biopsy shows infiltrative poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma.

The left adrenal gland contains a tumor with a diameter of 7.5 cm, surrounded by a thin capsule and cystic lesions up to 3.7 cm in diameter. Histologically, the tumor is composed of Zellballen with eosinophilic cytoplasm and nuclei containing prominent chromatin, with a mitosis count of 2/10 HPF and without atypical mitosis. Small areas of bleeding and necroses were observed with no evidence of vessel invasion or capsule destruction. Immunohistochemically, the tumor was positive for synaptophysin, CD56, and chromogranin, and negative for AE1/3, EMA and p53. Sustentacular cell counts were reduced, and Ki67 was positive in less than 1%. The final diagnosis is pheochromocytoma.

Breast right, wide local excision: Infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade III (of III), forming a mass, 1.2 x 1.1 x 0.9 cm. (AJCC pTIc). Angiolymphatic invasion is not identified. The surgical margins are negative for tumor. The closest margin (inferior) is free by 0.3 cm. Lymph nodes, right axillary sentinel, excision: Multiple (2) right axillary sentinel lymph nodes are negative for tumor. Blue dye is not identified in either of the right axillary sentinel lymph nodes. Lymph nodes, right axillary, excision: Multiple (6) right axillary lymph nodes are negative for tumor. HER2/neu protein overexpression is negative, score of 0, according to the interpretation guidelines in the FDA-approved HercepTest.

The pathology report describes a case of invasive urothelial carcinoma with high histologic grade, involving the urinary bladder, prostate, seminal vesicles, cytoprostatectomy, and surrounding soft tissues. The tumor has both papillary and flat non-invasive growth patterns and inverted/nodular invasive growth patterns and is multicentric. There is involvement of the superficial half of muscularis propria, but no vascular or perineural invasion is identified. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and lymph nodes are not involved. The prostate has nodular hyperplasia and other high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia, but is not involved in the carcinoma. The left and right ureters, the urethra, and pelvic floor are all negative for tumor. The report includes a summary of sections with specific locations of the tumor and resected tissues.

Clinical Diagnosis: Right renal cortical tumor. 

Diagnosis: Renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, nuclear grade II/IV, with solid pattern growth, confined within the renal capsule and no invasion of the renal vein identified. Non-neoplastic kidney shows glomerulosclerosis and interstitial inflammation. All surgical margins are free of tumor. The adrenal gland is not submitted. 

Gross Description: Kidney with attached ureter, weighing 440 grams, and measuring 20 x 8.6 x 4.5 cm. Well-circumscribed yellow-brown mass with a central scar measuring 4.5 x 4.5 x 4.0 cm. 

Special Studies: Special Stain. Comment. RECUT. 

Summary of Sections: UM - ureteral margin. VM - vascular margin. TAM - tumor with anterior margin. TPM - tumor with posterior margin. TP - tumor with renal pelvis. N - normal parenchyma. HF - hilar fat, for possible lymph nodes.

Filtered report:

Gross description: Radical cystectomy with a whitish, solid, and vegetative tumor developed at the level of the right hemibladder.

Microscopic description: Urothelial carcinoma, G3, poorly differentiated, with alveolar and papillary pattern, invading into the chorion and into the deep and superficial musculature, but without surpassing it. Acinar adenocarcinoma of the prostate with infiltrative glandular pattern at the level of one of the lobes. 

Diagnosis: 
1. Invasive urothelial carcinoma of the bladder, poorly differentiated, G3, pT2b pNo pMx. 
2. Acinar adenocarcinoma of the prostate, histological score Gleason 6 (3+3), pT2a pNx pMx.

Comments: Lymph nodes with reactive lymphoid hyperplasia, without tumoral metastases. Small segment of ureter with dilated lumen and non-specific inflammatory infiltrate diffusely distributed into the chorion. Tumor size not specified. Lymphatic invasion present. Venous invasion not specified.

A pathology report shows metastatic squamous carcinoma in some lymph nodes in the neck and a poorly differentiated non-keratinizing squamous carcinoma in the right pyriform sinus. The tumor does not invade bone, and margins of resection are tumor-free. The report also includes the gross description of teeth. The report provides section codes and measurements of all the affected areas. The mucosal margin is free from the tumor. The specimen of the tooth is for gross only.

The report describes the findings of a left adrenal-sparing radical nephrectomy, which showed the presence of a well-circumscribed, 4.5 cm tumor in the mid-pole of the kidney. The tumor was confirmed to be a renal cell carcinoma with conventional/clear cells, with a Fuhrman grade of 2, and had invaded through the renal capsule into the peri-renal connective tissue into the renal sinus. No tumor was present in the renal artery or vein, or the ureter, and resection margins were free of tumor. Additionally, the report noted chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis and the presence of a black irregular stone in the gallbladder. No lymph nodes were identified in the hilum of the kidney, and representative sections of the tumor were submitted for possible electron microscopy and other research protocols. The adjacent kidney parenchyma was unremarkable, and the pelvicalyceal system was smooth and devoid of any lesions.  SNOMED codes included T-71000 and M-83123.

Filtered Report:
Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma, Type I with a diameter of 3.6 cm, and Grade GII is observed. The surrounding Kidney parenchyma does not show any tumor. Stage is reported as pT1a, pNX, pMX, RO. ICD-0-Code is 8260/3.

Summary: The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma with a maximum dimension of 3.8 cm. Some additional notes include the presence of glomerulosclerosis, interstitial nephritis, and massive arteriosclerosis. Resection margins are clear of tumor. The pTNM classification (2002 edition) indicates stage pT1a, pNX, pMX, and a grade of GII.

Patient has a ten-month history of a right neck mass and a DL revealing asymmetrical enlargement of right tongue base and vallecula. Biopsies confirm the presence of invasive, non-keratinizing, poorly-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right base of the tongue. The specimen received is a 0.7 tan-pink mucosal bit bisected in formalin.

The pathology report concerns a surgical case with the following diagnoses: (A) rule out parathyroid, no tumor in thyroid tissue and adjacent soft tissue, (B) papillary thyroid carcinoma measuring 2.5cm in the left lobe with a focus of tumor in soft tissue, (C) no tumor in the left superior paratracheal tissue, and (D) metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in four out of six lymph nodes in the left paratracheal dissection, without extracapsular extension. The report describes the gross description of the specimens submitted, including the total thyroidectomy specimen with nodules present in both lobes, portions of which were submitted to the tumor bank. The report concludes with the clinical history, SNOMED codes, and a disclaimer regarding the FDA approval status of some tests.

Diagnosis: Invasive squamous cell carcinoma in tongue and mandible involving minor salivary gland. Moderately differentiated with surface necrosis and lymphovascular and perineural invasion. No in situ component identified. Tumor size: 6.0 cm, depth of invasion: 1.3 cm. Lymph nodes (0/48) and bone negative for tumor except for margins which are positive at the anterior aspect. AJCC staging: PT3, PNO, pMX.

Diagnosis: Wedge excision and right upper lobectomy of a 2cm poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the subpleura of the right upper lobe. Margins negative for carcinoma, lymphovascular space invasion of venous system, and benign lymph nodes. The primary tumor staging is pT1 and lymph nodes are pNo. Immunohistochemistry staining was positive for p63. No additional masses identified in the remaining parenchyma. No invasion of visceral pleura or adjacent structures, and tumor-associated atelectasis/obstructive pneumonitis were absent.

A  patient with a history of sarcoma in the right calf underwent excision of a malignant fibrous histiocytoma involving subcutaneous soft tissue. Angiolymphatic invasion was identified, and the tumor extended to within less than 1mm of the medial margin of the specimen. However, biopsy from medial/subcutaneous margin #2 and medial tendon margin #2 both tested negative for tumor. The deep margin from Part A of the case also tested negative for tumor. Three formalin-filled containers were received, and representative sections of the mass with medial margin were submitted for potential future studies. Microscopic evaluation was performed.

The pathology report describes a tissue sample from a patient who underwent a hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, diagnosed with endometrial adenocarcinoma of the endometrioid type. The tumor is exophytic and measures 2.8 x 2.5 x 1.9 cm, located in the anterior uterine wall, invading 0.2 cm of the myometrium. There are no notable findings in the cervix or lymph nodes. Two intramural leiomyomata ranging from 2.2 cm to 3.5 cm are observed, and the bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes are unremarkable. The final report is based on gross examination and frozen section histologic evaluation, with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) staining. The total weight of the uterus with attached bilateral tubes and ovaries is 176.0 grams, and multiple lymph nodes in the left and right pelvic areas are negative for the tumor.

The pathology report describes the results of a radical hysterectomy and lymph node dissection performed on a patient with invasive endocervical adenocarcinoma with mucinous features. The report indicates that there was no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in the lymph nodes, including the pelvic and common iliac lymph nodes, with only benign fibrofatty tissue present. The uterus and cervix showed moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with maximum dimensions of 3.5 cm, invading the anterior and posterior ectocervix and lower endocervix with equivocal lymphovascular invasion. The specimen margins were not involved by invasive carcinoma. The report mentions hyperplasia, squamous metaplasia, and Nabothian cysts, and proliferative endometrium. No gross tumor was seen in any of the lymph nodes. No other abnormalities were reported, and the report notes that the immunohistochemical tests used have not been approved by the FDA.

The pathology report indicates the presence of glioblastoma multiforme, a high-grade brain tumor, in the left temporal lobe of the brain. The report is based on the examination of three specimens labeled A, B, and C, which were biopsied and removed from the patient. Specimen A shows infiltrating anaplastic astrocytoma, and both specimens B and C demonstrate glioblastoma multiforme. The report includes a gross description of the specimens and notes that a portion of specimen A was frozen for intraoperative diagnosis. The remainder of all specimens was entirely submitted in separate cassettes.

A lump with a tumor of 1.2x1.3 cm in size was found in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. Fatty tissue lymph nodes demonstrate lipomatosis. The tumor is diagnosed as infiltrating duct carcinoma, G3, and there is absence of venous invasion and involved margins. Ten dissected lymph nodes demonstrate focal fibrosis and reactive hyperplasia of the follicles, 0/10 positive for metastasis (Axillary 0/10). The Nottingham Histologic Score cannot be determined. No evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings were observed.

Diagnosis: Prostate, radical prostatectomy- Adenocarcinoma, with Gleason score of 6/10 and involving approximately 25% of the anterior portion of the right lobe of the prostate. High grade PIN is also present. No extraprostatic extension, seminal vesicle involvement, or lymphovascular space invasion noted. Surgical margins of excision are free of carcinoma. pTNM stage is pT2aNXMX. The gross description shows an intact prostate with gray-tan rubbery nodular cut surface, without conclusive evidence of a definitive mass. Representative sections from the prostate are submitted for analysis.

A diagnosis of anaplastic oligodendroglioma, WHO grade III, was established in a  year old female with glioma of the left frontal lobe. The infiltrating glioma contains hyperchromatic nuclei, perinuclear haloes, and background chicken-wire vasculature. Mutated isocitrate dehydrogenase-1 (IDH1) was identified, and Ki-67 labeling index showed focally increased proliferative activity (15-20%) in highly cellular areas. Chromosome analysis determined co-deletions of chromosomes 1p and 19q in the tissue analyzed. The laboratory is certified to perform high complexity clinical laboratory testing under the Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments of 1988 (CLIA-88).

The pathology report describes a surgical pathology of a right nephrectomy specimen, which weighs 1670g and was diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type. The tumor is limited to the kidney, with negative vascular, ureteric, and soft tissue resection margins. Lymphovascular invasion is present, but tumor involvement of the renal vein is absent. AJCC Classification (6th Edition): T2 NO MX. The report also describes infra-aortic vena cava lymph node with three lymph nodes that are negative for tumor. Immunoperoxidase studies of paraffin-embedded sections reveal a mixed population of CD3-positive/CD5-positive/CD43-positivT cells and CD20-positive B cells. The B cells highlighted with CD10 appear to be polytypic. The clinical data lacks a history of the patient's operation, and there are no reports of clinical diagnosis. The karyotype shows clonal aberrations, including loss of the short arm of chromosome 3, which is a common occurrence in renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type. Mosaicism and small chromosome anomalies are not detectable with standard methods, but there is no indication for test results.

The pathology report suggests the presence of Hepatocellular carcinoma, moderately differentiated, with mild steatosis and periportal fibrosis (stage 2), in a partially resected liver specimen, along with chronic cholecystitis in the gallbladder and reactive hyperplasia in a regional lymph node biopsy. The lesion appeared as a well-defined round mass without necrosis and showed trabecular histologic type with partial capsule formation and capsular infiltration but no invasion of surgical resection margin, serosa, portal vein, or microvessels. Multicentric occurrence and intrahepatic metastasis were not reported.

Clinical history: Bilateral thyroid nodules, history left lobe PTC positive.
Specimens submitted: 
1. Tissue near left upper pole (fs): Benign thyroid tissue.
2. Left paratracheal tissue (fs): One benign lymph node (0/1).
3. Total thyroidectomy: Five foci of papillary carcinoma, well differentiated, ranging from 0.4 cm to 1.1 cm; one classical type and four microcarcinomas. Tumor encapsulated partially, location in left and right lobes. No blood vessel invasion or tumor necrosis identified. Extrathyroid extension invades perithyroidal adipose tissue and parathyroid gland. Surgical margins free of tumor. Tumor multicentricity. Non-neoplastic thyroid exhibits nodular hyperplasia and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis. Two parathyroid glands identified, one parathyroid gland involved on the left side. Two benign lymph nodes (0/2) identified. Congo red and immunohistochemical stains negative.

The pathology report relates to a right hemicolectomy with en bloc resection of abdominal wall muscle and fascia for a patient with a pre- and post-diagnosis of a tumor of the cecum. The received specimen comprises a segment of proximal right colon with distal ileum, with an irregular muscle fragment near the cecal pouch. There is a circumferential tumor mass at the ileocecal valve that extends into the muscularis propria, with no direct invasion into the adjacent pericolonic abscess and inflammation. The tumor is moderately-differentiated colonic adenocarcinoma, with negative margins, no vascular invasion, and metastatic carcinoma in none of the 19 mesenteric lymph nodes.

Left breast simple mastectomy: Infiltrating ductal carcinoma of Nottingham grade III (of III) located in outer quadrant forming a 2.6 x 2.4 x 2.0 cm mass is present with no angiolymphatic invasion identified. No significant ductal carcinoma in situ component is present. A hyalinized fibroadenoma is present superior to the mass. The nipple and skin are unremarkable. Multiple (3) left axillary sentinel lymph nodes are negative for tumor. Immunohistochemical cytokeratin stain confirms the H&E impression. [AJCCpN0(i-)]. Her-2/NEU has been ordered on paraffin embedded tissue.

The pathology report describes a tumor in the right, lower outer quadrant of a breast specimen, which was obtained from a radical mastectomy. The tumor is a moderately differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma, measuring 2.2 x 1.8 x 1.8 cm. There is evidence of a grossly evident lesion, but the extent of the tumor is not specified. There are 0/2 lymph nodes positive for metastasis with no mention of the presence of extracapsular invasion. The margins are not specified. There is no determination of the Total Nottingham Score, and there is no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings. There are no comments included in the report.

The pathology report contains details about sample collection, histology, staging, and diagnosis. The sample type is either Buffy or Tumour, and the site and year of collection are recorded. The age of the patient and the days to the collection are also included. The site and preparation of the tissue are noted, along with any comments or procedures performed. The primary diagnosis is reported, along with the type and grade of the tumor and its clinical stage. The pathology report also provides a slide URL for the associated whole slide image. The tumor size is 1.5 cm, and it is classified as stage II with T1, N0, and M0 classifications.

A thymus resection showed a thymoma, WHO type B2, with a greatest dimension of 5.5 cm. The tumor showed multifocal microscopic invasion into mediastinal fat and was present microscopically at a cauterized margin of resection. Residual thymic tissue with minimal involutional changes was also present. Immunohistochemistry revealed positive staining for CD3, CD1a, low and high molecular weight keratins, and p63. The tumor is in keeping with a minimally invasive thymoma, WHO type B2 (aka cortical type), with a microscopically positive margin of resection. Gross examination revealed a well-circumscribed nodule on one pole of the thymus, measuring 5.5 x 3.8 x 2.5 cm with focal areas of calcification. The peripheral aspect of the nodule is firm and centrally soft and friable.

The pathology report describes an intact right eye sample that measures Axial 24mm, Horizontal 24mm, Vertical 23mm. It exhibits a dark pigmented nodule on infero-postero and a dome-shaped pigmented choroidal mass measuring LBD 15mm, height 12mm. The posterior segment shows a choroidal melanoma that is partially pigmented consisting of a mixture of spindle and epithelioid cells with a prominent microvasculature, a large accompanying exudative retinal detachment, and retinal invasion. Mitoses are counted at around 5/40 high power fields. The examiners identified a large extraocular growth, which has arisen at two sites, and encapsulated only by a thin layer of connective tissue. The optic nerve and vortex veins have no tumor involvement. The diagnosis is choroidal melanoma of mixed cell type with extraocular melanoma growth. Further molecular genetic examination of the DNA extracted from the tumor cells will be performed using multiplex-ligation dependent probe amplification (MLPA), looking at chromosomes.

Diagnosis: Invasive poorly differentiated endometrial carcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade 3, invading the myometrium, with lymphovascular invasion present. Multiple leiomyomas are also present. No tumor is found in the ovaries, fallopian tubes, or lymph nodes. A calcified hyalinized nodule is found in the omentum, but no evidence of malignancy is present. The tumor does not invade the lower uterine segment or the endocervix. The patient underwent total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, lymph node dissection, and omentectomy. The lymph nodes and omentum are negative for malignancy. The provisional pathologic staging is T1b/N0/MX.

Final diagnosis: 
Right kidney radical nephrectomy:
A. Renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, Fuhrman nuclear grade 3 of 4.
B. Tumor does not extend beyond Gerota's fascia.
C. All examined surgical resection margins are free of tumor.
D. No evidence of angiolympathic invasion is identified.
E. Non-neoplastic kidney shows focal interstitial chronic inflammation.
F. TNM pathologic stage = pT2 NX MX.
G. TNM histologic grade = G3. 
Comment: Although large areas of carcinoma are composed of tumor cells with Fuhrman's nuclear grade 1 and 2, grade 3 areas with adjacent tumor necrosis are clearly identified.

The pathology report describes a composite resection specimen from a patient with a history of floor of mouth carcinoma. The specimen includes a large tumor mass that has eroded through the mandible and involves the floor of the mouth, tongue, anterolateral skin, and parotid gland. Squamous cell carcinoma is present and is moderately to poorly differentiated, with perineural invasion and possibly angiolymphatic invasion present. The left inferoposterior and right inferior subcutaneous soft tissue margins of resection have carcinoma present. In the left level II neck dissection, 1 out of 8 lymph nodes has carcinoma present, while in the left level III neck dissection, no carcinoma is identified in 6 nodes. The mandibular margins of the specimen show carcinoma present within bone, soft tissue, and perineural space in the left mandibular margin (posterior-superior), and free of carcinoma in the right mandibular margin after decalcification.

Summary:

The patient, a female, underwent a surgical procedure to remove the thyroid gland due to papillary thyroid carcinoma, conventional type, located in the left lobe. The carcinoma was 1.0 cm in size and did not show extrathyroidal extension or lymphovascular invasion. The resection margins were negative. The background thyroid showed adenomatous hyperplasia. One out of six lymph nodes in the left side showed metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma with periglandular extracapsular extension absent. A pleomorphic adenoma of 2.0 cm was found in the submandibular gland. No tumor was found in one right facial lymph node examined. The clinical history of the patient is not given.

Liver mass consistent with hepatocellular carcinoma with a moderately differentiated trabecular histologic type and complete capsule formation. No evidence of invasion or metastasis identified. The remaining liver parenchyma shows cirrhosis. Left hemihepatectomy was performed with a safety margin of 1.5 cm. Microscopic examination shows no fibrous septum formation or fatty change. No additional information on multicentric occurrence or intrahepatic metastasis is available.

Clinical history: Malignant neoplasm corpus uteri. Gross examination of a hysterectomy specimen revealed an exophytic mass involving the uterine isthmus, the lower uterine segment, and the superior part of the cervix. The biopsy of peritoneal and pelvic lymph nodes did not show any malignancy. Microscopic examination confirmed the endometrioid adenocarcinoma with FIGO grade 1, limited to the surface of the cervix without stromal invasion. The tumor did not invade myometrium or serosa and was negative for vascular invasion. Both ovaries and fallopian tubes were negative for malignancy. The pathological stage was pT1aNO.

Gender: M. Diagnosis: Kidney, Right, Partial Nephrectomy - Clear Cell Renal Cell Carcinoma. The tumor measures 1.8 cm with Fuhrman nuclear grade 2. Margin status is positive as the tumor focally extends to renal parenchymal margin. Lymphovascular invasion is not identified. Pathological stage: I. Tumor site: not specified. Histologic type: Clear cell renal cell carcinoma. Sarcomatoid features: not identified. Tumor necrosis: not identified. Microscopic tumor extension: tumor limited to kidney. Source of Specimen: Mass;Right Renal Mass. Clinical History/Operative Dx: Right renal mass. Gross Description: A 1.8 cm lobulated tumor mass that is 0.2 cm from the renal parenchymal margin is present. Microscopic Description: Microscopic sections have been examined.

The patient is a female with metastatic high-grade adenocarcinoma. The omentum and uterus are extensively infiltrated by the tumor. Histologic typing and grading reveal a serous carcinoma of endometrial origin. The tumor focally extends 0.3 cm into a 1.1 cm thick myometrium. Lymphovascular space invasion is not definitively identified, and surgical margin status is not definitive. The lymph node status indicates no lymph nodes were removed. The specimen received includes a portion of the omentum, omentum, and uterus with the right tube and ovary. The gross description indicates two gray-white tumor nodules ranging from 2.0 to 6.0 cm in the omentum. The uterus is 5.6 cm in length, and the right ovary measures 3.0 x 1.5 x 1.3 cm. The specimen is submitted for permanent sections. The frozen section diagnosis confirms metastatic adenocarcinoma. Immunohistochemical stains for WT-1 and P53 show positive staining for P53 with no to only focal nuclear staining for WT1. The diagnosis is pT3a NX (FIGO IIIA).

A wide excision of a scalp melanoma with skin graft was performed. The final diagnosis reports a malignant melanoma, focally ulcerated with multiple foci of angiolymphatic invasion and cutaneous and dermal satellites present. Resection margins, including the deep margin are free of tumor. Two lymph nodes (left sentinel #1 and #2) were excised and found to be free of tumor cells after routine stains and immunostains for s100, Melan. a, HMB45, tyrosinase or CD68.

The pathology report identifies two primary diagnoses. First, a mesenteric nodule is present, which is benign and characterized by fat necrosis, fibrosis, and mild chronic inflammation. Second, a left nephrectomy was performed due to a carcinoma. The carcinoma is a clear cell renal cell carcinoma, Fuhrman grade 3/4, located in the mid pole and approximately 8 cm in size. Lympho-vascular space invasion was identified, but there was no evidence of transcapsular or renal vein invasion. One paraaortic lymph node was examined and found to be benign and hyperplastic. Mild chronic pylonephritis is also present. The surgical margins and ureteral margins were negative. The kidney weighed 640 grams and had a large, circumscribed golden yellow mass that was predominantly within the mid pole lesion but did not invade surrounding perinephric fat. The report notes that representative sections were submitted for examination.

The pathology report describes a brain tumor resected from a patient diagnosed with an astrocytoma. The gross examination of the tumor reveals a highly cellular pleomorphic population of astrocytes consistent with a high grade glioma. The area initially interpreted as necrosis on frozen section actually represents an area of hemorrhage as seen in permanent sections. The final diagnosis is an anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO grade III).

Filtered report for CLIP training: 

- Specimen Source: RIGHT TESTICLE AND TUBE. 
- Diagnosis: MIXED GERM CELL TUMOR WITH SEMINOMA (80%), CHORIOCARCINOMA (20%). TUMOR MEASURES 3 CM WITH AREAS OF NECROSIS AND HEMORRHAGE. TUMOR LIMITED TO TESTES. NO INVASION OF EPIDIDYMIS NOTED. LYMPHOVASCULAR INVASION NOTED. SURGICAL MARGINS FREE OF TUMOR. INTRATUBULAR GERM CELL NEOPLASIA. SEMINIFEROUS TUBULES WITH EVIDENCE OF SPERMATOGENESIS AND ATROPHY. 
- Gross Exam: A 60-gram orchiectomy specimen including 4.5 x 3.5 x 3-cm testis, 3 x 0.7 x 0.4-cm epididymis, and 10 cm in length and 1.5 cm in diameter spermatic cord. A 3 x 1.8 x 1.8-cm white-tan to pink-tan, fleshy, well-circumscribed mass with focal areas of hemorrhage and necrosis. 
- Special stains pending. Note: pT2NXMX. 
- Cassettes: 1 to 2 Tumor. 3 Tumor and tunica vaginalis. 4 Tumor and epididymis. 5 Tumor and adjacent testis. 6 Spermatic cord resection margin. 8 Spermatic cord midportion. 9 Spermatic cord peritesticular portion.

The report is of a patient with a history of PSA value of 5.3 and a biopsy revealing moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3 = 6 in the left and right sides of the prostate. The patient underwent radical prostatectomy which showed invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+4=7, involving both the right and left lobes with a greatest nodular diameter of 1.4 cm, but being organ-confined without evidence of extracapsular extension, and free of carcinoma in the bilateral seminal vesicles. There was no carcinoma identified in 3 lymph nodes in the right pelvic excision and in 8 lymph nodes in the left pelvic excision. High-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia was identified. The pathologic TNM stage was pT2c, NO MX. TNM histologic grade was G3. Multifocal disease and extraprostatic extension were not identified, and all examined surgical resection margins were free of carcinoma. However, perineural invasion was identified and benign prostatic hypertrophy and chronic moderately active prostatitis were noted.

Summary: The report describes a case of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the abdominal esophagus, with 3.5x3x3cm size, invading the adventitia and fat tissue. It is ulcerated and invasive, with moderate, light eosinophilic keratinized cytoplasm and enlarged nuclei with coarse clumped chromatin and prominent nucleoli. Mitotic figures are present. Lymph nodes show metastasis. No evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings are reported.

The pathology report describes a case of invasive poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma with focal squamous differentiation in a urinary bladder specimen obtained via TURBT. The tumor has invaded the muscularis propria, and histology indicates high grade urothelial carcinoma with squamous differentiation. Lymph-vascular invasion is indeterminate, and there are additional findings of cautery artifact and necrosis. The gross specimen consists of multiple fragments of tan-pink rubbery soft tissue with a total weight of 8.1 grams, and it has been totally submitted in formalin.

The pathology report describes a radical cystoprostatectomy specimen for a patient with urothelial carcinoma. The frozen sections of the ureteral margins show urothelial dysplasia on the right side and benign urothelium with reactive changes on the left side. The final diagnosis for the radical cystoprostatectomy shows invasive urothelial carcinoma with squamous differentiation and extensive necrosis involving the bladder, prostate, and left seminal vesicles. The tumor invades the detrusor muscle and extends into the perivesical fat. The inked prostatic resection margins and the distal urethral resection margin are involved. Perineural and extensive angiolymphatic invasion were identified, and the TNM stage is pT4a NO Mx with a histologic grade of G3. No evidence of malignancy is present in the 24 lymph nodes examined. Finally, low-grade intraurothelial neoplasia is identified.

Pathologic diagnosis: The patient had a modified radical mastectomy due to a right breast mass. The Pathologic diagnosis reveals invasive ductal carcinoma associated with microcalcification, ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), necrosis and microcalcifications. The DCIS is cribriform, micropapillary, and solid type with low and intermediate nuclear grade. Columnar cell changes and two small fibroadenomas were also identified. 20 out of 29 lymph nodes tested were positive for metastatic carcinoma with extranodal extension present. The breast parenchyma and axillary tissue exhibit blood vessel and lymphatic invasions. The ER and PR expression was strong, while Her2/neu antigen (FISH) was non-amplified. The patient has pT2(m), N3, MX stage according to pTNM (AJCC, 7th edition, 2010).

The pathology report is for a nephrectomy of the right kidney due to a renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, with a histologic grade of 3 (of 4, Fuhrman classification) and a tumor size of 4.5 cm. Multifocality of the tumor was discovered during control block use, and a second lesion was found measuring 0.9 cm without extracapsular invasion. The tumor did not grossly involve Gerota's fascia, renal vein, ureter, adrenal gland, or the lymphatic system. The patient's clinical history was a right renal mass. The kidney weighed 850 g and measured 14.5 x 8.0 x 7.0 cm, and the adrenal gland measured 4.5 x 2.4 cm. The tumor was located in the superior pole and had a glistening, maroon-hemorrhagic appearance consistent with necrosis. There was no confinement to the kidney, and the extent of invasion was not identified. Two lymph node candidates were identified. A separate mass measuring 0.9 x 0.9 x 0.9 cm was found. The light microscopic examination showed a clear cell carcinoma of the kidney with nucleoli identifiable at 10X.

This is a pathology report for a patient with prostate cancer. The report includes four specimens labelled A through D. Specimens A and B represent left lymph nodes and both are fragments of reactive lymph node, with no sign of carcinoma. Specimen C is a 30 gram prostate gland with adenocarcinoma present on both sides in the peripheral zone, with a GLEASON score of 3+4=7/10 and a dominant nodule of 1.1 cm in size. Perineural invasion is present and there is a small focus of tumor at the inked margin of the right prostatic apex. No tumor is seen in the bladder neck FS specimen. Specimen D is bladder neck FS with no carcinoma identified. Frozen sections of specimens A and D also showed no sign of carcinoma. There is no extraprostatic invasion seen elsewhere. A further clinical correlation is recommended.

The patient, a male with biopsy-proven left base of tongue squamous cell carcinoma, underwent near total glossectomy, partial pharyngectomy, left neck dissection, right neck dissection, and teeth extractions. The final diagnosis was invasive well to moderately-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma involving the left posterolateral tongue, pharynx, and soft palate, with lymph node involvement in multiple ipsilateral zones. The tumor extends to the right/midline lingual specimen margin, but separately submitted lingual margins are uninvolved. An immunohistochemical study for EGFR demonstrates moderate to strong labeling. The report includes gross descriptions of various specimens and their respective diagnoses. Some tests were developed and validated, but have not been cleared or approved by the FDA. The report does not include patient, doctor, hospital, or treatment plan details.

The report describes a case of lung malignant adenocarcinoma in a female patient with a lung nodule. The specimen received includes various lymph nodes, which showed negative results for malignancy upon microscopic examination. The left lower lobe measures 18.0 x 9.0 x 3.3 cm and reveals moderately anthracotic pulmonary parenchyma with a 1.2 cm intramural tan gritty nodule located 2.5 cm from the bronchial resection margin. The remaining lung reveals spongy and moderately anthracotic pulmonary parenchyma with no other mass lesion. A representative section of the nodule is submitted for frozen section while the remaining tumor is submitted for permanent section. The lobectomy specimen reveals adenocarcinoma (1.2 cm) in the lower lobe, which is moderately differentiated and unifocal, with no involvement of the pleura, bronchial margin, vascular margin, or parietal pleural margin, and no evidence of tumor extension. Three peribronchial lymph nodes were negative for malignancy. The primary tumor is categorized as pT1a, and there is no presence of regional lymph node metastasis (pNO).

Diagnosis: 1) The biopsy from the right periaortic lymph node shows metastatic tumor composed of epithelial cells of carcinosarcoma. 2) The total hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy specimen reveals a Carcinosarcoma of endometrium with heterologous differentiation, arising from an endometrial polyp. Myometrial Invasion (=<50%), measures 18 mm in maximum depth and endocervical invasive depth measures 1.5mm. No lymphovascular invasion identified. 3) The omentum excision shows metastatic serous adenocarcinoma to the omentum and two benign lymph nodes (0/2).

Final Diagnosis: Adrenal tumor (adrenalectomy) with multiple pheochromocytomas. The specimen contains at least four contiguous, but apparently separate, nodules of pheochromocytoma, 0.8-2.5 cm in greatest dimension. Three of the nodules are entirely intra-adrenal, while the fourth bulges through the adrenal capsule and is partly extra-adrenal. The nodules vary in cytomorphological appearance, consistent with separate neoplasms rather than a single coarse nodular one. Immunohistochemical staining for Ki67 is low overall, with occasional hot spots. Hyaline globules are focally prominent. Calcitonin is negative in all nodules, while S100 shows variable numbers of sustentacular cells stained in a patchy distribution. Neurofilament shows rare tumor cells and neurons positive. SDHB staining is positive, consistent with normal succinate dehydrogenase genes. No definite adrenal medullary hyperplasia is observed, and there is no periadrenal soft tissue invasion, vascular invasion, or necrosis. There is no evidence of a composite tumor. The presence of multiple pheochromocytomas suggests the possibility of a hereditary tumor syndrome, most likely MEN2. Clinicopathologic correlation is recommended.

Diagnosis: Papillary sebosradenocareinoma grade tumor, which completely replaces the specimen's surface, identified in the left ovary and fallopian tube. Lymphovascular space invasion was not identified.  Metastatic serous adenocarcinoma involving one of the two examined pelvic lymph nodes was also identified. Inflammation and mesothelial reaction were detected in the omentum specimen, but no neoplasm was found. No pathologic changes were detected in the right ovary, fallopian tube, cervix, endometrium, and myometrium. Staging sheet #3 indicates pTNM staging of T3c, N1, MX (FIGO: IIIC). Preoperative diagnosis was a pelvic mass, and symptoms/radiologic findings were not specified. The specimens received were left tube and ovary, left pelvic, omentum, uterus, cervix, and right tube and ovary. Gross description details for each specimen were provided, including their dimensions, color, texture, and presence of lesions. Genomic research study cassettes were also received for three of the specimens.

The pathology report describes multiple excisions, including soft tissue and kidney samples from the left kidney of a patient with renal tumors. The report details various masses identified as renal cell carcinoma, papillary type I, along with benign tissue and scar tissue. All of the soft tissue samples, including "psuedocapsule/lateral," "anterior perirenal fat," "perirenal fat - upper pole," and "scar tissue," did not contain any detectable tumors. A skin biopsy and rib fragment were also submitted and found to be negative for any tumorous growth.

The total thyroidectomy specimen consists of bilateral and multifocal papillary carcinoma, with the dominant tumor being classical variant with focal tall cell change (<5%), and a microcarcinoma in the right lobe. The left lobe tumor measures 1.1 cm in greatest dimension, despite chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis, and the margins are uninvolved by carcinoma. Tumor capsule is partially encapsulated with minimal present tumor capsular invasion. Lymph-vascular and perineural invasion are not identified, and extrathyroidal extension is not present. No regional lymph node metastasis is detected in 6 examined lymph nodes. The thyroid specimen weighs 15.5g, and there is a well-delineated partly calcified nodule in the lower left lobe measuring 1.1 cm x 0.9 cm x 0.7 cm. Additional findings include multiple microcarcinomas in the bilateral and isthmic areas.  Sections of the left lobe nodule and normal tissue are stored frozen.
Summary: Diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma WHO grade III based on histology and morphology.
Filtered Report: The patient's birth date is noted along with the tumor site in the right fronto-temporal region. The histological diagnosis of the tumor is glioblastoma multiforme.

Diagnosis: Partial colon resection material with an ulcerated moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma. Invasive tumor spread observed within all parietal layers, extending to within 6cm of a resection margin. One of the 26 lymph nodes showed a metastasis of the colon carcinoma not extending over the capsule. Other lymph nodes with uncharacteristic reactive lesions. Tumor stage confirmed as pT3 pN1 (1/26) LO V0; G2 R0. Colon otherwise shows several pseudodiverticula and slight chronically scarring peridiverticulitis.

Diagnosis: High grade dedifferentiated liposarcoma with a fibrosarcoma/malignant fibrous histiocytoma-like appearance. The tumor is adherent to the diaphragm skeletal muscle and bowel wall and is surrounded by a thin intact membrane, however, microscopic examination showed tumor extending to the inked surface. The tumor also has areas of necrosis, estimated grossly as 10%. The specimen consists of a 24.5 x 18 x 11 cm mass with a portion of terminal ileum, cecum, colon, mesentery, and an appendix. Grossly, the mass is covered by peritoneal and fibrous membranes and has a lobulated yellow-tan cut surface with areas of necrosis and hemorrhage mixed with myxoid areas. The specimen sections include the appendix, bowel margins, representative bowel sections, tumor with diaphragm, tumor with margins, and tumor with peritoneum.

Diagnosis: Renal cell carcinoma (5.0 cm maximum dimension) with clear and eosinophilic cells, Fuhrman nuclear grade 3, confined to the kidney. Renal adenoma and renal cortical cyst also present. Adrenal gland is free of tumor. The tumor does not invade into the perinephric adipose tissue, renal sinus or the renal vein.
Gross description: A radical nephrectomy specimen including the left kidney, renal artery, renal vein, ureter, and adrenal gland. The tumor is well-circumscribed, red-yellow with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis, confined to the kidney, and close to but not invading the renal sinus or vein. A multiloculated cyst is present in the upper pole of the kidney. No lymph nodes are identified in the hilum of the kidney. The adrenal gland is unremarkable.
Clinical history: Left renal mass.

Left temporal lobe of brain neoplasm biopsies and removal reveal glioblastoma multiforme (WHO grade IV), small cell variant. The tumor has extensive cortical permeation and subpial spread with heterogeneous differentiation observed on immunohistochemical stains. Intraoperative consultations confirm the glioblastoma multiforme diagnosis. Gross descriptions of the specimen show multiple irregular segments of tan-white, soft tissue and opaque white to pink-tan, soft tissue fragments measuring in aggregate 5.0 x 4.8 X 0.65 cm. The specimen is submitted entirely in three cassettes for frozen and permanent section analysis.

A  year old patient with papillary thyroid carcinoma underwent a biopsy of right paratracheal tissue, R/O left lower parathyroid, left paratracheal lymph node, total thyroid, and additional left paratracheal tissue. The biopsy revealed benign fibroadipose tissues in the right paratracheal tissue, benign enlarged hypercellular parathyroid gland in R/O left lower parathyroid, and micrometastatic papillary carcinoma in the left paratracheal lymph node. The total thyroid biopsy indicated papillary carcinoma, tall cell variant, within the left lobe measuring 1.3 cm and an additional separate papillary microcarcinoma in the left lobe. Three encapsulated nodules were identified in the left lobe and four encapsulated nodules were found in the right lobe. The report confirmed that the surgical margins were free of tumor, and no adenoma(s) were identified away from the carcinoma. Lastly, in the additional left paratracheal tissue biopsy, one lymph node was positive for micrometastatic papillary carcinoma.

The colon resection material is tumor-free except for an ulcerated, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with two regional lymph node metastases and penetration of the peritoneum, serosa, and liver metastases. The cancer is graded as G2 with a pT4 L1 V0 pN1 2/17 pM1 HEP/PER classification.

The pathology report describes the findings of a partial right nephrectomy surgery to remove a kidney mass. The mass is confirmed to be a 3.6 cm papillary renal cell carcinoma, along with papillary adenomas less than 0.5 cm. The carcinoma is of papillary type 1 with low-grade nuclear features, and is limited to the kidney without lymphatic/vascular invasion. The surgical margins are negative for tumor, and the tumor extends into perinephric adipose tissue. The report also notes the possibility of the patient having hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma syndrome, and suggests further studies and genetic counseling may be considered. The pathologic stage of the tumor is pT3aNXM0, with no lymph node or distant metastasis. A representative tissue is submitted for frozen section diagnosis.

The pathology report describes the results of mutational analysis and FISH for a non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) specimen from the left lower lobe of the lung. PCR-based DNA sequencing targeting exons 18-21 of the EGFR gene and exons 1 and 2 of the KRAS gene showed no mutations or sequence changes. FISH analysis revealed no rearrangement of the ALK gene, but gain of the ALK region was detected in 79% of cells. The tumor was well-differentiated adenocarcinoma and was confined to the left lower lobe, without involvement of the visceral pleura or lymphovascular spaces. Two lymph nodes were found to be negative for malignancy. Ancillary studies are pending. No treatment plan or patient information was provided.

Final Pathologic Diagnosis: Soft tissue, left thigh, excision: Leiomyosarcoma (6.5 cm in greatest dimension). Procedure: Radical resection. Tumor site: Left thigh. Tumor size: 6.5 cm (greatest dimension). Histologic type: Leiomyosarcoma. Mitotic rate: 12/10 high-power fields (HPF). Histologic grade: High grade. Margins: Margins negative for sarcoma, peripheral margin is 0.1 cm from the tumor. Ancillary studies showed no additional pathologic findings. Gender: F.

The pathology report describes various findings from a tissue sample. The spleen tissue appears normal and includes regular red and white pulp. Free fatty tissue and lymph nodes are observed. There is a poorly differentiated advanced gastric carcinoma, which is an invasive adenocarcinoma of the intestinal type that has infiltrated all wall layers, with lymphatic vessel penetration and metastases in the adjacent lymph nodes and fatty connective tissues. The report also mentions regular anastomotic rings of the small bowel and inflammatory reactive changes in the pancreas. Further secondary resections are required. The TNM classification includes infiltration of omental tissue and peritoneum, and infiltration of lymph nodes in the area of the omentum. The tumor classification is ICDO-DA-M 8140/3, pT3, pN1, L1. A consultation was held regarding the definitive TNM classification and a clear margin of healthy tissue was removed locally during the operation.

The pathology report describes a 40-year-old female with left breast cancer. The sample includes a sentinel lymph node with isolated tumor cells detected by immunohistochemical staining, benign fibroadipose and vascular connective tissue with no evidence of lymph nodes, and invasive lobular carcinoma of outer upper and mid quadrant. The lobular carcinoma is graded as 2, moderately differentiated, and has a size greater than 5.0 cm. Additionally, a smaller separate tumor is found within the inner upper quadrant. Ancillary studies performed on a core biopsy reveal positive estrogen and progesterone receptors, negative HER 2 neu by IHC, and lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS). No lymph node metastases are found except for one with isolated tumor cells. The deep margin is inked black and is negative for malignancy. The report notes the prior core biopsy, and the case received prospective peer review. Additionally, the report includes detailed gross descriptions of the specimen received.

Left kidney and adrenal gland radical nephrectomy specimen with a 9.0 cm renal cell carcinoma, conventional, consisting of 60% clear cells and 40% eosinophilic cells, with Fuhrman's nuclear grade 4. Tumor extends into renal vein and appears to invade renal sinus and perirenal fat but not reaching Gerota's fascia. No tumor is present in the adrenal gland and adjacent renal parenchyma is unremarkable. No hilar lymph nodes are identified.

Filtered report: The pathology report describes a resected tissue sample from the right lower lobe with well-differentiated papillary non-mucigenous adenocarcinoma measuring 50mm. The tumor extends to the visceral pleura and the bronchial resection level. Subpleural areas of scarring and pleural residues of adhesion are also noted. The tumor classification is M-8140/3, G1, pT2 2, pN0, and pMX. The tumor is staged as IB, and R0.

The pathology report describes a lobulated soft tissue mass in the abdomen and pelvis with bilateral renal cyst and hydronephrosis. A biopsy shows atypical smooth muscle proliferation, favoring low-grade leiomyosarcoma. Samples of the appendix and appendectomy reveal mucinous cystadenoma with diverticulum formation and mucus extravasation with no carcinoma identified, and the surgical margin is uninvolved. A radical resection of the pelvic sarcoma shows high-grade leiomyosarcoma with the tumor measuring 19.0 x 18.8 x 15.2 cm, necrosis and eight mitotic figures identified. The tumor extends to the surgical margin. The skin with the abdominal scar shows gray-tar wrinkled skin with a linear scar and is representatively submitted. Further sections of the specimens are also submitted for examination.

The report indicates that a  year-old female had three separate renal masses, one of which was biopsied and diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma, chromophobe type, nuclear grade 2. The second and third masses were treated with partial nephrectomy and were also diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma, chromophobe type, with histological grades of 2 and 3. The tumors were well-circumscribed and multifocal, but no invasion of surrounding tissues or organs was identified. Surgical margins were free of tumor, and no metastasis was observed in lymph nodes. The AJCC staging for all masses was pT1a, pNx. The report provides gross description details of the four containers received for analysis.

The pathology report describes a tumor in the stomach—an exophytic, dense-elastic, white-pinkish mass measuring 6 x 5.5 x 1 cm—that invades all wall layers and extends into the lesser omentum. There is evidence of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, and 6 out of 18 examined lymph nodes have metastases. There is no lymphatic invasion or venous invasion, and the margins are uninvolved. No evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings are mentioned.
Cervix biopsy shows invasive poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma.

Summary: The report describes the examination of five specimens received for a patient diagnosed with SCC lung. Out of the five specimens, four are lymph nodes while one is a right upper lobe of the lung. The lung specimen shows a moderately-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. The peribronchial resection margin shows involvement predominantly through spread along perineural spaces, but there is no involvement of overlying pleura. The remaining lung parenchyma shows emphysematous changes predominantly in a subpleural location. The lymph nodes show reactive changes only with no evidence of metastatic carcinoma.

Patient has been diagnosed with left breast invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) and ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) with intermediate nuclear grade located in the upper inner quadrant measuring 1.5cm in its largest dimension. The malignant tissue is negative for vascularity and it is not affecting the surgical margins. The results of special stains and re-cuts from deeper levels have been ordered, and the results will be noted in an addendum that includes the HER2 test, estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) status. Additionally, benign breast tissue with fibrocystic changes, including ductal hyperplasia without atypia and apocrine metaplasia, is identified in right breast mastectomy. No metastatic tumor is found in the examined sentinel lymph nodes.

This is a pathology report for a patient with malig neo corpus uterus. The patient underwent a bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, hysterectomy, omentectomy, peritoneal biopsies, and hernia sac repair. The report includes gross and microscopic examination findings for the right fallopian tube and ovary, left fallopian tube and ovary, uterus and cervix, bladder flap peritoneum, cul-de-sac peritoneum, and omentum. The report indicates the presence of serous adenocarcinoma in the right and left fallopian tube and ovary, as well as in the bladder flap and cul-de-sac peritoneum. The uterus and cervix had serous papillary carcinoma involving the endometrium, which was limited to the endometrium without myometrial invasion or lymphatic/vascular invasion. Multiple implants of serous adenocarcinoma were found in the serosa. The pathology stage is TxNxMx, with an uncertain primary origin site. The report notes that it is not possible to determine a primary site with certainty. Further testing revealed that the tumor was unreactive for Wilm's tumor gene (WT-1), supporting the primary tumor's endometrial origin. The report includes no information about the patient's name, doctor name, hospital name, reference, treatment plan, or sample size, shape, and weight.

Summary: The report describes an advanced colon cancer that has spread to all layers of the colon and the blood vessels (mucinous adenocarcinoma of the colon, G3, pT3, L1, V1). The mucosa, submucosa, and muscularis layers appear normal, and there is no cancer found at the radial resection margin. None of the 14 lymph nodes analyzed show any cancer cells (0/14).

Diagnosis: Endometrioid adenocarcinoma with spindle cell metaplasia located in the endometrium. Inner half myometrial invasion with a depth of 3 mm and a wall thickness of 8 mm, representing 37.5% invasion. No evidence of serosal or cervical involvement, lymphovascular space invasion, adnexal involvement, or lymph node involvement. The cancer is ER and PR positive. The AJCC pathological stage is pT1b pNO pMx, and the FIGO stage grouping is IB. The adnexa, fallopian tubes, and lymph nodes examined have no tumors. Atrophic endometrial polyps and vascular calcifications are noted within myometrium. The report is subject to change based on additional information and clinical review.

The pathology report describes a case of a right lung mass where a pneumonectomy has been performed. The specimen received is labeled "right lung" and weighs 757 grams, with nodules present on the lung, pleura, and pulmonary vasculature. Microscopic examination indicates adenocarcinoma extending into the middle lobe. The tumor is moderately differentiated and has invaded the visceral pleura and lymphovascular spaces. Metastatic carcinoma is present in 5 out of 10 lymph nodes examined. A limited panel of immunohistochemical stains is positive for TTF1 and CK7 and negative for CK20, supporting the diagnosis of primary lung malignancy. The report mentions that the test performed by the laboratory is used for clinical purposes and the laboratory is certified under the Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments.

The pathology report describes various biopsies and excisions from different locations within the patient's body. The lymph nodes from right levels 10 and 4, and level 7 had no evidence of carcinoma and only showed anthracotic lymph nodes with lipid granulomas. The soft tissue from the right posterior chest wall showed no evidence of malignancy but had a portion of lung with inflammatory changes, organizing pneumonia, fibrin deposition, and necrosis. The right fifth rib was partially resected and showed no carcinoma. The pleura from the right parietal resection had chronic inflammation and fibrosis but no malignancy. The pneumonectomy of the right lung showed moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma with extensive necrosis, measuring 4.5 cm. Additionally, eight hilar lymph nodes were free of carcinoma. The surgical margins showed no carcinoma, and there was no definitive angiolymphatic invasion identified. The patient's TNM staging was pT2a NO. Lastly, there was no extrapulmonary extension, lymphatic invasion, or satellite lesions identified. The patient had chronic interstitial pneumonia as an underlying disease.

The pathology report describes an adenocarcinoma of the stomach that has invaded into the perigastric fat, with metastases in 10 out of the 15 examined lymph nodes. The tumor is poorly differentiated and located in the antrum, measuring 4x0x6 cm, and is ulcerated. Lymphatic invasion is present and there is no evidence of venous invasion. The margins are uninvolved. In the omentum, there is a focal prevascular lymphoid infiltration. There is no information regarding neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings.

The pathology report describes a case of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, with a tumor size of 3.0 cm that invades muscularis propria. Surgical margins are free of tumor with a closest margin radial at 8 mm. Eighteen lymph nodes are negative for tumor, and chronic cholecystitis is observed. Pathologic tumor staging synopsis indicates pT2 primary tumor, pNO regional lymph nodes, and pMX distant metastasis, resulting in a pathologic stage of IB. Lymphovascular invasion is not identified, and the margin status is R0, negative. Additional pathologic findings include gastrointestinal stromal tumor, chronic inactive gastritis with intestinal metaplasia, and esophagitis, consistent with gastroesophageal reflux. The report covers examination of three specimens: pancreatic lymph node, gallbladder, and total gastrectomy, with the latter demonstrating the presence of a 3.0 cm tumor that invades muscularis propria. Immunohistochemistry confirms a gastrointestinal stromal tumor located in the muscularis propria. No metastatic tumor cells are identified, and no Helicobacter organisms are identified by immunohistochemistry.

Pathological diagnosis: Brain, left frontal, excisional biopsies reveal an astrocytoma with atypical features. Brain, left frontal excision shows an astrocytoma with anaplastic features and a MIB-1 proliferation index of 2-3%. Another brain, left frontal excision shows an astrocytoma with atypical features. Microscopic analysis shows a heavily infiltrating and diffusely spreading glial neoplastic proliferation in the cerebral cortex and white matter. The proliferation has round or ovoid nuclei with a prominent single nucleolus. There are mitotic figures, microvascular cellular proliferation, or necrosis. Immunohistochemistry shows heavy and diffuse gliofibrilogenesis, proliferative indices of 2-3%, and absent microvascular cellular proliferation and necrosis. Morphological features suggest an astrocytoma with anaplastic transformation from a low-grade tumor.

The patient has a history of retroperitoneal mass consistent with moderately differentiated leiomyosarcoma, and multiple specimens were submitted for evaluation. The tumor capsule biopsy shows a fragment of high-grade leiomyosarcoma and hemorrhage. The left common iliac vein specimen reveals a 3 cm segment encased by high-grade leiomyosarcoma, with positive soft tissue margins and negative vascular margin. The left ureter segmental resection shows a 1 cm segment encased and invaded by high-grade leiomyosarcoma, with a positive soft tissue margin peripherally. The left colon segmental resection shows a segment with focal mucosal hyperplastic changes but no tumor identified. The retroperitoneal tumor excision reveals a high-grade leiomyosarcoma measuring 18 cm, with close but negative margins. Additional immunoperoxidase stains for SMA, DESMIN, and CMA are positive, supporting a diagnosis of leiomyosarcoma, while a stain for C-KIT is negative.

The pathology report indicates a case of moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma in a right hemicolectomy preparation. The tumor measures 6 cm in diameter and has invaded all intestinal wall layers, including bordering fatty tissue. The resection margins and greater omentum are tumor-free, but two out of ten lymph nodes show metastases. A tubulovillous adenoma of the mucous membrane with moderate epithelial dysplasia is present in the cecum. Additionally, a subcapsular liver parenchyma section reveals complete cirrhotic remodeling and pronounced fatty degeneration (fatty liver cirrhosis). A follow-up report indicates 31 lymph nodes ranging from very small to 0.7cm in diameter, all of which are tumor-free. The final lymph node status is determined to be pN1 (2/41).

The report describes the results of a left hemiglossectomy due to invasive squamous cell carcinoma with severe dysplasia/carcinoma in situ present at the lateral margin. Perineural invasion and metastatic cancer were also found in regional lymph nodes on the left neck levels 2 and 3-4. Benign tissue was found at the base of the tongue and additional margins. The final pathologic stage was determined as pT3 N2b. The report includes detailed gross descriptions and microscopic analysis information for each specimen. No outside tissue diagnosis was provided, and the patient's medical history was not disclosed.

The report describes specimens submitted for a left retroperitoneal mass and includes a diagnosis of dedifferentiated liposarcoma with a focal well-differentiated liposarcoma component. The report mentions the tumor measures 10 cm and has some necrosis present. The report also includes details about the spleen and omentum, which show mature adipose tissue. Sections were representatively submitted for each specimen. An addendum includes a negative result for immunohistochemical stains for CDK4 and MDM2. There is no mention of patient or doctor name, hospital name, reference, treatment plan, sample size, shape, or weight.

The pathology report describes a case of invasive squamous carcinoma, moderately differentiated, measuring 2.5cm in largest dimension and infiltrating to a depth of 1.5cm. The report confirms negative tumor status in multiple lymph nodes across various levels of the neck and parotid region. The report also notes the absence of bone or cartilage invasion in the mandible. A composite resection of mandible floor of mouth and tongue was performed and the margins of resection were grossly uninvolved. Bone margins are negative for carcinoma. No tumor was found in the left posterior tongue margin, posterior deep tongue, left mylohyoid, and digastric muscles. The patient's clinical history and SNOMED codes are also provided.

The pathology report is for a patient who had a right breast and axillary sentinel lymph node mastectomy and biopsy. The report shows the presence of multicentric invasive lobular carcinoma, Nottingham grade 1-2, which is spread across an 8cm area of the breast. Two axillary lymph nodes are tumor-free, and resection margins are also free of cancerous tissues. Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is widespread throughout the right breast, and the patient has no distant metastasis. The invasive tumor size in the central area of the breast is 8cm, has a slightly stellate appearance, and is soft and rubbery. The grossly identifiable surgical margins of the specimens are negative, and no lymph nodes are identified within the lateral portion of the excision. The pathology report also shows the presence of subareolar duct ectasia, focal fibrosis, cysts, mild usual type ductal hyperplasia, and a discrete focus of scar tissue in the central inferior breast. As for receptor status and HER2/neu, Estrogen and Progesterone receptors are positive, while Her2/neu is 1+. The pathological stage is IIB.

DIAGNOSIS: Uterus with papillary serous carcinoma forming a mass of 3.0 x 2.1 x 1.8 cm invading 0.3 cm into a 1.5 cm thick myometrium, FIGO grade III. No involvement of the lower uterine segment and cervix. Both right and left ovaries and fallopian tubes show no abnormality. Multiple lymph nodes including right and left pelvic, right and left para-aortic, as well as additional right para-aortic below the inferior mesenteric artery lymph nodes are negative for tumor. Omentum and multiple staging biopsies are also negative.

Final Pathologic Diagnosis: Thymoma, WHO type B2. The tumor breached the capsule but did not definitively invade peri-thymic adipose tissue. Gross description revealed a tan-yellow soft tissue specimen with a firm, well-circumscribed lesion on one edge. Microscopic examination was performed and F. Race was identified as White.

A female underwent surgical treatment for papillary thyroid carcinoma of conventional type, located in the right lobe of the thyroid gland, without any multi-focality and any extrathyroidal extension. Resection margins were negative, and background thyroid showed chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis consistent with Hashimoto's thyroiditis. No lymphovascular invasion or involvement of lymph nodes was evident. A single dark red nodule measuring 0.8 x 0.3 x 0.2 cm, located in the right paratracheal region, was negative for tumor. The entire thyroid gland, including an enlarged left lobe and right pyramidal lobe, was submitted for pathological examination. The report is SNOMED coded as T-B6000, M-80503, and M-B0630, and no clinical history is provided.

Summary: The report describes a case of a patient with right neck swelling, dysphagia, odynophagia, and bilateral otalgia. Fine needle aspiration showed squamous cell carcinoma. The report mentions two biopsy samples received in formalin for analysis: one from the left tongue base and another from the left aryepiglottic fold. Microscopic examination of both samples identified invasive basaloid squamous cell carcinoma. The report is signed by the staff pathologist.

Pathology report: Left temporal lobe biopsy revealed an anaplastic gemistocytic astrocytoma with a MIB-1 proliferative index of about 12%. Gross pathology showed irregular tan white friable soft tissue fragments with some sections having hemorrhagic and necrotic focus. Microscopic examination of sections indicated diffusion of the astrocytoma into the leptomeninges. The tumor is composed mainly of gemistocytic and undifferentiated cells with hypercellularity, nuclear pleomorphism, and hyperchromasia. Mild vascular endothelial hyperplasia is present but there is no necrosis. GFAP is strongly positive in tumor cells.

The pathology report describes the diagnosis of prostate cancer in the patient. The report contains details about the different specimens received for analysis, including tissue over the prostate, right extended pelvic lymph nodes, and radical prostatectomy specimen. The report specifies adenocarcinoma of the prostate, mostly in the peripheral zone, with a Gleason score of 3 + 4 = 7/10. The report also indicates the absence of lymphatic invasion but presence of perineural invasion. One of the margins is positive, while the others are clear, with no extraprostatic invasion. The TNM stage of the tumor is revised as pT3a, pNo, pMX. No treatment effect on carcinoma is identified. The report ends with details about the procedure followed for diagnosis, including 26 blocks of H&E X1 stains for different specimens.

A 6cm tall cell variant papillary thyroid carcinoma with extracapsular extension was identified in the left lobe of a patient who underwent total thyroidectomy. One lymph node with metastatic carcinoma was detected in the excised tissue. Three of four lymph nodes in the central compartment also had metastatic carcinoma. The tumor was negative for mutations in NRAS61, HRAS61, KRAS12/13, and RET/PTC rearrangement, but tested positive for the BRAF V600E mutation. The tumor is staged as pT3 N1a MX with negative surgical resection margins, although the tumor is seen 0.1cm from the margins. The sample also contained benign thyroid tissue with nodular hyperplasia. RET/PTC FISH analysis did not show any rearrangement pattern. The report includes additional information on the molecular studies ordered, specimen preparation, and procedures used.

Specimen received is a partial hepatectomy and cholecystectomy of liver Segment V and VI, and gallbladder from a patient with hepatocellular carcinoma. The tumor is moderately differentiated and measures 3.4 cm in greatest dimension with possible intrahepatic metastasis. No lymphovascular invasion is identified. Resection margins are negative for malignancy. One benign lymph node is present. There is background cirrhosis and chronic hepatitis. Grossly, the liver has a nodular and cirrhotic appearance with no second mass lesion identified. The gallbladder is unremarkable. Several sections are submitted for further analysis.

Final Diagnosis: A. Gallbladder Cholecystectomy: Gallbladder with chronic cholecystitis. B. Lymph Node Hepatic Artery Biopsy: One lymph node with metastatic adenocarcinoma 1/1. C. Biliary Stent Removal: Biliary stent, gross diagnosis only. D. Pancreatoduodenectomy: Adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated, pancreatic ductal origin, perineural target-vessel, and lymphatic invasion identified. Carcinoma invades the duodenum, common bile duct, Ampulla, and peripancreatic tissue. Adjacent pancreatic parenchyma with panIN 3. Adenocarcinoma involves 1 of 27 lymph nodes 1/27. The attending pathologist personally reviewed all slides and CL materials and rendered the final diagnosis electronically. Comment: The carcinoma seems to be of pancreatic origin based on the presence of extensive pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia and the lack of Ampullary precursors. The bulk of the invasive carcinoma is within the pancreas and secondarily involves the Ampulla and duodenum. Deeper sections were examined of lymph node blocks D31-D32, D41, and D43. Key Pathological Findings: Specimen type: D. Pancreas-Exocrine Synoptic Data. Specimen type: Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple resection), partial pancreatectomy. Tumor site: Pancreatic head. Tumor size: Invasive-1.5 cm. Other Organs Resected: Gallbladder, duodenum, distal stomach. Ductal Adenocarcinoma. Histologic grade: G2-Moderately differentiated. Duodenum, bile duct. Primary Tumor (pT): pT3-Tumor extends beyond the pancreas but without involvement of the celiac axis or the superior mesenteric artery. Regional Lymph Nodes (pN): pN1a-Metastasis in single regional lymph node. Number examined: 28, Number involved: 2. Distant Metastasis (pM): pMX: Cannot be assessed. Margins: Margins free of tumor. Venous (large vessel) Invasion (V): Present. Lymphatic (small vessel) Invasion (L): Present. Perineural invasion: Absent. Additional pathologic findings: Pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (highest grade: PanIN 3). Comment(s): Lymph node count includes the hepatic artery lymph node. Specimen(s) Received: A. Gallbladder, B. Hepatic Artery Node, C. Biliary Stent Gross Only, D. Whipple 4FS. Clinical History: Ampullary Cancer. Preoperative Diagnosis: Ampullary Cancer. Intraoperative Consultation: FSD1- Pancreatic Margin-Negative, FSD2: Common Bile Duct Margin-Negative, FSD3, FSD4- Retroperitoneal Margin (perpendicular) - Negative. Comment: This frozen section diagnosis/result was communicated to and acknowledged by Dr. in. I,. M.D., who performed the intraoperative consultation(s) and issued the above diagnosis. Gross Description: A. The specimen was received fresh in 4 containers. Specimen A is labeled Gallbladder. The specimen consists of a gallbladder measuring 8 x 4 x 3 cm. The serosa covering the gallbladder is pink-tan to dusky purple, smooth, and glistening. No transmural perforations are grossly identified. The gallbladder's contents consist of a moderate amount of dark green, viscous bile. The mucosa of the gallbladder is elevated and grossly unremarkable. The cystic duct is patent to the flow of bile and has a 0.3 cm in diameter fumen. No lymph nodes are grossly identified attached to the gallbladder's neck. The gallbladder's wall is mildly edematous, averaging 0.3 cm in thickness. No tissue was submitted to the Tissue Procurement Laboratory. Representative sections of the specimen are submitted in 2 cassettes, A1, and A2. B. Specimen B is labeled Hepatic Artery Node. The specimen consists of a single, roughly ovoid, rubbery potential lymph node measuring up to 1.4 cm in greatest dimension. No tissue was submitted to the Tissue Procurement Laboratory. The lymph node is serially sectioned and is submitted entirely in 2 cassettes, B1, and B2. C. Specimen C is labeled Biliary Stent, Gross Only. The specimen consists of a blue plastic tube 13.0 cm in length and 0.2 cm in diameter. The ends of the tube reveal a patent lumen up to 0.2 cm in diameter. No sticky material is identified on the tube surface. The specimen is received for gross analysis only. D. Specimen D is labeled Whipple; frozen section on retroperitoneal margin, pancreatic margin, bile duct. The specimen consists of a pancreatic head (7 x x 2.5 cm) with attached duodenum (16.0 cm in length and up to 4.5 cm in circumference at the level of the distal resection margin) and distal portion of the stomach (4.5 cm in length and up to 10.0 cm in circumference at the level of stapled gastric resection margin). The stomach's serosa is pink-tan, smooth, and glistening, while the duodenum's outer surface is shaggy with a small amount of fibroadipose tissue attached. There is also a small amount of omental adipose tissue attached to the gastric wall. The peripheral aspects of the pancreatic head are composed of a small amount of adipose tissue ranging from 0.1 to 0.3 cm in thickness. Prior to sectioning, the specimen is inked as follows: Anterior aspect of the pancreatic head-Green, Medial aspect (groove)-Red, Stapled retroperitoneal margin-Orange, The remainder of the posterior aspect of the pancreatic head-Black, Parenchymal resection margin-Black, Common bile duct margin-Blue. On opening, the duodenum reveals an irregular, ill-defined, sessile, focal hemorrhagic tumor measuring 1.5 x 1 cm, which involves the ampulla of Vater. On sectioning, the tumor measures up to 0.5 cm in depth and appears to involve the adjacent portion of the pancreatic head. The tumor also appears to involve the distal portion of the common bile duct and main pancreatic duct. A 1.0 distal cm of the common bile duct and the area of junction between the main pancreatic duct and common bile duct are partly obstructed by the tumor. The dilated portion of the common bile duct located distal to the obstructed area is 0.5 cm from the closest retroperitoneal resection margin and is dilated up to 1.8 cm in circumference. The remaining parenchyma of the pancreatic head is pale yellow, lobulated, rubbery to the firm with some areas of intralobular fibrosis within the parenchyma surrounding the dilated portion of the common bile duct. The portion of pancreatic parenchyma adjacent to the parenchymal resection margin is grossly unremarkable. Several potential lymph nodes are grossly identified within fibroadipose tissue surrounding the pancreatic head. The remaining mucosa of the duodenum and stomach is grossly unremarkable. Representative sections of the specimen are submitted to the Tissue Procurement Laboratory. Representative sections of the specimen are submitted for frozen section analysis, and frozen section remnants are submitted in 4 cassettes as follows: FSD1: Pancreatic resection margin, tangential section. FSD2: Common bile duct margin, tangential section. FSD3, FSD4: Retroperitoneal margin (perpendicular cross-sections) closest to the tumor. Additional sections of the specimen are submitted in 39 cassettes, D5-D43, as follows: D5-D6: Gastric resection margin, tangential section. D7: Duodenal resection margin, tangential section. D8: Ampulla of Vater with the adjacent area of the junction between the main pancreatic duct and the common bile duct. D9-D12: The remainder of the tumor involving the ampulla of Vater with adjacent distal portion of the common bile duct. D13-D15: Additional sections of the retroperitoneal margin concerning the main pancreatic duct.
