D16-D19: Additional sections of the indurated parenchyma of the pancreatic head adjacent to the common bile duct and the main pancreatic duct. D20: Dilated portion of the common bile duct. D21: Additional section of the duodenum adjacent to the ampulla of Vater. D22-D24: Additional sections of the pancreatic head adjacent to the common bile duct and the main pancreatic duct. D25-D27: The remaining fibroadipose tissue, anterior aspect of the pancreatic head. D28: The remaining fibroadipose tissue attached to the medial aspect of the pancreatic head. D29-D30: The remaining fibroadipose tissue, superior aspect of the pancreatic head. D31-D34: The remaining adipose tissue of the retroperitoneal aspect with potential lymph nodes. D35-D36: A portion of less omental adipose tissue in its entirety. D37-D43: A portion of greater omentum with potential lymph nodes.

The pathology report describes specimens obtained from different parts of a patient's body, including a portion of the sixth rib, mediastinal lymph nodes, right level 4 lymph nodes, and level 7 lymph nodes, as well as a right lung pneumonectomy. The report notes that no tumors were seen in any of the lymph nodes, and there was no invasion of visceral pleura. However, the right lung pneumonectomy revealed a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with clear cell changes, measuring 7cm. The bronchial and vascular margins were negative, and no tumor was seen in fifteen peribronchial lymph nodes.

The pathology report describes a 12 x 9.5 x 4 cm infiltrating ductal carcinoma with a prominent lobular component, with a histological grade of 3 out of 3 and nuclear grade of 2 out of 3. The tumor is multifocal, present in all quadrants of the breast, with in-situ carcinoma occupying 5% of the tumor and having a lobular type. The non-neoplastic breast tissue shows fibrocystic change including intraductal hyperplasia, ductal ectasia, and apocrine metaplasia. Lymphatic/vascular invasion is present and metastatic carcinoma is present in five of ten lymph nodes with extracapsular extension. The nipple and skin are uninvolved by carcinoma, and surgical margins are negative for carcinoma. Microcalcifications are present. Estrogen/progesterone and cell cycle analysis are pending.

The pathology report includes information on various specimens from the patient's right and left breast, including a possible lymph node from the left axilla region. The report diagnoses focal atypical ductal hyperplasia, an invasive ductal carcinoma (poorly differentiated), and usual ductal hyperplasia in the patient's right and left breast tissue. Sentinel lymph nodes from the left axilla region are negative for carcinoma. The report also includes information on the ER/PR/HER2 status, which shows negative ER, positive PR, and negative HER2. Finally, the oncotpye Dx breast cancer assay shows a recurrence score of 52, indicating a high risk for future recurrence.

Prostate gland, radical prostatectomy. Histologic type is adenocarcinoma. Malignancy is identified in the left lobe only and accounts for less than 5% of the total prostate volume. Gleason grade is 6/10 (primary pattern=3/5, secondary pattern=3/5). Extraprostatic extension, seminal vesicle involvement, and lymphovascular space invasion are not identified. High-grade PIN and treatment effect are not identified. Margins uninvolved. No lymph nodes received. pTNM stage is pT2a, NX. The prostate is received with attached bilateral adnexa and shows an ill-defined mass involving the posterior quadrants. The mass approaches the inked capsule and is present at the prostate/seminal vesicle junction. Gross extension of this lesion into the seminal vesicle is not appreciated. Additional masses or calculi are not identified. Representative sections are submitted in cassettes 1-18. Clinical history and symptoms/radiologic findings are not explicitly stated.

The pathology report describes a left breast mastectomy specimen with invasive mammary carcinoma, micropapillary type, poorly differentiated and Nottingham Grade 3 present in 13/14 slides. Ductal carcinoma in situ is also present with a high nuclear grade (DIN3) as a single focus. Metastatic carcinoma is present in five out of five intra mammary lymph nodes, seventeen out of twenty axillary lymph nodes, two out of two lymph nodes in level 3 of the left lymph node dissection, and five out of five lymph nodes in the lymph node dissection above the left brachial plexus. Lymphovascular invasion is also present. The tumor is ER and PR positive and HER2 negative. The report does not include any information on the patient's identifying details, treatment plan, sample size, and weight.

The pathology report describes the specimens that were examined, namely the prostate and left and right pelvic lymph nodes. The diagnosis reveals prostatic adenocarcinoma involving 25% of the prostate gland with a Gleason score of 4+4=8/10. There is evidence of perineural invasion, while no lymphovascular invasion is seen. A microscopic focus of extraprostatic extension into fat is also identified on the right posterior capsule. The report concludes that lymph nodes taken from the left and right pelvic areas are negative for carcinoma. The gross description notes that the prostate measures 5.5 cm from right to left, 4.5 cm from anterior to posterior, and 3.2 cm from apex to base, with a weight of 35g. The attached seminal vesicles and vas deferens show no gross evidence of tumor involvement. The report also includes details on the clinical history, pre-operative diagnosis, and microscopic findings.

The pathology report describes a lung lobe with two separate rubbery mass lesions, one measuring 2.6 cm in diameter with pleural invasion and the other measuring 4 cm in diameter with yellow-orange discoloration around it suggestive of pneumonia. Both mass lesions consist of poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinoma with areas of squamous and glandular differentiation. Margins of resection for the bronchial and vascular are negative for malignancy, while metastatic carcinoma is present in 1 of 3 hilar lymph nodes. The report suggests that the two mass lesions could be either synchronous primaries or part of the same process, and recommends clinical correlation. Lymph nodes from level 11, 2R, 4R, and level 7 are negative for malignancy. Inflammatory changes with focal pneumonia are seen surrounding the tumors.

The pathology report indicates the presence of serous adenocarcinoma in various soft tissue locations, including the cul de sac, left pelvic peritoneum, sigmoid, retro cecal area, IP ligament, and right perinephric area. Additional involvement of lymph nodes and the omentum is also noted. The report suggests a peritoneal primary carcinoma, rather than a primary tubal carcinoma, based on involvement of paratubal soft tissues rather than the fallopian tube lumen. The tumor exhibits features of high-grade serous carcinoma, including papillary, glandular, and solid growth patterns, as well as psammoma bodies and lymphovascular invasion. No metastatic carcinoma is identified in lymph nodes. The report also notes additional findings, including benign endometrial polyps and leiomyoma, atrophic changes, and epithelial denudation/superficial mucosal erosion in the cervix.

A diagnosis of Grade II squamous carcinoma is present in the right sympathetic nerve sheath which involves the nerve with perineural invasion. A Grade II squamous carcinoma is also found in various connective tissues including the anterior compartment and deep subcutaneous tissue, esophagus, and lympho-vascular invasion. Fragments of the tumor are identified in transduced and non-transduced tumor specimens. A tumor is extensively involving connective tissue and perineural compartments at the base of the skull and is present at the designated resection margin. No tumor is identified in ten lymph nodes and in the thyroid gland. SNOMED codes for the same have also been provided.

Clinical Diagnosis: Adenocarcinoma of colon.
Specimens Submitted: 1. Segmental resection of Colon, right. 2. Omentectomy.
1. Segmental resection of Colon, right: Tumor Type: Adenocarcinoma with mucinous features (<50%-mucinous component). Histologic Grade: Moderately differentiated. Tumor Location: Cecum. Tumor Size: Length is 5 cm. Width is 8 cm. Maximal thickness is 0.4 cm. Deepest Tumor Invasion: Subserosal adipose tissue and/or mesenteric fat. Tumor Staging (AJCC 7th Edition) : pT3 (Tumor invades through the muscularis propria into pericolorectal tissues). Lymph Node Stage (AJCC 7th Edition). NO (No regional lymph node metastasis).
2. Omentectomy: BENIGN MATURE ADIPOSE TISSUE. No lymph nodes are grossly identified.

A specimen labeled "Right Colon" was received consisting of a partial colectomy specimen along with the appendix. The report shows the presence of an 11.8 cm poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with neuroendocrine and signet ring cell features and focal mucin production. The tumor has extended through the muscularis propria and involved the visceral peritoneum. Lymphovascular invasion is also present. The proximal, distal, and radial resection margins are free of the tumor. There is also a tan mucosal polyp and multiple lymph nodes ranging from 0.5-1.5 cm in greatest dimension. One out of thirty-two lymph nodes examined had metastatic carcinoma. The appendix has fibrous obliteration and peri-appendiceal adhesions. The clinical diagnosis was colon cancer.

A lymph node excision of nodes #7, L4, R4, R2, #10, R4, level 7 showed no malignancy. The right upper lobe lobectomy revealed an adenocarcinoma with clear cell features and mixed cell patterns. There is one peribronchial lymph node with metastatic adenocarcinoma, and centrolobular emphysema is present. Tumor size is 6.3 x 2.9 x 2.0 cm, vascular invasion is present, and the tumor infiltrates the visceral pleura to the pleural surface. Pathologic staging is p stage IIB (T2b N1 MX). TTF-1 is present, p63 is negative, and EGFR mutation analysis will be performed. Gross descriptions of the specimens are given. Microscopic details are not provided.

Final diagnosis: Hepatocellular carcinoma in the left lateral segment of the liver measuring 3.1 cm and moderately differentiated. Immunohistochemistry stains and special stains showed positive results for tumor cells and portal fibrosis with short fibrous septa, respectively. The tumor was solitary and had no vascular invasion, but the histologic grade and distant metastasis could not be assessed. The margins were uninvolved by invasive carcinoma with a distance of 9 mm from the closest margin. A sectioned representative tumor was submitted for further analysis. Clinical history indicates liver cancer (HCC), and the frozen section diagnosis revealed a 3.5 cm nodule located at least 1 cm from all margins. The surrounding parenchyma was dense, tan brown, and mildly indurated, while the vascular margins and normal-appearing parenchyma were submitted for additional testing.

Diagnosis: Uterine malignant mixed Mullerian tumor with myometrial invasion of 8.0 mm into a 24.0 mm thickness and lymphovascular invasion. Chronic inflammation and Nabothian cysts in cervix. Bilateral ovaries and tubes without tumor. Left pelvic lymph nodes have 2 lymph nodes without tumor, right common lymph node has 1 without tumor, left pelvic lymph nodes have 5 lymph nodes without tumor, left common lymph nodes have 2 without tumor, below the IMA para-aortic lymph node has 1 without a tumor, above IMA para-aortic lymph nodes have 9 without tumor. The tumor is predominantly a high grade carcinoma composed of undifferentiated carcinoma and high-grade serous carcinoma, with a sarcomatous component including malignant cartilage. Grossly, the uterus and cervix with bilateral ovaries and tubes are returned unremarkable except for the fleshy exophytic tan tumor replacing the endometrium, grossly invading less than half of the myometrial thickness. Ink code: Blue - anterior, black - posterior. The clinical history is uterine cancer. SNOMED codes: T-83020, M-89503.

Final diagnosis: Poorly differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Scarff-Bloom-Richardson grade III/III, measuring 10.5 cm in maximum dimension, with lymphovascular invasion present. Surgical margins are free of the lesion, except for the deep surgical margin which is 1.2 mm from the tumor. Ten out of fourteen lymph nodes are positive for metastatic carcinoma. Tumor stage: Stage IIIC, T3, N3, MX. Procedure: Modified radical mastectomy right breast, insertion mediport. Tissues: Breast mastectomy (WMV) nodes - right breast and axillary contents. Microscopic examination confirms the final diagnosis.

Postmenopausal patient diagnosed with endometrial cancer underwent total abdominal hysterectomy with pelvic lymph node dissection. The synoptic report showed a well-differentiated endometroid adenocarcinoma with a maximum dimension of 4.5 cm, involving 10% of the anterior endomyometrium and 30% of the posterior endomyometrium with greater than 1/2 thickness of myometrium invasion. Lymph node examination revealed 13 nodes examined and no lymph nodes were positive. Pathologic staging showed pT3a, pNo, and pMX with FIGO stage IIIA. The pelvic wash specimen was positive for malignant cells.

The pathology report pertains to a right orchidectomy case that was carried out on a patient. The specimen examined had a diameter of 9.0 cm and was found to have seminoma. There was no evidence of angio-invasion or invasion in rete-testis. Additionally, there was no invasion of the tunica albuginea as per the pathologist report.

The pathology report describes the findings of a left lower lobe lung biopsy and a lymph node biopsy. The lung biopsy shows a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma located beneath the pleural puckering area, measuring 27mm. Pleural invasion is present, but there is no evidence of lymphatic, blood vessel, or perineural invasion. The bronchial margin is clear. Metastatic carcinoma is found in all the identified hilar lymph nodes. The adjacent lung shows evidence of emphysema, fibrosis with UIP-like pattern, and honeycomb changes. The lymph node biopsy does not show evidence of metastases but contains carbon pigment consistent with silica. The diagnosis is T2a N1 [AJCC 7th ed].

The pathology report describes a case of adenocarcinoma in the prostate gland with small foci of mucinous differentiation and a histologic grade of 4+4, resulting in a Gleason score of 8. Tertiary pattern 3 is also present in 5% of the sample. The tumor is located in the anterior, right and left lateral, and posterior areas of the prostate, with extra-prostatic extension and seminal vesical invasion. Surgical margins are involved by invasive carcinoma, multifocal, and of indeterminate nature, without reporting the extent or Gleason grade of carcinoma present at these margins. Lymphovascular and perineural invasion are both present, with a tumor volume of 30-40% of the prostate gland. The patient has been diagnosed with pT3b and pN1, with metastasis present in 1 of 4 left obturator lymph nodes. High-grade prostatic intra-epithelial neoplasia and basal cell hyperplasia are additional pathological findings.

The pathology report describes a radical prostatectomy specimen and pelvic lymph nodes exam in male patient Jex, MRN #, with a preoperative diagnosis of prostate cancer. The prostate size is 36 grams, measuring 5.7 x 2.9 x 2.9 cm, with 1-3% volume occupied by prostatic adenocarcinoma, graded as Gleason score 7/10 (3+4). No extraprostatic extension, seminal vesicle involvement, or lymphovascular space invasion is identified, but perineural invasion is present. Surgical margins, including apex, base, and inked prostatic margin, are negative for tumor. Among ten lymph nodes examined, no metastatic carcinoma is identified. The pTNM stage is pT2aNO. The report also includes specimen data and gross description with numerous labeled representative sections submitted for genomic research study.

The pathology report describes a case of invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast, which was treated with left segmental mastectomy and sentinel lymph node biopsy. The tumor measured 1.5 cm in largest dimension and was classified as Nottingham grade 2. No lymphovascular invasion was identified, and the tumor was positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors. HER2/neu immunostaining revealed equivocal results, and HER2/neu FISH analysis showed no amplification of the gene. The report also mentions the presence of atypical ductal hyperplasia and non-neoplastic breast tissue changes, as well as the identification of metastatic carcinoma in one of two axillary sentinel lymph nodes examined. The report concludes with a detailed breakdown of the tumor characteristics and diagnosis, including the presence of ductal carcinoma in situ and benign breast fibroadipose tissue.

The pathology report describes a heterogenous lower pole mass in the right kidney, which was diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, nuclear grade II/IV, with an acinar pattern of growth and a greatest diameter of 7.5 cm. The tumor extends through the renal capsule but is confined within Gerota's fascia and invaded the renal vein. All surgical margins are free of tumor. The non-neoplastic kidney shows patchy chronic inflammation. A possible lymph node measuring 4.0 cm in greatest dimension was identified within the adipose tissue of the right para-caval lymph nodes and was found to be benign upon biopsy. Various sections of the kidney and lymph node were taken for analysis.

The pathology report describes the findings from a Whipple resection surgery performed on a patient with poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the head of the pancreas. The tumor extends beyond the pancreas and involves peripancreatic soft tissue, and perineural invasion is identified. Angiolymphatic invasion is not identified, and multiple lymph nodes are negative for tumor. The report includes negative biopsy results for lymph nodes, soft tissue margins, common hepatic duct margin, and lymph node around the common hepatic artery. The gross description includes the size, shape, and labeling of various tissue specimens, including 29 cm of duodenum, 6 x 4.5 x 4.3 cm portion of the pancreas, and 10.5 x 4.0 x 1.5 cm of the gallbladder. Representative sections of peripancreatic and periduodenal lymph nodes are submitted for analysis, along with other tissue margins. The report does not include any reference to patient-specific information or treatment plans.

The pathology report describes a specimen type of lobectomy from the upper right lung, measuring 3 X 2.5 X 2 cm. The histologic type is squamous cell carcinoma and the histologic grade is well differentiated. No information is provided on the tumor extent, other tumor nodules, lymph nodes, lymphatic invasion, venous invasion, margins, or evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment. No additional pathologic findings or comments are reported.

Preoperative diagnosis: Hepatoma right lobe of liver. Specimen received: A) Gallbladder, benign gallbladder wall with mild focal chronic inflammation, no evidence of malignancy. B) Diaphragmatic nodule, benign, consistent with fat necrosis and dystrophic calcification, no evidence of malignancy. C) Liver segment 5 and 6, resection: well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma, clear-cell pattern, tumor size 6.5 x 5 x 4.2 cm, histological grade I, free of carcinogenesis in inked parenchymal resection margin, presence of portal chronic inflammatory infiltrate. No evidence of cirrhosis. Intraoperative diagnosis: A) Gallbladder tumor grossly 1.2 cm away from margin, 6.5 cm in size. B) Diaphragmatic nodule - benign, consistent with fat necrosis. Gross description: A) Gallbladder - specimen consisting of 3 segments, green color, no presence of gallstones, fine velvety texture. B) Diaphragmatic nodule - fragment of white to tan-yellow tissue measuring 5 x 0.5 x 0.2 cm. C) Liver segment 5 and 6 - 279.2 g, 15 x 12.5 x 6 cm firm, dark, red-brown segment with partially hemorrhagic nodule, irregular tan-white to tan-yellow, located 1.2 cm from margin, free of carcinogenesis in inked margin. Overall, the report describes the benign gallbladder wall with mild inflammation, benign diaphragmatic nodule, and a well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma with clear-cell pattern present in liver segment 5 and 6, with no evidence of carcinogenesis in the inked resection margin and no presence of cirrhosis.

DIAGNOSIS: Adrenal gland, right (adrenalectomy): - Pheochromocytoma, 5.5 cm. The tumor cells are arranged in well-defined nests with finely granular purplish to amphophilic cytoplasm and conspicuous nucleoli. Immunohistochemical analysis reveals positive staining for synaptophysin in the lesional cells and S-100 in sustentacular cells. Attached to the pheochromocytoma is an unremarkable adrenal cortical tissue. The patient is a woman with a pheochromocytoma. The gross description of the adrenalectomy specimen is consistent with the above description. Approximately 5.0 CC of tumor and 1.0 CC of normal adrenal gland are procured for research.

Final Diagnosis:

- Papillary thyroid carcinoma: three foci in the right lobe and isthmus, with the largest focus exhibiting extensive extrathyroidal extension into skeletal muscle, as well as angiolymphatic and perineural invasion present.
- Chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis.
- Pathologic stage: pT3 N1b.
- Metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in 5 of 9 lymph nodes in the central compartment, and in 1 of 32 lymph nodes in the right lateral neck.
- No extranodal extension detected.
- Total thyroidectomy and selective neck dissection performed.
- Additional findings: normocellular parathyroid tissue and scant fragment of thymic tissue.

Patient History:

- Chief complaint/pre-op/post-op diagnosis: thyroid cancer.
- Procedure: total thyroidectomy/neck dissection.
- Specific clinical question and outside tissue diagnosis not answered.

Diagnosis: Adenocarcinoma of endometrium (endometrioid type) with focal clear cell features, histologic FIGO grade 2 and nuclear grade 2. The tumor invades less than half of the myometrium with a maximal thickness of 5 mm. Small focus suspicious for angiolymphatic invasion is identified. Leiomyoma, calcified and focal adenomyosis are present in the myometrium. Appendectomy shows a benign appendix with fibrous luminal obliteration. Lymph nodes are negative for metastatic carcinoma. Benign lobulated adipose omental tissue is seen in omentum. Whole slide image shows leiomyomas and three lymph nodes with yellow-brown irregular moderately firm fragments of tissue.

Pathology report for a patient with a pelvic mass and ovarian cancer. Omentum: Metastatic mullerian-derived carcinoma. Fallopian tubes and ovaries: Primary ovarian adenocarcinoma, mixed epithelial types, grade III; involvement of mucosa in both fallopian tubes suggests possibility of synchronous primary tubal neoplasms. Rectosigmoid: Metastatic mullerian-derived carcinoma. Uterus: Metastatic mullerian-derived carcinoma involving external aspect of endocervix, outer muscular wall of endocervix, anterior peritoneal soft tissue reflection, external aspect/serosal surface of anterior and posterior lower uterine segments, outer aspect of muscular wall of anterior lower uterine segment, serosa and subserosa of anterior uterine corpus. Lymphovascular invasion by carcinoma is present. Other sites: Metastatic mullerian-derived carcinoma present in peri-intestinal fibroadipose tissue, mesentery of sigmoid colon, soft tissue of right pelvis, cul de sac peritoneum, soft tissue of right diaphragm, liver surface, soft tissue of right sidewall, and soft tissue of left peritoneum. The carcinoma consists of multiple components and tumor-associated necrosis is present in multiple sites. No evidence of metastatic carcinoma found in left pelvic lymph nodes but one of two right obturator lymph nodes is positive for metastatic carcinoma. Acute and chronic inflammation is present in several sites.

Filtered Summary: The pathology report indicates that the patient has a 4 x 3 x 1.2 cm invasive squamous cell carcinoma, with poorly differentiated histologic grade, infiltrating the outer half muscle propria of the cervix. Lymphatic invasion is present, and two out of three bilateral pelvic lymph nodes are positive for metastasis. There is infiltration of lymphocytes in the stroma, and the tumor tissue arranges in the form of group or broad sheets or trabecular of tumor cells. The malignant cells have moderately, light eosinophilic cytoplasm, and nuclei are enlarged, with variability in size and shape, containing coarse clumped chromatin with prominent nucleoli. The report does not specify any margins or evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment.

The pathology report describes the examination of a gastrohepatic lymph node and a left lateral segment of the liver, collected from a patient diagnosed with liver cancer. A biopsy of the lymph nodes showed no malignancy, but lipogranulomatous inflammation was present. The left lateral segment of the liver had a solitary, well-defined and moderately-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma tumor measuring 4.2 cm, without lymphovascular space invasion. Margins of resection were negative for the tumor. The background hepatic parenchyma revealed mild chronic inflammation with no significant fibrosis. No other abnormalities were identified upon microscopic examination.

De-Identified Specimen Code: M. SPECIMEN SUBMITTED: Part A: 4R. Part B: #7. Part C: RIGHT LOWER LOBE WEDGE OF SUPERIOR SEGMENT. Part D: PLEURA ADJACENT TO RIGHT LOWER LOBE. Part E: LEVEL 11. Part F: #7. Part G: R9. Part H: R8. Part I: 11R. Part J: #7. Part K: #7. Part L: #12. Final Diagnosis: 1. Lymph nodes, 4R, #7, level 11, #7, R9, R8, 11R, #7, #7, #12, excision (A-B, E-N) - Lymph nodes, negative for neoplasm. 2. Right lung, lower lobe, superior segment, segmentectomy (C) - Mucinous adenocarcinoma, acinar-predominant (see comment). - Centrilobular emphysema with fibroelastosis. Extensive chronic bronchiolitis with rare ill-formed non-necrotizing granulomas. - Organizing acute fibrinous pleuritis. - Peribronchial lymph nodes, negative for neoplasm. 3. Pleural adjacent to right lower lobe, excision (D) - Organizing acute fibrinous pleuritis. Diagnosis Comment: Tumor Location: Right lower lobe, superior segment. Tumor Size: 7.5 x 6.4 x 4.7cm. Vascular Invasion: Negative. Lymphatic Invasion: Present. Bronchial Margin: Negative. Vascular Margin: Negative. Parenchymal Margins: Negative. Pleura/Soft Tissue Margin: The tumor invades into the visceral pleura but is not present at the pleural surface. Pathologic Stage (AJCC): p Stage IIIA (T3 NO MX). Intraoperative Diagnosis: A. Lymph node, negative for malignancy. B. Lymph node, negative for malignancy. C. Negative for malignancy. Clinical Diagnosis: LUNG CA. Gross Description: A. Received fresh for frozen section labeled "4R" are multiple fragments of brown-black soft tissue, aggregating to 1.7 x 1.4 x 0.2 cm. Totally submitted in cassette A1 for frozen section. B. Received fresh frozen section labeled "#7" are multiple fragments of red soft tissue measuring 1.3 x 0.3 x 0.3 cm in aggregate. Totally submitted in cassette B1 for frozen section. C. Received in formalin labeled "right lower lobe wedge of superior segment" is a specimen consisting of a large pulmonary wedge weighing 223 grams, and measuring 13 x 11 x 4.5 cm. A bronchial remnant measures 1.2 cm in diameter and 0.3 cm in length. The pleural surface shows adhesions and an area of puckering with underlying firm mass. Three stapled margins are present measuring 3, 4 and 6.5 cm in length and are inked orange. The pleural surface overlying the mass is inked blue. On sectioning, a fleshy tan lobulated mass measuring 7.5 x 6.4 x 4.7 cm is present abutting the pleura with pleural puckering and thickened. The mass is located 0.6 cm from the closest resection margin and 0.5 cm from the bronchial margin. The remainder of the uninvolved parenchyma is pink-red. Sections are submitted as follows: C1 bronchial margin for frozen evaluation, C2 vascular margin, C3-C6 tumor with overlying pleura, C7 tumor in relation to bronchus, C8-C9 tumor with closest resection margin (orange), C10 tumor, C11 uninvolved lung parenchyma, C12-C13 bronchial lymph nodes. D. Received in formalin labeled "pleura adjacent to right lower lobe" is an irregular segment of pleura with adhered soft tissue measuring 12 x 6 x 0.5 cm. Cross sections reveal an unremarkable cut surface. Representative sections are submitted in formalin in cassettes D1 and D2. E. Received fresh on Telfa gauze labeled "Level 11" is a tan anthracotic nodule measuring 0.4 x 0.3 x 0.2 cm. The specimen is totally submitted in cassette E1. F. Received fresh on Telfa gauze labeled "#7" are multiple irregular anthracotic nodules aggregating to 2 x 2 x 0.5 cm. The specimen is totally submitted in formalin in cassette F1. G. Received fresh on Telfa gauze labeled "R9" is a solitary irregular anthracotic nodule measuring 0.7 x 0.5 x 0.5 cm. The specimen is totally submitted in cassette G1. H. Received fresh on Telfa gauze labeled "R8" is an anthracotic nodule envelope and soft yellow adipose tissue measuring 1.5 x 1 x 0.5 cm. The specimen is totally submitted in cassette H1. I. Received fresh on Telfa gauze labeled "11R" is a solitary anthracotic nodule measuring 1 x 0.7 x 0.5 cm. The nodule is totally submitted in formalin in cassette 11. J. Received fresh on Telfa gauze labeled "#7" are multiple irregular anthracotic nodules aggregating to 2 x 0.5 x 0.4 cm. The nodules are totally submitted in formalin in cassette J1. K. Received fresh on Telfa gauze labeled "#7" is a gray soft nodule measuring 0.8 x 0.5 x 0.4 cm. The nodules are totally submitted in formalin in cassette K1. L. Received fresh on Telfa gauze labeled "#12" are multiple irregular anthracotic nodules aggregating to 1.5 x 1 x 0.6 cm. The nodules are totally submitted in formalin in cassette L1. Microscopic: {Not Entered}.

The pathology report describes a section of the distal esophagus and proximal stomach, including a tumor mass located 40mm from the proximal resection margin at the gastro-oesophageal junction. The tumor measures 20x20mm, appears ulcerated and fungating, and extends through the wall of the esophagus into surrounding fat. The remaining stomach and esophageal mucosa appear normal. Metastatic tumor is identified in three of six lymph nodes, with extra nodal spread in two nodes. The diagnosis is poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of diffuse type, arising in gastric cardia type mucosa at the gastro-oesophageal junction, extending through muscularis propria to the posterior serosal surface, with clear resection margins. Two paraoesophageal lymph nodes show metastatic tumor infiltration.

The pathology report describes a subcutaneous mastectomy of the right breast and an axillary lymph node dissection. Multicentric intralobular and infiltrating lobular carcinoma of the pleomorphic type is identified in the right breast, with multiple foci of invasion ranging from 1mm to 3.5cm in greatest dimension. Metastatic breast carcinoma is identified in one of sixteen lymph nodes examined in the right axilla. There is no evidence of extranodal extension by tumor. The margins of resection are free of tumor, and there is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion. The biopsy sites are present.

Soft tissue resection of the right calf revealed an undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma, measuring 18.8 cm, with deep soft tissue tumor and histologic grade III. Ancillary studies were negative, lymphovascular invasion was not present, and margins were negative. The right tibial nerve nodule excision showed pleomorphic sarcoma involving a segment of the peripheral nerve. Although most of the tumor is undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma, other portions resemble low-grade myxofibrosarcoma and pleomorphic liposarcoma with multivacuolated giant cells, and S100 immunostains were negative. No lymph nodes were dissected, and AJCC stage was determined to be Stage III (assuming "cM0" status). The report also provides a gross description of the submitted specimens.

Bladder tumour specimen received for histopathology is diagnosed with transitional cell carcinoma G3pT2. Microscopy reveals a poorly differentiated grade 3 tumour with a mixed papillary and solid growth pattern. Muscularis propria is present and invaded, but no vascular channel invasion is observed. Flat urothelium is absent.

A brain neoplasm frontal is seen on MRI. Gross examination shows brain tissue infiltrated by an anaplastic oligodendroglioma (WHO Grade III), characterized by hypercellularity, mitotic figures, and necrosis. FISH interpretation summary shows the tumor may not respond therapeutically like that typically associated with the oligodendroglioma with a loss of 1p and 19q. Leukocyte common antigen (LCA) test is positive in 15% of cells, and proliferation index is high with 15% of tumor cells exhibiting staining. MGMT is negative in 5% of tumor cells, while EGFR is positive in 80%. PTEN is lost in 2% of tumor cells. S6 is positive in 30% while AKT is negative in 20% of tumor cells. MAPK is positive in 40%.

The pathology report describes a biopsy and removal of an intra-axial lesion found in the left frontal lobe of the brain. The diagnosis identifies the lesion as a glioblastoma multiforme, with a majority of the tumor demonstrating small cell variant morphologic features. The report notes an intraoperative consultation diagnosis of a high grade glioma and provides information about the specimens submitted for analysis.

The pathology report pertains to a case of lung cancer and includes information on three specimens received: level 11 lymph node, right lower lobe, and level 7 lymph node. The report states that fragments of lymphoid tissue from levels 11 and 7 lymph nodes were negative for malignancy. The right lower lobe specimen had a moderately-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, grade 2, with associated necrosis, measuring 4.5 cm in greatest dimensions. The tumor had not metastasized to five peri-bronchial lymph nodes, and the bronchial, vascular, and visceral pleural margins were free of malignancy. Remaining lung showed no significant pathological changes. The specimen was labeled as pT2bNO(PLO) based on TMN staging. The report also includes gross descriptions of each specimen and lists the lab and collection procedures.

Diagnosis: Left superior neck lesion - Seborrheic keratosis, excised. Right lobe thyroid - Papillary thyroid carcinoma, follicular variant, encapsulated, 2.9 cm in size, unifocal, no capsular or vascular invasion noted. Surgical margins not involved (<1 mm). No lymph nodes sampled. Parathyroid normocellular. AJCC PATHOLOGIC TNM STAGE: pT2 pNx pMx. Nodule confined to gland, no additional lesions noted.

The report describes the diagnosis of a renal cell carcinoma, conventional (clear cell) type, with a grade IVAV Fuhrman nuclear grade. The tumor measures 4.3 cm in diameter and did not invade the renal vein nor the local area. The surgical margins were free of tumor, and non-neoplastic kidney, adrenal gland, and lymph nodes were not identified. The staging indicates that the tumor is limited to the kidney with a size <= 7.0 cm. The specimen, labeled "right renal tumor," is a wedge-shaped portion of the kidney that contains a well-circumscribed yellow lesion measuring 4.3 x 4.1 x 2.1 cm. The report also describes the gross description and the summary of sections. Additionally, an intraoperative frozen section consultation was performed, confirming the diagnosis of "right renal tumor" with a close margin of about 0.1 cm.

Specimen 1 is a left kidney with a portion of the adrenal gland showing two separate foci: a 5.0 cm and 0.8 cm in size, respectively. The histology confirms renal cell carcinoma, conventional type, nuclear grade III/IV. The tumor is confined within Gerota's fascia and has no invasion of large renal vein. All surgical margins are free of tumor. The non-neoplastic kidney shows focal benign simple cortical cysts. Specimen 2 is a histologically benign adrenal gland tissue, while specimen 3 shows ten benign lymph nodes. Intraoperative consultation confirms the frozen section diagnoses of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type.

Summary: The pathology report identified invasive lobular carcinoma, classic and solid types, measuring 3.0 cm in greatest dimension, in the upper/inner quadrant of the left breast. The lymph nodes (sentinel #1, #2, #3, and #4) did not show any evidence of tumor presence. The report noted no lymphovascular invasion and widely free margins. The report recommended no further treatment plans.

Summary: Invasive poorly differentiated colon carcinoma (sigmoid colon carcinoma) with penetration of all parietal layers and vascular infiltration. Free resection margins in the mucosa region and deep circumferential resection margin. Tumor classification: ICDO-DA M8140/3, G3, pT3 L1, V1, pN1 (2 of 13 + 1), locally R0.

The pathology report describes the results of biopsies taken from multiple lymph node stations, all of which are negative for tumor. The report also indicates the presence of invasive grade 3 adenocarcinoma in the left lower lobe lung, forming a 6.6 x 6.2 x 5.8 cm mass, with visceral pleural invasion but no angiolymphatic invasion. Frozen section histologic interpretation was performed on several lymph node stations. The report includes a gross description of the submitted tissue samples and a block summary of each station biopsied. An addendum notes that k-ras mutation analysis will be performed on paraffin-embedded lung tissue. An amended report corrects a typographical error in the previous diagnosis.

The pathology report describes the results of an excision of a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, which was completely removed. No metastatic carcinoma was found in the examined lymph nodes. The report includes a gross description of the six specimens submitted for analysis and a synoptic worksheet detailing the tumor size and characteristics. The report also mentions an intraoperative consultation and a microscopic examination confirming that the visceral pleura was not involved in the carcinoma.

Diagnosis: Invasive moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the distal esophageal tumor biopsy. Clinical history: Esophageal CA. The tumor cells are immunonegative for Her-2/neu (score 0 of 3).

Final diagnosis: Metaplastic carcinoma, matrix-producing type, Nottingham grade III, identified in the right breast with axillary sentinel lymph nodes. Ductal carcinoma in situ and fibrocystic changes are also present. All surgical resection margins are negative for tumor. Left breast and lymph nodes are negative for metastatic carcinoma. Multiple excisions of breast skin and parenchyma are without diagnostic abnormality.

Specimen A is a right lower lung wedge resection, which revealed a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with a primary tumor measuring 2.5 cm in greatest dimension. Surgical margins were uninvolved. Specimen B is a right lower lobe lobectomy that did not reveal any carcinoma, but two lymph nodes with no evidence of metastatic disease were identified. Specimen C revealed no evidence of metastasis on four level 12 lymph nodes examined. Specimen D showed no evidence of metastasis on seven level 7 lymph nodes examined. Specimen E had no nodes identified, but demonstrated fibrovascular tissue in the level 9 lymph nodes. Specimen F demonstrated no evidence of metastasis on three level 11 lymph nodes examined.

Diagnosis: Poorly differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma located in the cecum/ascending colon with penetration of the serosa. Tumor-free regional lymph nodes, small and large intestinal resection margins, mesenteric resection margin and omental fat tissue. Tumor stage: pT4 pNO (0/20) pMX; G3; L1, V0, locally R0. Final tumor stage: pT4 pN0 (0/21) pMX; G3; L1, V0, locally R0. No indication of metastasis from the carcinoma found.

The pathology report describes a liver specimen from a patient diagnosed with HCC who underwent a right posterior sectionectomy. The liver weighed 780.0 gm and had a 7.5 cm heaptic mass confined to the capsule. The tumor was  cord-like and nesting with a fibrous capsule formation. The major differentiation was III and the worst differentiation was IV. The report does not indicate any invasion of the surgical resection margin, serosal invasion, portal vein invasion, or bile duct invasion. The remaining liver parenchyme showed chronic hepatitis, HBV associated. No tumor was present in the adrenal gland. The gallbladder showed autolysis. Representative sections were submitted for review.

A biopsy of the cervix at 1 o'clock position revealed a large cell keratinizing type invasive squamous cell carcinoma that is moderate to poorly differentiated. The biopsy specimen is irregular and is trisected with a size of 1.3 x 1 x 0.3 cm. The entire specimen is submitted in one cassette for examination. CPT codes for the procedure are cervical biopsy/88305 and ICD9 code is 180.9.

Summary:
Lung, right, lower lobe shows a tumor (3.5 x 2.0 x 2.2 cm) diagnosed as Squamous Cell Carcinoma, basaloid with a pT2a, pNO (0/38), pMx, G3 grading.

Summary: 

Male patient with anaplastic squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus. Grossly, an esophageal fragment with a gastric appearance and a gray tumor mass measuring 1 cm in thickness are observed with a metastatic paraesophageal lymphatic node. Microscopically, the tumor appears ulcerative and heavily infiltrated with lymphocytes and the surgical borders are clear. Paraesophageal lymphatic node presents metastatic cells, but there is no sign of metastasis in paragastric lymphatic nodes and greater omentum. Final diagnosis is anaplastic squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus.

The report describes a lingulectomy specimen received, consisting of a wedge resection of lung with a pleural-based peripheral tumor measuring approximately 35 x 31 x 19mm. The tumor appears to directly involve disrupted pleural surfaces and is moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma with confirmed invasion of the visceral pleura. The stapled surgical resection margin is well clear of malignancy and no lymphatic or perineural invasion is identified. The surrounding lung has obstructive pneumonitis, foci of bronchiectasis, organizing pneumonia, and subpleural honeycomb changes with interstitial fibrosis in these areas. Vascular invasion is present with no evidence of lymph node involvement. Pathological stage T2a Nx is confirmed.

A moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 70mm is identified in the left lower lobe of the lung. No invasion to the pleura is identified, but many enlarged hilar lymph nodes and intraparenchymal lymph nodes are identified with metastatic carcinoma in intraparenchymal and hilar lymph nodes. No evidence of vascular or perineural infiltration is seen. The pathological stage is T2 N1. Reactive lymph nodes with anthracosis and occasional silicotic nodules are also found.

Left orchiectomy was performed to remove a tumor in the left testis, which was later diagnosed as seminoma. The tumor has invaded the tunica albuginea and epididymis, and vascular invasion is present. However, the resection margin and scrotum are free of tumor. The left testis received for analysis was 14.0 x 10.0 x 8.0 cm in dimensions, with a portion of the spermatic cord and a part of the scrotum en bloc. The testis is fully replaced by the lobulated whitish-gray tumor measuring 13.0 x 8.0 x 8.0 cm.

This report describes a case of a patient with a right temporal tumor, resected during surgery. Pathological diagnoses reveal the presence of glioblastoma with leptomeningeal invasion and a high proliferation index. The report also includes information on the absence of MGMT promoter methylation, allelic loss assessment, and EGFRVIII mutation. The tissue sections show that the neoplastic cells overexpress the p53 protein and depict focal microvascular proliferation. The report does not include any irrelevant information.

The patient underwent a laparoscopic retroperitoneal adrenalectomy to remove a 14.465g right adrenal gland consisting of a 3.0 x 2.6 x 1.2 cm single mass with attached adipose tissue and possible normal adrenal gland. The mass appeared encapsulated and was surrounded by a 0.1 cm rim of orange tissue similar in appearance to unremarkable adrenal gland. Cross sections of the mass showed a mottled white-pink appearance with foci of hemorrhage and a fish flesh appearance. Serial sections of atrophic adrenal tissue were also present. Additional tissue from the right adrenal gland consisted of two ragged portions of cauterized, pink-tan fibroadipose tissue. Pathology confirmed a 3.0 cm pheochromocytoma in the right adrenal gland with a possible positive margin although the normal adrenal gland in the additional tissue sample may invalidate this finding.

The pathology report describes the examination of various lymph nodes and lung tissue samples. The report confirms the absence of metastatic carcinoma in most of the lymph nodes. However, one lymph node is found to have a focus of metastatic carcinoma. The lung tissue sample shows infiltrating mucinous carcinoma with small vessel invasion but no penetration through the visceral pleura. The bronchial and vascular resection margins are negative for tumor. Immunostains confirm the primary lung carcinoma. The final diagnosis indicates the presence of regional lymph node metastatic carcinoma in one out of three hilar lymph nodes with no distant metastasis. The tumor measures 8.5 cm in maximal dimension and has small vessel invasion. Additionally, multifocal nodular areas of bronchiolar pneumonitis are observed.

Pathology review of a mediastinal paraganglioma revealed a reddish to light-colored tumor measuring 5x4x3 cm with a weight of 42 g. The tumor is partly rose and composed of zellballen with medium-sized cells containing enlarged nuclei with chromatin and distinguishable nucleoli. Pleomorph nuclei and focal sclerosis with necrosis are also present, but no extensive necrosis or increased mitosis count. No vessel invasion was observed. The final diagnosis is an extra-adrenal paraganglioma.

Report Summary:

Specimen: Left colon
Pre-Op Diagnosis: Sigmoid colon Adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated
Gross Description: 22cm long portion of colon; intact with lobular fat; 3.7 x 2.5 x 0. cm exophytic lesion with invasion through muscularis propria and continuity with serosal puckering; invasion into fat within 1cm of radial margin
Microscopic Description: pT3 Adenocarcinoma invading through muscularis propria, metastatic carcinoma in three of 27 lymph nodes, pericolonic tumor deposits within serosal fat
Diagnosis: Adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated, invading through muscularis propria, metastatic carcinoma in three of 27 lymph nodes, pericolonic tumor deposits present within serosal fat.

Summary: The pathology report describes a glial neoplasm in the right frontal brain that infiltrates white and gray matter. The tumor cells are diffusely immunoreactive for p53, consistent with astocytic origin. Scattered MIB-1 reactive cells are present with a labeling index of 2.8%, indicating low-grade histologic features. The diagnosis is a well-differentiated astrocytoma (WHO grade II) with a minor area showing classic oligodendroglioma. No mitotic figures, microvascular proliferation or necrosis are identified. Secondary structures including subpial condensation, perineuronal satellitosis, and perivascular accumulation are seen.

The pathology report describes a case of muscular invasion transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) of the bladder. The frozen sections for the right and left distal ureter and urethral margin showed no carcinoma in situ, while chronic inflammation with granulomas consistent with BCG therapy was observed in the urethral margin. The prostate showed bilateral prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 6 (3+3), which foci invaded the capsule. However, surgical margins, lymphovascular space invasion, and seminal vesicles and vas deferentia were free of tumor. The para-aortic, paracaval, common iliac, external iliac, lymph node of Cloquet, hypogastric/obturator, and presacral lymph nodes, left and right proximal ureters were all free of metastatic carcinoma, except for the left hyperplastic prostatitis consistent with BCG treatment.

The pathology report describes the diagnosis of breast cancer in the patient's left breast. The report states that the left axilla's sentinel node was excised, and no tumors were found. However, upon examining the left breast, the report identified two separate invasive ductal carcinomas, with the larger being 2.2 cm in size and the smaller being 1.3 cm in size. Moreover, the smaller tumor is present 0.3 cm from the closest posterior margin, while the larger tumor is located in the lower outer quadrant of the breast at the 4:00 o'clock position. The report also mentions ductal carcinoma in situ, solid type, and atypical ductal epithelial hyperplasia. There was no angiolymphatic invasion. There was perineural involvement, but the mammillary skin and nipple were free of tumor. No lymph nodes were positive for metastasis, and all margins were free of tumor. The estrogen and progesterone receptors were positive, while the HER2/NEU was positive at a low level.

The pathology report describes the diagnosis of endometrioid adenocarcinoma, FIGO II (of III), in the upper endometrial cavity of a patient who underwent total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. The tumor invaded into the myometrium to a maximum depth of 1.3 cm. No lymphatic vascular invasion was observed. The cervix shows acute and chronic cervicitis with erosion. The bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes were normal. Multiple lymph nodes, including left and right pelvic and para-aortic lymph nodes, were negative for tumor. Left and right gonadal vessels were also negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive cervical cancer, with metastasis to two of twenty-seven (2/27) left pelvic lymph nodes and two of twenty-six (2/26) right pelvic lymph nodes. The left common lymph nodes are negative for metastasis. The tumor is a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma located in the anterior and posterior cervix, with a size of 7.5 cm, and a depth of invasion of 1.5 cm completely through the cervical wall. Pelvic wall extension and rectal mucosal extension are absent, but there is extensive lymphovascular invasion. Parametrial invasion is present, and cervical ressection margins are clear by less than 0.1 cm. The tumor extends from the cervix to the body anterior and posterior uterine body. The report also includes gross and microscopic descriptions of the specimen. The staging information is T2b, N1 (Stage IIIB). Pending special studies are noted in the report.

The pathology report describes the specimens received from a patient diagnosed with right lung cancer. The report includes twelve different sources of tissue, which include cytology specimens, lymph nodes, lung lobes, and a portion of the 6th rib. The frozen section diagnosis reveals negative margins. The right middle and lower lobe of the lung shows adenocarcinoma with WHO mixed subtype, with lymphovascular invasion identified. The surgical resection margins are free of carcinoma. Metastatic carcinoma is present in some of the lymph nodes, indicating a pTNM stage of T2 N2 M1. The report provides specific information on the size and description of each specimen, but no information on patient identification, doctor or hospital names, treatment plans, or reference.

Diagnosis: Left breast invasive lobular carcinoma with a tumor size of 2.1 cm and a nuclear score of 3/3, grade 2. No lymphovascular space invasion or skin involvement. One lymph node out of ten examined had metastatic carcinoma with extra-capsular extension. Other findings include fibrosis and hemorrhage compatible with prior biopsy site, mild fibrocystic change featuring apocrine metaplasia, and focal florid ductal hyperplasia. No definite tumor is identified in the axillary node specimen. pTNM: T2N1MX. Two specimens were received, the left breast and axillary contents and the left axillary node. The breast specimen had a circumscribed tan white fibrous appearing nodule with nine lymph nodes examined. The left axillary node had an isolated single cell micrometastasis identified through immunohistochemistry. No repeat of breast carcinoma prognostic indicator analysis was performed on the present specimen, and a repeat will not be performed unless requested by the primary clinician.

The pathology report describes a case of a high-grade spindle cell sarcoma compatible with dedifferentiated liposarcoma in the right retroperitoneum, right kidney, and right adrenal gland. The tumor measuring 18.2 cm in greatest dimension does not involve the kidney or adrenal gland but extends close to the resection margin. The report mentions a focal area showing spindle cells in a loose, partially myxoid background with scattered large atypical cells. Immunohistochemical stains show that the tumor cells are positive for CD34, CDK4, and MDM2 and negative for S100, SMA, Desmin, and CD117. A MIB 1 stains show a high proliferation rate of 15-20%. The report includes gross descriptions and sections of the submitted specimens. FISH studies are underway to confirm the diagnosis.

The pathology report is for a laparoscopically assisted vaginal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and staging lymph node dissection procedure on a patient diagnosed with grade I endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium. The tumor invades the myometrium to a depth of 2.5 mm, with no lymphovascular space involvement. The tumor size is 3 x 2 cm and located on the lateral aspect of anterior endometrium. No other sites of neoplastic involvement are found, but the specimen also contains adenomyosis, leiomyomata uteri, and an endometrial polyp. Margins and lymph nodes are negative for malignancy. TNM staging resulted in pT1a with less than one-half myometrium involvement, pNo, and pMX. Estrogen and progesterone receptor assays will be reported separately, and no malignancy is present in the pelvic washings.

Specimen: A. Whipple's specimen (as per clinical history: ampullary tumor?)
Diagnosis: Whipple's procedure revealing a moderately to poorly differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, 2.9 cm in greatest dimension, located in the head of the pancreas, invading the duodenal mucosa and common bile duct with positive lymph node involvement (3/8 nodes), vascular and perineural invasion identified. All resection margins negative for tumor involvement. Gross description shows the lesion is poorly circumscribed, and histopathology reports metastases in three of the eight lymph nodes detected.

The pathology report describes three specimens received during surgery: A sentinel lymph node, a left breast excision, and an additional medial, anterior-posterior margin. The intraoperative consultation diagnosis reveals that the sentinel lymph node is negative for tumor and that the left breast excision has a tumor measuring 1.6 cm and is invasive ductal carcinoma, SBR grade 3. The biopsy site changes with fibrosis. The report also mentions that the lymph nodes are negative for metastases, and there is no tumor in the additional medial, anterior-posterior margin. The synoptic report provides details about the tumor size, site, margins, and pathological staging, which is pT1c N0. The ER/PR/HER2 results show ER and PR are positive, and HER2 is negative by IHC. No dcis present.

Diagnosis: Squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe of lung with poor differentiation (G3/4) and a size of 3.1cm. The tumor is unifocal without invasion of visceral pleura or adjacent structures, and there is no tumor-associated atelectasis/obstructive pneumonitis. Elastic stain supports lack of visceral pleural invasion. All margins are negative for carcinoma with the nearest margin being 3cm from the tumor. All sampled lymph nodes are benign. Staging (AJCC): Primary Tumor pT2a, Lymph Nodes pN0. Frozen section diagnosis revealed non-small cell lung carcinoma with negative bronchial margin. No additional findings were recorded.

Clinical diagnosis: Cancer of the hepatic flexure. Macroscopic description: A lesion sized 4 X 3 cm in the mucosa of the colon and caecum was observed. The lesion covers 100% of the intestine circumference and infiltrates the periintestinal tissue. Microscopic description: Adenocarcinoma tubulare (G2) with infiltratio carcinomatosa telae adiposae pericolicae. Histopathological diagnosis: Adenocarcinoma tubulare coli, Tubular adenocarcinoma of the colon (G2; Dukes B; Astler-Coller B2; pT3; pNO).

The pathology report describes a specimen labeled "bladder and prostate" received for analysis. The bladder tumor is a high-grade urothelial carcinoma with unifocal focal lesion and lymphatic invasion present. The tumor has invaded through muscularis propria into perivesical fat, without involving the ureters. However, uretero-vesicular junctions are involved bilaterally. The urethra shows prostatic adenocarcinoma but not urothelial carcinoma. The prostate cancer is a Gleason score 3+3 adenocarcinoma with a unilateral right lesion with less than 50% involvement and no evidence of extracapsular extension or vascular invasion. Bilateral pelvic lymph nodes were dissected, with metastatic urothelial carcinoma identified in 7/10 nodes on the right side and 1/3 nodes on the left side without extracapsular extension or evidence of metastatic prostatic adenocarcinoma. The AJCC stage for bladder cancer is pT3a pN2 pMx, and for prostate cancer is pT2b pNO pMx.  A 2.5 x 2.0 x 0.5 cm questionable prostate is observed without grossly identifying seminal vesicles or vasa differentia. Light microscopic examination confirms urothelial carcinoma extending into perivesicle fat and prostatic adenocarcinoma identified in the right lobe.

A moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma was identified in the sigmoid colon, with a tumor size of 2.8 cm length, 6.5 cm width, and maximal thickness of 0.7 cm. Tumor budding was focal and increased tumor infiltrating lymphocytes were absent. The deepest tumor invasion was in subserosal adipose tissue and/or mesenteric fat, with surgical margins free of tumor and no lymphovascular invasion. No tumor deposits were found in pericolorectal soft tissue. Lymph nodes were examined, with no metastasis identified among the 21 nodes examined. The colon in the proximal and distal rings contained colonic mucosa with hyperplastic features, and no tumor was detected. The tumor was classified as pT3, and there was no regional lymph node metastasis. Further sections, including lymph nodes, were examined.

The pathology report pertains to a case of gastric cancer in a male patient who underwent partial gastrectomy surgery. Microscopic examination of the resected stomach reveals a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 3 cm in greatest dimension, invading the muscularis propria layer, and located 6 cm from the proximal margin of the specimen. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and no lymph-vascular invasion or distant metastasis is identified. Three regional lymph nodes are examined, and all are negative for malignancy. Additionally, the report includes details of the gross specimen examination and intraoperative consultation findings. An area suspicious of metastatic tumor measuring 4 mm is identified, and four additional small lymph nodes are found, but they are negative for malignancy. Finally, the report documents the freezing and banking of representative portions of the tumor.

Diagnosis: Endometrioid adenocarcinoma in the lower uterine segment and cervical wall implant. FIGO grade 3, 4.4 x 3.8 x ?1.0 cm tumor size, no lymphatic/vascular invasion. Leiomyomata in remaining myometrium, fibromuscular tissue in right round ligament. No tumor found in ovaries, fallopian tubes or lymph nodes. Surgical procedure: hysterectomy, oophorectomy, and lymphadenectomy. Pathologic stage: pT2 pNO pMX.

Diagnosis: Carcinosarcoma (malignant mixed Mullerian tumor) in endometrial polyp with predominantly carcinomatous areas; uterine intraepithelial serous carcinoma, focal; cervix with patchy atrophy and chronic inflammation; bilateral ovaries with epithelial inclusion cysts; right hydrosalpinx; left fallopian tube with no histopathologic abnormality. Lymph node excisions showed no evidence of malignancy except for one lymph node which was positive for malignancy. Operative procedure: total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and staging. Gross examination revealed a uterus measuring 9 cm x 7 cm x 4 cm with a 3.0 x 1.0 cm polypoid mass that appears superficial but with no definitive invasion identified. The lower uterine segment, endocervix, and lymphvascular space are not involved by the tumor. The provisional pathologic stage assigned is T1aN0Mx. Preoperative imaging was not suggestive of any distant metastases.

The pathology report describes three specimens labeled "10th rib", "right kidney" and "regional lymph nodes". The bone marrow specimen showed normal hematopoiesis with no evidence of malignancy. The kidney specimen contained a 10 cm renal cell carcinoma, of chromophobe type with a Fuhrman nuclear grade III/IV and lymphovascular invasion identified near the renal vein. However, margins were free of tumor. The lymph nodes were negative for tumor. Immunohistochemistry supported the diagnosis of chromophobe type. The adrenal gland was not identified. The report also includes details about the specimens received for each label and their respective sizes.

The pathology report describes two specimens received in the laboratory for analysis. The first specimen is sentinel lymph nodes from the right axilla, and the second is right breast needle localization. One of the four lymph nodes shows isolated tumor cells. The breast needle localization specimen contains four masses diagnosed as invasive lobular carcinoma, SBR grade 2, with a tumor measuring at least 3.5 cm and present at the anterior margin. The synoptic report confirms the presence of invasive lobular carcinoma with a tumor size of 3.5 cm and negative lymph node status (0/5 isolated tumor cell clusters). The Oncotype DX breast cancer assay results show a recurrence score of 29, ER Score Positive, PR Score Positive, Her2 Score Negative, and an average rate of distant recurrence at 10 years of 19% for patients with a recurrence score of 29 in the clinical validation study.

Total thyroidectomy was performed on the patient, and the left lobe was found to have unifocal papillary carcinoma, with the greatest dimension of 5.3 cm. Two lymph nodes associated with the lobe were negative for tumor. The tumor had multiple foci of extrathyroidal extension, with a region of the left lobe margin being involved. Venous and lymphatic invasion was present. Nodular hyperplasia was also found. The doctor who reviewed this case concurs with the findings.

Diagnosis: The liver has moderately developed fatty infiltration of the parenchyma, along with von Meyenburg's complex in the subcapsular portion. A portion of the sigmoid colon was resected and found to have a mucosal adenoma, epithelial dysplasia, and transitions into a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colorectal type, extending fully circumferentially into the internal portions of the submucosa. Oral and aboral resection margins were tumor-free, and seventeen mesocolic lymph nodes were tumor-free with uncharacteristic reactive changes. Tumor stage was determined as pT1 pNO (0/17) L0 V0; G2 R0.

Examination type: Histopathological examination (cito). Material: Multiple organ resection - sigmoid colon. Clinical diagnosis: Cancer of the sigmoid colon. Macroscopic description: A 15.2 cm length of the large intestine with an ulcerous tumor sized 4.2 X 6.5 X 0.8 cm in the mucosa, which removed 7.2 cm from the incision line and 5.3 cm from the opposite one. Microscopic description: Adenocarcinoma tubulopapillare (G2) infiltrated deeply into the tunicae muscularis priopriae et telae adiposae mesenterii pericolicae, with metastases carcinomatosae in the lymph nodes (NO I/VIII), and carcinomatosa capsulae lymphonodi. Histopathological Diagnosis: Adenocarcinoma tubulopapillare coli with metastases carcinomatosae in lymphonodo. (G2, Dukes C, Astler-Coller, C2, pT3, pNI).

Summary: Papillary carcinoma tumor measuring 1x0.7x0.7 cm is present in the left thyroid lobe. The tumor has a fibrovascular stalk and colloid follicles covered by cuboidal epithelial cells, with invasion into the capsule but no extrathyroidal extension seen. Nuclei are regular with finely dispersed chromatin or intranuclear grooves. The tumor is fibrous.

Specimen type: Excision of tumor from the esophagus with the tumor measuring 3.5x3x1.5cm. Histologic examination revealed a moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma originating from adventitia. There was no evidence of lymphatic or venous invasion, but the margins were involved. Zero out of five regional lymph nodes tested positive for metastasis. There was no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment or any additional pathologic findings observed in the sample. No further comments were provided in the report.

The report is about a patient who had a radical prostatectomy due to prostate cancer. The examination of the lymph nodes showed evidence of neoplasia in one out of twenty nodes on the right pelvic side, while no evidence was found on the left. The examined prostate and bilateral seminal vesicles contained an invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+4=8. The carcinoma showed extracapsular extension and perineural invasion but was free of carcinoma in all examined surgical resection margins and in the bilateral seminal vesicles. High grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia and multifocal disease were present. Pathologic TNM stage was pT3a N1 Mx, and benign prostatic hypertrophy and chronic severely active prostatitis were noted.

The pathology report describes a case of papillary carcinoma in the thyroid gland, which appears to have metastasized to multiple lymph nodes, including those in the central and bilateral neck regions. The report notes that there is no pathological diagnosis for certain lymph nodes, but it confirms the presence of multiple tiny microcarcinomas. The histological analysis reveals the presence of both classical and follicular variants of papillary carcinoma with focal tall cell change. The report also notes the absence of lymph-vascular and perineural invasions and extrathyroidal extensions. The largest tumor has a predominant dimension of 1.9 cm and is partially encapsulated. Margins uninvolved by carcinoma are noted, with an invasive extent of 0.2 mm. The report details the dimensions of the thyroid gland, non-cancerous nodules, and lymph nodes and provides primary tumor and regional lymph node staging information based on AJCC/UICC TNM, 7th Edition. However, details such as patient identification, doctor identification, and treatment plan are excluded from the report.

The pathology report describes a case of a right upper lobe lung tumor in a male patient who underwent lobectomy. The tumor is predominantly squamous cell carcinoma with some focal glandular differentiation and is moderately to poorly differentiated in terms of histological grade. The tumor is unifocal and measures 4.2 x 4.0 x 2.3 cm with visceral pleural and lymphovascular space invasion. The tumor has not shown any treatment effect, and the lymph node analysis shows no metastatic carcinoma. The patient has a pTNM stage of pT2a NO. The report also mentions observations of emphysematous changes.

Diagnosis: Renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type. The tumor is multifocal with the largest nodule measuring 1.9 cm in diameter. There is no evidence of invasion into perirenal adipose tissue, Gerota's fascia, renal vein, ureter, or adjacent organs. The surgical margins for perirenal adipose tissue, renal vein, renal artery, and ureter are all negative. Chronic interstitial nephritis and arteriolonephrosclerosis are present. The kidney away from the tumor appears unremarkable with preserved cortical structure. AJCC Staging: pTla pNx pMx. The adrenal gland was not received and lymph nodes were not sampled. Tissue blocks were submitted for special investigations.

The pathology report describes specimens obtained from an esophagogastroduodenoscopy of a patient with esophageal cancer. The report includes the gross and microscopic characteristics of the specimens, margin assessments, frozen section diagnoses, and histological diagnoses. The report notes that the tumor is a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, measuring 2.2 cm in greatest dimension, which has invaded through the muscularis propria into the adventitia, with perineural invasion but no identified lymphovascular invasion. Thirteen examined lymph nodes were negative for tumor. The report documents the location and size of the tumor, as well as the margins, histologic type, and pathologic staging.
Cervix biopsy reveals invasive squamous cell carcinoma grade 3.

The pathology report describes a case of renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney along with an interstitial cell tumor. The tumor is of conventional type with mostly clear cells and eosinophilic cells. The tumor is invasive and involves the renal vein and sinus adipose tissue. There is also an IVC thrombus, but the margins of the resection are free of tumor. The adrenal gland shows no tumor. The report also includes a gross description of an 18.0 x 9.0 x 7.5 cm radical nephrectomy specimen with sections for tumor and normal tissue submitted to the tissue bank. The clinical history and SNOMED codes are also given.

The pathology report indicates that molecular anatomic pathology testing for mutations in various genes was not identified. The final diagnosis reveals that the patient had an encapsulated oncocytic follicular variant of papillary thyroid carcinoma, which was confined to the thyroid and did not invade any surrounding tissues. Eight lymph nodes in the central compartment were examined and no tumor was found. The patient also had chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis. The report does not provide any irrelevant information such as patient or hospital details, treatment plan, or sample size and weight.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of lymph nodes, level 11 and level 7, excisions - negative for tumor. Regarding the lung, a poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinoma was found in the right lower lobe, compatible with poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. The margins are negative for malignancy, and no direct extension of tumor or pleural invasion was identified. The regional lymph nodes included in the excision are negative for tumor. The lung away from the tumor has scattered chronic inflammation and interstitial thickening. The report includes gross descriptions of four specimens labeled A, B, C, and D, which are all fragments and tissue pieces from the excision. There is a block summary of the specimens indicating bronchial and vascular margins, lung tissue away from the tumor, tumor, and lymph nodes. No distant metastasis was identified. Overall, the report indicates the presence of non-small cell carcinoma in the lung and the absence of malignancy in the excised lymph nodes.

The pathology report describes a case of invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe of the lung, measuring 2.0 cm in greatest dimension. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and no tumor is seen in two removed lymph nodes. The patient has a history of prior laryngeal T4 squamous cell carcinoma. It is unclear whether the tumor in the lung represents metastatic disease or a new primary. The report includes details on the gross appearance, size, and location of the tumor in the lung, as well as the absence of tumor involvement in attached structures and satellite nodules. A small slice of tumor and normal tissue was given to Tissue Block Summary. The report also notes emphysematous changes in the nontumorous lung.

DIAGNOSIS: Grade 4 squamous cell carcinoma forming a 2.0 x 2.0 x. 1.5 cm mass located in the left upper lobe of the lung. Multiple (10) intrapulmonary peribronchial lymph nodes and the visceral pleura are negative for tumor. Grade 4 non-small cell carcinoma with squamous features is present in the soft tissue of the left hilar region. An intraparenchymal lymph node in the left lower lobe is negative for neoplasm, but non-necrotizing granulomatous inflammation is present. Multiple lymph nodes in the superior mediastinal, aortic, inferior mediastinal, and left lower lobe bronchus regions are negative for tumor. Special stains for microorganisms will be reported separately in an addendum.

SUMMARY: The left kidney specimen with attached perinephric fat was received and includes a circumscribed golden yellow partially hemorrhagic mass within the upper pole measuring 4.0 x 4.0 x 2.5 cm. The mass is identified as clear cell (conventional) renal cell adenocarcinoma with lymphovascular space invasion and a Fuhrman grade of 2/4. The tumor appears to be limited to the kidney without any invasion to the capsular, renal vein, or vascular margins. Adrenal gland was not resected, and there were no identified lymph nodes. The ureteral margin and soft tissue margins are negative. A representative section was taken for genomic studies.

DIAGNOSIS: Pheochromocytoma (5.5 x 4 x 3.5 cm) was identified in the specimen labeled "interaortocaval tumor". One lymph node was observed and showed no signs of tumor. No adrenal tissue was identified. The clinical information indicates that the right retroperitoneal mass was examined. The interaortocaval tumor was a single piece of red/purple, soft tissue, with a smooth surface and somewhat soft. The dimensions of the specimen were 5.5 x 4 x 3.5 cm, weighing 39.1 grams. The surgical margins were free of tumor. A representative section of the specimen was submitted for analysis.

The pathology report describes a resected sample of the cervical esophagus, measuring 5.5x5x1cm, with moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. Metastasis was found in 1 of 1 intraabdominal lymph nodes. The tumor was localized in the lamina propria or submucosa, but invasion of lymphatic or venous structures was not specified. No information was provided on margins or neo-adjuvant treatment. No other significant pathologic findings were reported.

The patient was diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma involving two separate nodules in the left breast, measuring 1.8 cm and 0.5 cm, respectively. Ductal carcinoma in situ, lympovascular invasion, pseudo angiomatous stromal hyperplasia, columnar cell alterations, proliferative fibrocystic changes, and fibroadenoma were also identified. Margins of resection were negative for tumor. Metastatic carcinoma was found in one of the left axillary sentinel lymph nodes, while the other nodes were free of tumor. The metastatic focus measured 0.2 mm and no extra nodal extension was identified. Prognostic markers were performed on the patient's core biopsy and the SNOMED codes are T-04050, M-85003, M-80310, M-72571.

Summary: The pathology report describes a radical nephrectomy specimen of the right kidney with a well-circumscribed 9.7 cm renal cell carcinoma, chromophobe type, Fuhrman nuclear grade 2, arising in the upper pole with no lymphovascular invasion. The report mentions that there is no tumor in the renal artery, vein, or ureter margins. The report also includes the evaluation of the non-neoplastic kidney which is normal with minimal chronic changes and no significant vascular sclerosis. The regional retroperitoneal lymph nodes are negative for tumor. The report concludes that attempted cytogenetic analysis was unsuccessful due to sample contamination but was indicated for oncological renal cell carcinoma.

The pathology report indicates the presence of infiltrating, poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinoma, with focal squamous features in the right upper lobe of the lung. The carcinoma measures 5.6 cm and does not involve the pleural surface. The report states that there is no involvement of the bronchial, vascular and parenchymal margins, and eight regional lymph nodes are negative for tumor. The non-neoplastic lung adjacent to the tumor shows numerous unspecified changes. The bronchial mucosa and one lymph node in the R10 excision, as well as two lymph nodes in the R11 excision, are negative for tumor.

The report describes the findings from a total thyroidectomy, a right upper parathyroid biopsy, and a right paratracheal lymph node excisional biopsy. No pathological diagnosis was given for the parathyroid and lymph node samples. The thyroid specimen showed a multifocal papillary carcinoma with widely invasive classical and Warthin-like variants, along with focal tall cell and hobnail cell changes. A follicular variant papillary microcarcinoma was also identified in the left lobe. Chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis was observed. No lymph-vascular or perineural invasion was identified, and extrathyroidal extension was not found. The primary tumor was staged as pT2 and there was no regional lymph node metastasis. Margins were uninvolved by carcinoma.

The pathology report relates to a male patient who presented with iron deficiency anemia and was diagnosed with invasive adenocarcinoma at the gastroesophageal junction via a preoperative biopsy. The gross and microscopic surgical panel includes various specimens collected during surgery. Specimens A, D, E, and F are negative for malignancy. Specimen C, designated new gastric margin, reveals microscopic foci of adenocarcinoma that are deeper in the paraffin-embedded tissue block and are away from the true en face margin. The original frozen section slides were reviewed, and no malignant cells were identified. The nodule identified in the serosa at the time of frozen section represents a gastrointestinal stromal tumor. The microscopic appearance confirms the diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with mucinous type, present in multiple paraesophageal and perigastric lymph nodes. The tumor invades through the muscularis propria to involve the paraesophageal fat and extend into the wall of the esophagus and stomach. Angiolymphatic space invasion is identified. Pathologic staging shows the final TNM as pT3N1M0 and stage IIIA, presumed no distant metastasis. Findings of this case were discussed.

The pathology report describes a case of left kidney nephrectomy due to clear cell renal cell carcinoma with a size of 4.2 cm, Fuhrman nuclear grade II, and no lymphovascular invasion. The tumor is confined to the kidney and no tumor is found in the submitted regional lymph nodes. The report also mentions mild focal global glomerulosclerosis, arterial and arteriolar sclerosis, and minimal fibrosis and mononuclear inflammation in the interstitium. The gross description of the specimen is included, with representative sections and fragments submitted for special studies. Cytogenetic testing showed clonal aberrations in all metaphases, including 3p deletion consistent with renal cell carcinoma. No mention of patient, doctor, hospital name, treatment plan, or clinical diagnosis is included in the report.
