Diagnosis: Papillary thyroid carcinoma, 2.0 cm (gross), with multifocal growth pattern and confined to the thyroid gland. Lymphocytic thyroiditis and nodular hyperplasia present in the background thyroid. Extracapsular and vascular invasion not identified. Close but negative surgical margins (<0.5 mm of the right lobe anterior margin A1). Metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma identified in 5/7 total lymph nodes (1/3 in specimen A and 4/4 in specimen B), with extra-nodal extension present in the largest metastasis (B1). AJCC Stage: pT1 pN1 pMx. Gross description indicates 6.2-gram total thyroidectomy specimen with a multinodular appearance away from the tumor. Digital photograph not taken. Tissue submitted for special investigation. No additional gross findings identified in the right central neck dissection specimen, which includes four lymph node candidates (ranging in size from 1.2 cm to 1.6 cm).

The pathology report shows that the patient had a right renal mass, which was partially removed, and various tissue samples were submitted for examination. The amended diagnosis revealed that the tumor was a renal cell carcinoma of conventional (clear cell) type with Fuhrman Nuclear Grade III/IV, measuring 4.0 cm in diameter, and limited to the kidney. The surgical margins were free of tumor, and there was focal glomerulosclerosis in the non-neoplastic kidney. There was no evidence of local or renal vein invasion, adrenal gland involvement, or lymph node involvement. The soft tissue around the tumor was benign fibroadipose tissue, and the benign renal cortical parenchyma with focal glomerulosclerosis was found in a biopsy sample. A benign partially denuded urothelium and urethral wall were identified in the proximal right ureter excision sample. Additionally, immunostains confirmed diffuse cytoplasmic membranous CA IX expression in the tumor cells, which were negative for CK7, c-KIT, and racemase. Intraoperative consultation diagnoses were not provided in the report.

The pathology report describes a specimen received, consisting of four different parts: lymph nodes ST10L TB angle and Subcarinal ST7, left lung with bronchial resection margin, and lymph node Inferior pulmonary ligament ST9. The report diagnoses poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with blood and lymphatic vessels invasion in the left lung specimen, which has invaded the pulmonary artery and the interlobar node extensively infiltrated by tumor. The lymph nodes ST10L TB angle and Subcarinal ST7 are negative for malignancy, while the lymph node Inferior pulmonary ligament ST9 only contains adipose tissue. The report also describes the gross description of each specimen and the representative sections submitted for analysis.

SUMMARY: A right radical nephrectomy was performed on a patient with a 2 cm papillary type II renal cell carcinoma, grade 3, confined to the kidney and without invasion of perirenal or renal sinus fat. Ureter, renal artery, and renal vein at surgical margin negative for malignancy. Non-neoplastic renal parenchyma shows mild arterionephrosclerosis. No lymph nodes or adrenal glands are present. AJCC cancer classification: T1aNXMX. The specimen consisted of a right nephrectomy with attached Gerota's fascia and perinephric fat, as well as a 4.0 cm length segment of ureter with adjacent vasculature. Representative sections were submitted for analysis.

The pathology report describes a patient who underwent a pancreaticoduodenectomy and cholecystectomy due to invasive ductal adenocarcinoma in the head of the pancreas. The tumor was moderately differentiated and measured 3.0 cm in size, with perineural invasion present. Pathological staging revealed pT4NO. The report also includes biopsies of the liver, falciform ligament, lymph node, bile duct margin, pancreatic duct margin, and soft tissues in the middle celiac vein area. The liver biopsy showed minimal mixed portal inflammation, mild cholestasis, and a focal area of dense fibrosis, all negative for malignancy. The lymph node and bile duct margin biopsies were negative for malignancy, while the pancreatic duct margin biopsy showed pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia and chronic pancreatitis. The soft tissue biopsy in the middle celiac vein area was positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma. Histopathological testing was used to evaluate the presence of ERPR, Her2, and EGFR in the tissue.

The report describes the gross and microscopic examination of several specimens related to the non-small cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung. The frozen section diagnosis indicates no tumor present in mediastinal lymph nodes 2R, 4R, 7, or in the completion right lower lobe freeze for bronchial margins. However, metastatic carcinoma is present in mediastinal lymph node level 7. The right lower lobe wedge biopsy reveals a 1.6 x 1.3 x 1.1 cm invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. The pleural surface is negative for carcinoma, and no direct extension of the tumor is identified. The pathologic stage is pTla pN2 (as per specimen #7). Other lymph nodes (#5 and #8) are negative for metastatic carcinoma. The lung completion lobectomy specimen shows no residual adenocarcinoma, and the bronchial margin is negative. Multiple peribronchial lymph nodes are negative for metastatic carcinoma.

A male patient with a history of PSA value of 12.8 and biopsy revealing poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma underwent radical prostatectomy. No neoplasia was found in any of the 17 examined lymph nodes. The final diagnosis shows a poorly differentiated prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+3=7, involving both left and right lobes with a maximum diameter of 1.6cm and established extracapsular extension in the posterior right mid-region. Bilateral seminal vesicles are free of carcinoma, surgical margins are free of carcinoma, perineural invasion is identified, high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (HG-PIN) is identified, and no angiolymphatic invasion is identified. Pathologic TNM stage: pT3a NO MX. Background prostate tissue with benign prostatic hyperplasia and focal atrophy.

Final Pathologic Diagnosis: High-grade urothelial carcinoma with extensive muscularis propria invasion identified in the bladder tumor biopsy. Clinical history includes a bladder mass in a  old black female patient. The specimen received in formalin labeled "bladder tumor" weighed 26 g and measured 4.0 x 4.0 x 3.0 cm, with multiple fragments of red blood clot and pink/brown tissue. A representative portion is given to tumor bank. The case was reviewed by another attending pathologist.

The report describes metastatic adenocarcinoma in several lymph nodes in the pelvic area. There is also a focus of prostatic adenocarcinoma in the prostate gland with extraprostatic extension into the left seminal vesicle and soft tissue. The Gleason score is 9 and the tumor occupies approximately 70% of the prostatic volume. There is no tumor present in the right seminal vesicle or vasa deferentia. The lymph node metastases measure between 4 and 8 mm. The report indicates that the tumor extends to the margin of resection in some areas, while in other areas the margin is free of the tumor. The report includes gross descriptions of the dissected tissue, including the dimensions and fragment sizes. The report was completed by a medical professional and is being issued as an addendum to the original report for additional information. No treatment plan or further details regarding the sample size, shape, and weight are provided.

Esophageal biopsy shows an infiltrating, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma arising from Barrett mucosa with low grade columnar epithelial dysplasia. Clinical history is esophageal cancer. Multiple irregular tissue fragments are observed. No further information is provided.

Large intestine tissue from an abdominal perineal resection was analyzed. The tumor was located at the rectosigmoid junction and measured 0 x 0 x 3.5 cm, with an ulcerated appearance and diagnosed as moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. The tumor extent was limited to the subserosa layer, and lymph node involvement was observed in 1 of the 12 lymph nodes examined. Margins were uninvolved. No information was given regarding any neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings. No comments were provided.

A 55-year-old woman with stage I endometrial carcinoma underwent a hysterectomy. The uterus was grossly distorted by multiple leiomyomas and had an exophytic mass that involved the endometrial cavity with numerous papillary projections. The endometrial tumor appeared to involve the superficial myometrium. The fallopian tubes and ovaries had endometriosis but no evidence of malignancy. Ten pelvic lymph nodes and three left pelvic lymph nodes were also free of malignancy. The uterus had endometrioid adenocarcinoma of FIGO grade 2/8, with superficially invasive depth, absent cervical involvement, absent vascular invasion, and free surgical margins.

The pathology report describes a patient with prostate cancer who underwent a robot-assisted prostatectomy. The report indicates that benign adipose tissue with no lymph node or carcinoma was identified in the anterior lymph nodes. A biopsy on the apical margin showed prostate adenocarcinoma, Gleason grade 3+3 with severe cautery artifact. The prostate gland and seminal vesicles showed prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason grade 3+3 with focal extraprostatic extension. Lymph node status was negative. The report provides detailed information on the tumor location, estimated volume, Gleason score, margin status, and involvement of capsule, seminal vesicles, and perineural infiltration. High-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia was focally present. The final diagnosis made was pT3aNX stage prostate cancer.

Left renal vein biopsy shows a benign segment of vein with no neoplasia seen. Left kidney laparoscopic radical nephrectomy reveals renal cell carcinoma with mixed morphology, predominantly clear cell type with sarcomatoid features and papillary carcinoma. Fuhrman nuclear grade is 4 out of 4. Sarcomatoid component comprises approximately 25% of the tumor. The neoplasm measures 6.0 cm in diameter, extends into the renal sinus fat, and shows evidence of angiolymphatic invasion. Carcinoma is present in the lumen and attached to the endothelium of the renal vein with all final surgical resection margins negative for neoplasia. Non-neoplastic kidney shows changes due to proximity to the tumor, while the adrenal gland is unremarkable. TNM stage is pT3b NX MX. The specimen received is urine voided with one ThinPrep slide showing two clusters of atypical transitional cells and transitional cells.

Summary: The pathology report identifies a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a maximum tumor spread of 2.6 cm, extensive perineural infiltration, and extraprostatic tumor growth. There is infiltration of the left seminal vesicle and surgical margins in the left rectolateral and basal resection. Additionally, there is tumor-free fatty connective tissue with vessels and nerves, along with multiple tumor-free lymph nodes. The tumor is classified as pT3b, Gleason 5+4=9 with a small tertiary Gleason 3 portion. Immunohistology shows no evidence of invasion of vessels or lymph node metastases but further investigation is being conducted to settle the question of chromatin expression.

Summary: The pathology report describes a case of laryngeal carcinoma in a male patient. The surgical specimen obtained during the examination included the larynx, hyoid bone, and part of the trachea. Macroscopic examination identified a tumor in the glottal region, invading the subglottal, glottis, supraglottal regions and aryepiglottic fold on the left side. Histopathological analysis revealed invasive squamous cell carcinoma (G3) of the larynx with the incision lines free of neoplastic lesions. The report includes the pT3 stage and the code 8071/3 T-24100 for classification purposes, and identifies cancerous lesions at the side of 1 wire and 2 wires (top) during intraoperative examination. The final diagnosis is pending confirmation after paraffin specimen analysis by the pathologist.

Left lingula segmentectomy, left lower lobe lymph nodes, and left hilar lymph nodes were submitted for analysis. A moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with a central irregular zone of necrosis was identified in the left lingula lobe, measuring 23 mm. The tumour is located 4 mm from the pleural surface and appears to arise from the airways, with no evidence of cavitation or lymph node involvement. Focal change suspicious for perineural invasion is identified within the confines of the tumour. Lung parenchyma immediately adjacent to the tumour shows focal change of obstructive pneumonitis, while more distant lung parenchyma shows emphysema. The lymph nodes show reactive changes and no tumour is identified. Pathological stage: pT2a NO.

The pathology report describes a surgically removed specimen from a male patient with pancreatic carcinoma in the head region. The report shows moderately differentiated invasive glandular adenocarcinoma up to 4.5 cm in diameter with infiltration of the peripancreatic soft tissue and a cyst of size 3.5x6x3.5 cm. There was infiltration into the adjacent fatty tissue dorsal and medial, with peripancreatic lymph nodes of maximum size 1.2 cm. There were single regional lymph node metastases peripancreatically. The enteric, parenchymatous, and deeper resection margins were all without tumor. The report also showed a severe chronic fibrotic pancreatitis with a pancreatic pseudocyst, chronic cholecystitis, metastasis-free lymph nodes, and metastasis-free lymph nodes at the liver hilum. The omentum majus showed no tumor, with focal fibrosis, fresh leucocyte infiltration, and hemorrhage due to the surgery. The TNM classification for the cancer was pT3, pN1 (1/22), cM0, Pn1, LO, vo, RO, G2.

The report describes the case of a White male diagnosed with malignant mesothelioma, biphasic type, primarily composed of epithelioid cells and 10% sarcomatoid cells. The tumor has extended to the visceral pleura, lung parenchyma, mediastinal fat, and through the pericardium with venous/lymphatic invasion. Metastatic mesothelioma has been detected in one lymph node extensively replaced by metastatic mesothelioma and in four other lymph nodes. The report details the staging of the cancer, which is pT4, N3, and provides additional information on the size of the tumor, the type of cells present, and the location of the cancer.

This pathology report pertains to a sample of the right adrenal gland. The tumor is 5.5 cm in diameter and has a red to brownish appearance. Histologically, the tumor is surrounded by a fibrous capsule and is composed of Zellballen with some trabecular architecture. The nuclei are round to oval with smooth chromatin. Septal areas around the Zellballen show numerous dilated blood vessels, and single necrosis is present in the center. There is no significant increase in the number of mitoses, profound nuclear pleomorphism, vessel invasion, or capsule destruction. The final diagnosis is pheochromocytoma.

The pathology report describes a case of adenocarcinoma in a patient's right upper lobe lung. The tumor is poorly differentiated with solid, micropapillary, and papillary architecture and measures 2 cm in largest dimension. There is evidence of lymphovascular space invasion, but no evidence of visceral pleural invasion. One benign lymph node and four metastatic lymph nodes are found in level 9, level 10, suprapulmonary vein, and left level 7, respectively. All lymph nodes in level 11 and level 4 are involved in metastasis. The report also notes the presence of mild respiratory bronchiolitis in the background lung. The tumor is at pT1a N3 MX stage. Gross descriptions of the specimens, including lymph nodes and lung, are also provided.

Diagnosis: Gemistocytic astrocytoma with focal oligodendroglioma in the right frontal lobe. Mixed glioma, oligoastrocytoma with gemistocytic features in the right frontal lobectomy specimen. MIB-1 labeling index of 2.5% in the excisional biopsy, and 8.0% in the lobectomy specimen. Clinical history indicates headaches and seizures. The tumor cells exhibit a gemistocytic phenotype with prominent nuclear pleomorphism and infiltration of glial cells. Mitoses, macrovascular cellular proliferation, and necrosis are absent. Cystic spaces formed in the central area of the specimen with secretion of mucinous material. The tumor is present in all margins of resection, and perivascular lymphocytic infiltrates are present. The oligodendroglioma is the predominant component, and it is of low grade. However, the gemistocytic component and the high MIB-1 labeling index are concerning for aggressive behavior.

Pathology report indicates a papillary carcinoma tumor on the right side with a size of 2.5x2x1.8cm. The tumor consists of papillae having a fine fibrovascular stalk or folliculae covered by a single to multiple layers of cuboidal epithelial cells. The tumor has invaded the capsule, vessel or benign tissue. The cells maintain their polarity, and the nuclei are regular with finely dispersed chromatin or intranuclear grooves. The tumor is necrotic, fibrous, and has invaded skeletal muscle. There is no information regarding extracapsular extension.

The pathology report describes the specimen received as a pancreaticoduodenectomy, which includes the head of pancreas, duodenum, stomach, common bile duct, and gallbladder. The report states the presence of adenocarcinoma measuring 5 cm in the head of pancreas, infiltrating the duodenal wall and peripancreatic soft tissue. The surgical margins are free of tumor with the nearest margin being 2 mm from the tumor. Additionally, chronic cholecystitis is noted in the gallbladder specimen. Ten regional lymph nodes are examined, and none contain tumor cells. The report provides the tumor size, histologic type, and grade, as well as the microscopic tumor extension and pathologic staging. Gross descriptions of the specimens received are also included. An intraoperative consultation was performed, with no tumor seen in the common bile duct and distal pancreatic duct margins. The report includes photo documentation.

The pathology report describes the findings from three specimens received from a female patient with a history of melanoma and a large abdominal mass. The report includes the diagnosis of metastatic endocervical adenocarcinoma with extensive necrosis in the left ovary and fallopian tube, with focal surface involvement. The right ovary and fallopian tube have benign paratubal cysts and physiologic changes, respectively. The hysterectomy with right salpingo-oophorectomy revealed endocervical adenocarcinoma with villoglandular features originating from the lower uterine segment with the largest invasive focus measuring 6.5 mm in horizontal extent by 4 mm in depth. No lymphovascular space invasion was identified. Other findings include cervical intraepithelial neoplasia 3 involving the anterior cervix, chronic cervicitis, multiple leiomyomas, and adenomyosis. The pathology report confirms the presence of squamous dysplasia and endocervical adenocarcinoma metastatic to the left adnexa and right paratubal tissue through immunohistochemical stains and morphology. The report also notes that there is no tumor seen in the omentum, and mesothelial hyperplasia and chronic inflammation are present. The report provides block summaries for each specimen received.

The pathology report describes the diagnosis and features of two adrenal gland specimens submitted for evaluation due to bilateral pheochromocytoma. The report indicates that the right adrenal gland specimen shows a composite pheochromocytoma with ganglioneuroma, while the left adrenal gland specimen shows a clear cell adrenal cortical adenoma with no evidence of adrenal medullary hyperplasia. The report notes the absence of adrenal medullary hyperplasia in the nontumorous medulla, making the possibility of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 unlikely. The right adrenal gland tumor will be tested for SDHB expression to rule out familial paraganglioma syndromes. The report includes details of gross and microscopic examination of the tumors and confirms the right adrenal gland tumor as a composite pheochromocytoma and ganglioneuroma, without evidence of SDH mutation. The MIB-1 labeling index is 5%.
Summary: Invasive carcinoma with focal intraductal spread and invasion of lymph vessels. Poorly differentiated lobular carcinoma classification: lobular carcinoma, G III, oT2N3aL1V0RX.

The pathology report describes a tumor fragment found in the lower lobe of the lung which is almost completely obstructed by a white, intrabronchial neoplasm of the spinocellular epidermoid carcinoma type, without keratinization. The tumor is approximately 1/2/1 cm in diameter, with papillary pattern, monomorphous cellularity, nuclear atypias, atypical mitoses, hotbeds of necrosis, and abundant fibrous-inflammatory stroma. The pulmonary parenchyma shows fibrin-leukocytic alveolitis. No metastases were found in the lymph nodes. The histologic type is papillary squamous cell carcinoma of moderate differentiation, and no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment is present. The tumor is located in the main bronchus of the left-lower lung.

Diagnosis: Brain, left occipital lobe biopsy and resection revealed a diffuse astrocytoma, WHO grade II. The lesion primarily displays astrocytic features with labeling of fibrillary cytoplasmic processes. Mib-1 labeling index is less than 2%. The immunoexpression of R132H mutant IDH1 is present. The material will undergo further cytogenetic and molecular testing. The diagnoses given during intraoperative consultation were also glioma.

The report states that the decalcified sections of the anterior mandibular resection margin and right mandible condyle are free of carcinoma. However, the original diagnosis remains unchanged, and the right composite resection and neck dissection show invasive squamous carcinoma, poorly differentiated, involving the mandible, buccal mucosa, and floor of the mouth. The report also mentions perineural invasion and metastatic squamous carcinoma involving 14 of 24 lymph nodes. The tumor measures 8.5 x 8.5 x 8.0 cm, and two pterygoid margins initially tested positive for carcinoma, but the final margin of excision is tumor-free. The rest of the soft tissue margins of resection including skin, skeletal muscles, pterygoid muscle, tongue margin, right palate margin, buccal margin, right maxillary tuberosity, and teeth do not show any tumor. The final margin of pterygoid muscle shows no tumor and the specimen is submitted to the bone laboratory for further processing. No discrete lesions are identified in the TONGUE MARGIN STITCH ANTERIOR, RIGHT PALATE MARGIN STITCH ANTERIOR, and BUCCAL MARGIN, while the LATERAL PTERYGOID MARGIN and NEW PTERYGOID MARGIN show poorly differentiated squamous carcinoma. Finally, the SNOMED codes are M-80703 T-D166X.

The pathology report describes a case of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with pleural and perineural invasion in a partial mandibulectomy resection. There are no tumors present in the left mental nerve, right ventral tongue margin, right alveolar ridge margin, or left new alveolar ridge margin, although the left alveolar ridge margin shows invasive squamous cell carcinoma. A piece of mucosa with focal dysplasia but no invasive carcinoma is detected in the left new alveolar ridge margin. The report lacks a clinical history and specific information about the patient or hospital.

Summary: The pathology report shows the presence of papillary serous adenocarcinoma in both ovaries, grade III, with lymphovascular space invasion and involvement of cortical surface and attached soft tissue. Omentum also showed metastatic papillary serous adenocarcinoma, which was extensive. The staging is T3C, NX, M1 (FIGO: IV). The gross description shows yellow to gray tan hemormagic soft tissue mass in the right ovary measuring 6.0 x 5.0 x 3.0 cm and multiple pieces of yellow tan to gray tan fibroadipose omentum tissue measuring 25.0x 11.0 x 3.0 cm. The left ovary also has a yellow-gray slightly hemorrhagic soft issue mass measuring 4.5 x 3.5 x 3.0 cm. Normal ovarian tissue is not grossly identified in any of the specimens. Representative sections were taken for genomic studies.

Final Pathologic Diagnosis: 
A. Ureter, left, biopsy: No tumor.
B. Ureter, right, biopsy: No tumor.
C. Bladder and prostate and seminal vesicles, cystoprostatectomy: Invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma in the bladder. Focal atypical glands in the prostate. No tumor in the seminal vesicle.
E. Pelvic lymph nodes, right, excision: Metastatic urothelial carcinoma in one lymph node (1/3).
F. Pelvic lymph node, left, excision: No tumor in one lymph node (0/1).

Comment:
Bladder Tumor Synoptic Comment.
1. Tumor type: Urothelial (transitional cell) carcinoma.
2. Tumor grade: High grade.
3. Tumor size: Gross appearance at least 1.9 cm in greatest diameter.
4. Extent of tumor in bladder: Invasion through muscularis propria into perivesical tissue.
5. Lymphatic/vascular invasion: None definitively identified.
6. Epithelial abnormalities in bladder: Focal areas of carcinoma in situ.
7. Extension of tumor into organs adjacent to bladder: No adjacent organs involved.
8. Surgical margins: Urethral margin, right ureter margin, and left ureter margin free of tumor. Perivesical margin: Invasive tumor <0.5 mm to inked specimen margin.
9. Lymph nodes: 1 of 4 lymph nodes contain metastatic tumor; the largest metastatic deposit measures 1.2 cm in greatest dimension; there is no extranodal tumor growth.
10. Other pathologic findings in bladder: None.
11. AJCC/UICC stage: pT3aN1Mx / Stage IV.
12. Additional Comments: Focal atypical prostatic glands identified in the urethral margin on the frozen section but absent on permanent sections. No definitive prostatic or urothelial carcinoma identified in the prostate or seminal vesicles. Ureter biopsies do not show dysplasia or carcinoma.

Clinical History: The patient underwent transurethral resection of a bladder tumor greater than 5 cm in size that was invading into the perivesicular fat at another institution.

Specimens Received:
A: Left ureter (FS)
B: Right ureter (FS)
C: Prostate and seminal vesicles, bladder (FS)
D: Apical margin
E: Right pelvic lymph node
F: Left pelvic lymph node
G: Final left ureter
H: Final right ureter

A breast tumor measuring up to 2.5 cm is present along with dense hyperemic metastatic lymph nodes of size up to 2 cm. Microscopically, infiltrating lobular carcinoma of the breast with a scirrhous growth pattern is observed, with a tumor grade of 2. Metastases are noted in ten examined lymph nodes. ER and PR receptors are positive with a reaction of 85% and 70% respectively, while Her-2/neu is negative, and the Ki-67 value is 18%. The tumor extent is T2, margin and venous invasion are absent. No treatment effect is reported. Nottingham Histologic Score couldn't be determined.

The pathology report describes specimens from a patient who underwent a right lower lobe wedge resection. The lung wedge resection revealed a 1.6 cm poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with no lymph-vascular invasion or pleural involvement. The staple line margin was free of tumor. One lymph node from station 9, one from station 7, and two from station 4 were biopsied and found to be negative for carcinoma. Additional findings included emphysema. No additional information such as patient demographics, hospital name, or treatment plan were provided. The report also mentions the use of immunohistochemical and mucin stains as special procedures.

The pathology report relates to a male patient who underwent left hemimandibulectomy due to invasive, well-differentiated squamous carcinoma invading mandibular bone. Resection margins were free of tumor. The report also shows that two lymph nodes from the upper and middle level 5, and seven lymph nodes from the left supraomohyoid area were free of metastatic disease. However, metastatic squamous carcinoma was detected in two of four submaxillary lymph nodes with extranodal extension. Additionally, there was mild atrophy in the submandibular gland, but no tumor was present. The skin and subcutaneous tissue of the cheek showed necrosis, acute inflammation, and foreign body giant cell reaction but no carcinoma was evident. A full gross description is provided, including the size and shape of lymph nodes and tumor margins. The details such as patient and doctor names, hospital names, etc. are not included in the report.

Diagnosis: Acinar cell adenocarcinoma.

Location: Right-upper lung tissue.

Specimen type: Lobectomy.

Tumor size: 6 X 6 X 7 cm.

Tumor extent: Not specified.

Histologic grade: Poorly differentiated.

Other tumor nodules: Not specified.

Lymph nodes: 3/13 positive for metastasis. (Hilar 3/13).

Lymphatic invasion: Not specified.

Venous invasion: Not specified.

Margins: Not specified.

Evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment: Not specified.

Additional pathologic findings: Not specified.

Comments: None.

The pathology report is related to a patient with bilateral thyroid nodules. The following specimens were submitted for evaluation: pretracheal tissue, Delphian node, right lower parathyroid, total thyroidectomy, and tissue from the right lower pole of the thyroid. The report states that the pretracheal tissue consists of one benign lymph node with crush and cautery artifact, while the Delphian node shows benign fibroadipose tissue with no lymph node identified. The right lower parathyroid biopsy shows a fragment of benign hyperplastic thyroid tissue. The total thyroidectomy reveals a papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, with a tumor diameter of 1.0 cm in the right lobe and papillary microcarcinoma in three foci in the left lobe. The surgical margins are free of the tumor. The thyroid exhibits nodular hyperplasia, and no parathyroid glands are identified. One benign lymph node is present. Immunohistochemistry was performed on one hyperplastic nodule showing positive staining for thyroglobulin and negative staining for calcitonin, chromogranin, and synaptophysin. The tissue from the right lower pole of the thyroid shows fragments of benign thyroid tissue with nodular hyperplasia. No intraoperative consultation diagnosis was given.

The report describes the examination of multiple specimens including lymph nodes and lung tissue from a patient with a pre-operative diagnosis of lung cancer. The analysis shows reactive lymph nodes in specimens A, B, D, E, F, H, K, L, and tumors in specimens I and J, which are squamous cell carcinomas. Specimen C, a right upper lobe wedge, shows scar and chronic inflammation with fibrous pleural adhesions. The report also includes information on gross descriptions, margins, and pathological staging. No treatment plan is mentioned in the report.

Sample type: Tumour. Sample preparation: Fresh Frozen. Site of primary: Uterine. Site of tissue: Endometrial mass. Procedure type: Surgical resection. Histology: Endometrioid adenocarcinoma, NOS & Endometrioid with squamous differentiation. Grade/Differentiation: III. Pathological T: T1b. Physical tumor size: 4.2 cm. Clinical M: M0.

The pathology report describes the final diagnosis of a left breast lumpectomy specimen, including the tumor type (infiltrating ductal carcinoma), Nottingham grade (poorly differentiated grade 3), Nottingham score (9/9), tumor size (1.3 cm), absence of microcalcifications, and presence of venous/lymphatic invasion. The report also notes the presence of DCIS, foci of angiolymphatic invasion, negative lymph nodes, and a benign axillary content removal. The specimen was inked and sectioned for evaluation, with representative sections submitted for testing. No intraductal component was identified and the nipple and skin were not sampled. The patient's hormone receptor and HER2 status were previously reported, and the final pathological stage was pT1 NO MX (AJCC Stage I). A single sentinel lymph node was also examined and found to be negative for tumor.

The surgical pathology report describes the samples received from a left temporal brain tumor in a male patient. The specimens consisted of multiple pieces of rubbery, pink-tan soft tissue, which were submitted for frozen section, tumor bank, and permanent cassettes. The frozen section diagnosis revealed an anaplastic astrocytoma with gemistocytic features. Immunohistochemical stains demonstrated that the majority of tumor cells were immunoreactive for GFAP, while P53 immunostain showed rare individual weakly immunoreactive tumor cells. The Ki-67 demonstrated an elevated proliferation index of up to 10%, supporting the diagnosis. The presence of hyperplastic blood vessels with fibrin thrombi and a prominent perivascular infiltrate of mature lymphocytes was observed. Chromosomal testing for 1p19q status was performed, and no deletions were identified. The report recommends correlation with clinical and imaging findings, and no definitive treatment plan was mentioned.

The pathology report indicates a case of invasive ductal carcinoma in the left breast with multiple foci and a total tumor size of 6.0 cm. A sentinel lymph node biopsy revealed metastatic tumor cells in two out of three lymph nodes examined, with extracapsular extension identified in one of them. The report also mentions the presence of ductal carcinoma in-situ (DCIS) in malignant zones, constituting 10% of the total tumor mass and located in both the lower outer and lower inner quadrants. Resection margins are negative for both invasive and in-situ carcinoma. Eleven axillary lymph nodes examined were negative for metastatic tumor. The tumor is positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors and negative for HER2/NEU with no amplification according to the previous pathology report. Various non-neoplastic breast tissue elements are also identified. The final pathological staging is T3N1aMx.

The pathology report is about a female patient with a history of symptomatic papillary thyroid carcinoma who underwent SPHS and SPGD procedures. The SPHS procedure involved a right level III lymph node with a portion of fibroadipose tissue containing six possible lymph nodes. The SPGD procedure involved a 17.8-gram thyroid with a 5 x 2.5 x 1.3 cm left lobe, a 4.5 x 3.2 x 1.3 cm right lobe, and a 1.3 x 1.0 x 0.4 cm isthmus. The right lobe had two nodules, one of which measured 1.3 x 1.2 x 1.0 cm, and a separate nodule abutting the thyroid capsule. The left lobe was variegated without nodules. A Level VI lymph node was also inspected and found to have multiple fibroadipose tissue portions containing several possible lymph nodes. The frozen section report indicated fragments of benign lymph nodes. In a subsequent procedure, a total thyroidectomy was performed, and the largest primary tumor measured 1.1 cm, confined to the thyroid without extrathyroidal extension or vascular invasion. Margins were negative, and lymph node metastases were not detected. A lymph node dissection was negative for neoplasm.

A resected specimen labeled "right upper lobe" contains a moderately well circumscribed, 2.0 cm. lung adenocarcinoma tumor that invades the visceral pleura and approaches the pleura. No additional mass lesions or abnormalities were identified. Five lymph nodes were recovered from the hilum, with nine lymph nodes submitted in total, all negative for metastasis. The 2R, 4R, station 7, and station 9 lymph nodes are negative for metastasis, except for one lymph node at station 9 containing metastasis. Granulomatous inflammation is present in station 7 and A9 lymph nodes. No other significant findings were observed.

A lump with a tumor measuring 3.2 x 2.7 cm in size was observed in the right lower outer quadrant of the breast tissue. The lump indicates an infiltrating ductal carcinoma of poorly differentiated G3 grade. Ten examined lymph nodes were hyperemic, up to 1 cm in diameter and showed reactive changes. The tumor extent is more than 2cm but not more than 5cm (T2). No venous invasion was identified. The lymph nodes did not show metastasis (0/10). The margins are uninvolved. Other features such as Nottingham Histologic Score, extracapsular invasion of the lymph nodes, and mitotic count were not specified. Neo-adjuvant treatment was also not indicated.

The pathology report describes the findings from a cholecystectomy, appendectomy, and total gastrectomy with proximal margin excision. The gallbladder showed benign glandular extension into the wall of the fundus consistent with an adenomyoma. The appendix was unremarkable with no dysplasia or malignancy identified. The stomach showed invasive adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated, arising just distal to the esophagogastric junction. The tumor invaded the submucosa with positive lymphovascular invasion and two of twenty-five lymph nodes showing metastasis. Margins were negative for malignancy, and there was no perineural invasion identified. Multiple fundic gland polyps and a few hyperplastic polyps were present, and the gastric antrum showed chemical gastritis with foveolar hyperplasia. The final esophageal margin showed benign esophageal wall without tumor involvement. The case was pathologic stage IIB, with the primary tumor being pT1b and regional lymph node involvement being pN1. No distant metastasis was identified.

Breast, right, simple mastectomy report shows moderately differentiated squamous carcinoma involving mammary parenchyma forming a 5.2 x 5.0 x 4.7 cm mass, located in the central aspect of the breast with skin ulceration. Angiolymphatic invasion is present, and a single intramammary lymph node is positive for metastatic carcinoma forming a solid and cystic mass (6.5 x 5.0 x 4.7 cm) in the lateral aspect of the breast. Extranodal extension is present, and the skin and nipple areolar region is also involved. However, all surgical resection margins including skin and deep margins are negative for tumor. The lymph nodes, right axillary, excision, show multiple (21) nodes negative for metastatic carcinoma. The surrounding breast parenchyma shows nonproliferative fibrocystic changes. Estrogen receptor, progesterone receptor, and HER2 status are not mentioned but will be reported in an addendum. The stage is [AJCC pT3N1] (7th edition, 2010).

The report describes a left adrenal pheochromocytoma measuring 3cm in length. Microscopically, the tumor shows densely cellular trabecular architecture without evidence of mitotic figures or necrosis. Immunohistochemical study illustrates chromogranin positivity, well-preserved sustentacular network highlighted by PS100. The PASS score indicates high cellular monotony and cellularity. There is peripheral adrenal cortical nodulation without hyperplasia of glomerulosa. There is no infiltration of the capsule or surrounding tissues.

The patient is a female with a high-grade, invasive urothelial carcinoma in the bladder and a microscopic focus of cancer in one lymph node. The tumor is multifocal and measures 3.2 x 1.8 cm in the anterior wall, with invasion to a depth of 1.0 cm extending to 0.3 cm from the inked margin. The left pelvic and right pelvic lymph nodes are negative for tumor. The uterus has atrophic endometrium and myometrium with three leiomyomas. The atrophic ovaries and unremarkable fallopian tubes are uninvolved. The right distal ureter tip shows no evidence of the tumor. TNM staging is pT3a, N1, MX.

Filtered Pathology Report: Right frontal brain tumor including inferior medial frontal lobe diagnosed as Oligodendroglioma with focal anaplastic progression (grade III) with MIB-1 labeling index of 8.2%. Microscopic examination reveals diffusely infiltrating hypercellular neoplasm of mildly to moderately atypical oligodendrocytes without microvascular proliferation or necrosis. Nodular foci with greater cellularity and atypia are seen in some regions, with 6 mitoses identified in 10 high power fields in one such region indicative of early anaplastic progression of the underlying low-grade oligodendroglioma. In the inferior medial frontal lobe tumor, only 1 mitosis is identified in 30 high power fields.

The pathology report describes a case of renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney of a patient. The tumor is 10.4 x 7.0 x 5.0 cm in size and is of the conventional (clear cell) type with a Fuhrman nuclear grade of 3. The tumor invades the renal vein but does not involve the renal vein margin. Resection margins, including the renal vein, artery, ureter, and perirenal soft tissue, are free of the tumor. The adjacent kidney parenchyma is unremarkable, and no lymph nodes are identified in the hilum of the kidney. The right adrenal gland is not present in the specimen. The adrenal gland is unremarkable after gross examination. No information on the patient's clinical history is available.

The pathology report describes a case of squamous cell carcinoma in the lymph nodes of the right and left neck, with extranodal extension present in the right neck. A squamoproliferative lesion with keratosis was found in the base left tongue, but no cancer was present. No tumor was present in the left lateral pharynx, and the right lateral pharynx had a tumor that invaded soft tissue and measured 4.0 cm, extending into pre-epiglottic soft tissue. Invasive squamous cell carcinoma was also present in the right glottis (1.0 cm). 19 lymph nodes were examined in the right neck, with 15 testing positive for cancer, and 37 lymph nodes were examined in the left neck, with three showing signs of cancer. There was vascular invasion, and intraperineural invasion was present in the right neck. The final margins were free, and the patient's stage is pT3 N2c for the right neck and pT1 for the left glottis. An addendum shows that immunostains for p53 and Ki-67 were not increased in the squamoproliferative areas, and the specimen included tissue from a total laryngectomy and other excisions. There is a history of MRSA infection, and no specific clinical question was given. An outside tissue diagnosis was not provided.

The pathology report describes a case of obstructing right colon cancer, with tumor characteristics including a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the cecum measuring 7.5 X 5.5 x 1.6 cm, extending through muscularis propria into subserosal adipose tissue but not clearly perforating the serosal surface. There is no unequivocal lymphovascular space invasion or mesenteric deposits, and all margins are clear with no lymph nodes positive for metastatic carcinoma. A pill cam was present in the terminal ileum, and there were fibrous serosal adhesions. The appendix and terminal ileum show no evidence of carcinoma. Clinical correlation and follow-up are recommended.

Final diagnosis: The pathology report indicates that the patient has prostate cancer. The report confirms the presence of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4=7 in the left and right apex through mid prostate. The tumor is confined to the prostate gland and there is no evidence of extracapsular extension, angiolymphatic invasion, or perineural invasion. Multiple high-grade PINs are observed and benign lymph nodes are identified in both the pelvic regions. The surgical resection margins are free of neo-plasia and the seminal vesicles and distal vasa deferentia are benign. The TNM pathological stage is pT2c, NO, MX. The patient had undergone a radical prostatectomy and bilateral pelvic lymphadenectomy.

DIAGNOSIS: Infiltrating poorly differentiated and mucinous adenocarcinoma with scattered signet ring cells and areas of overlying squamous epithelium at the esophagogastric junction tumor. Villiform columnar-lined mucosa with high-grade columnar epithelial dysplasia/intramucosal adenocarcinoma and bacterial colonies are also present. GROSS DESCRIPTION: Multiple red-tan soft tissue fragments aggregating to 1.0 x 0.3 x 0.2 cm. CLINICAL HISTORY: GE junction adenocarcinoma metastasized to the liver. IMMUNOHISTOCHEMISTRY RESULTS: HER2 overexpression is positive with 10% invasive tumor cells exhibiting complete membrane staining for HER2. Uniformity of staining is absent, and a homogeneous, dark circumferential pattern is present. SNOMED CODES: T-56000, T-56350, M-81403, M-54030, M-84803, M-84903.

The pathology report describes a partial nephrectomy of the left kidney due to a 4.8 cm papillary renal cell carcinoma located in the upper pole of the kidney. The tumor did not penetrate the capsule or extend into perinephric fat, and there was no involvement of the renal pelvis, ureter, renal sinus, hilar renal veins, or lymph nodes. The tumor grade was determined to be 3 based on occasional Fuhrman grade 3 nuclei. Other biopsied tissues showed either no tumor or necrotic debris. Frozen sections were taken of the mass, base margin, and cyst wall for diagnosis during the operation and were later confirmed by microscopic examination. The attending pathologist provided the final diagnosis.

DIAGNOSIS: A. Benign adipose tissue without neoplastic process identified. B. No tumor identified. C. Renal cell carcinoma, papillary subtype. Tumor confined to the right kidney, measuring 4.0 cm. Foci of transgression of renal capsule noted. Fuhrman grade 2/4 with no lymphovascular space invasion or sarcomatoid features identified. Surgical margin status showed tumor present at inked capsular surface. Lymph node status unknown. pTNM stage: T3a. Papillary architecture with foci of clear cell change noted. Case reviewed by an expert who agrees with the diagnosis. Specimens received include peritumor fat, posterior margin #1 with frozen section, and right renal tumor. No tumor identified in peritumor fat and posterior margin #1. Tumor present in right renal tumor with surgical margin status indicating tumor at inked capsular surface. Intra-operative consultation showed no tumor identified on frozen section.

Type: Clinical Diagnosis & History: Bladder carcinoma. Specimens Submitted: 1: SP: Right ureter, benign segment. 2: SP: Left ureter, segment with urothelial carcinoma in situ. 3-6: Lymph node dissections, metastatic urothelial carcinoma in 4 of 4 lymph nodes in right common iliac, 2 of 10 in right pelvic, and 2 of 12 in left pelvic, extranodal extension identified. 7: SP: Bladder, uterus, bilateral tubes and ovaries, cervix; urothelial carcinoma with mixed histologic features, high grade; invasion of perivesicle soft tissue, involvement of ureters, urethra, vascular & perineural invasion, tumor present at left ureteral margin, chronic cystitis present. Examinations of various organs were unremarkable. Surgical margins: tumor present at left ureteral margin. 8: SP: Left ureter #2; urothelial carcinoma in situ.

The pathology report describes a case of T2N2M0 squamous cell carcinoma of the tongue with a separate lesion on the right vallecula. The left hemiglossectomy specimen showed poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring approximately 4.0 cm in greatest dimension, extensively involving the specimen, and diffusely involving the deep margin of resection. Medial and lateral margins were free of tumor. Right neck nodes showed metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in 2 of 22 lymph nodes (lymph node count by level: Level I - 1 of 2, Level II - 1 of 4, Level III - 0 of 5, Level IV - 0 of 8, Level V - 0 of 3) with the size of largest metastasis 2.0 cm in greatest dimension, and extracapsular extension of the tumor. Left neck lymph nodes and cervical contents showed metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in 3 of 25 lymph nodes (lymph node count by level: Level 1 - 2 of 4, Level II - 1 of 9, Level III - 0 of 8, Level IV - 0 of 4), with the size of the largest metastasis 1.8 cm and extracapsular extension of the tumor identified. Intraoperative frozen section consultations showed no tumor identified in the vallecular lesion, posterior lateral tongue mucosa, right and left surface mucosa margins, posterior muscle margin, right muscle margin, floor of the mouth mucosa margin, and floor of the mouth muscle margin. The report includes a detailed description of specimens and blocks, lymph nodes, and light microscopy, but no other significant findings were observed.

Filtered Pathology Report: Liver tumor identified as moderately differentiated Hepatocellular carcinoma in liver segment 2, 3. Lymphovascular invasion noted in small vessels. Resection margin negative. Cirrhosis/fibrosis and chronic Hepatitis B also noted. Gross description reveals a well-circumscribed yellow mass measuring 2.7 x 2.3 x 2.1 cm, with necrosis and punctate hemorrhage. Microscopic examination identifies trabecular pattern >4 cells thick with notable areas of pseudoglandular architecture. Glypican-3 staining is strongly positive, indicating hepatocellular origin. Other markers of differentiation, including markers of cholangiocytic differentiation and stem cell features, are largely negative.

The pathology report describes the examination of a chest mass, which was excised from a left upper lobe. The gross description notes the presence of a white-tan indurated lesion that measures 3.2 x 3.2 x 2.3 cm and is contiguous with a 1.5 cm umbilication. Histologically, the primary tumor is identified as a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma that extends up to the visceral pleura but has negative margins of resection. Vascular invasion is present, but there are no regional lymph nodes or distant metastases identified. The excised lymph nodes at levels 10, 5, and 7 are negative for metastatic carcinoma.

Final Diagnosis: Oligodendroglioma with early anaplastic transformation (WHO grade III) in left frontal masses #1-#3 and CUSA resection. Immunohistochemical stains showed neoplastic cells positive for IDH1 (R132H) mutation and scattered p53 protein positivity. Ki67 labeling index varied from low to moderate. FISH studies for 1p19q deletion ordered. Preliminary Frozen Section Consultation indicated diffuse glioma, favor astrocytoma. Smears prepared for left frontal masses #1, #2, and CUSA specimen trap for further analysis.

Diagnosis: Colon carcinoma, moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma, invasive spread within all intestinal wall layers up to the bordering mesocolic fatty tissue and the level of the subserosa, extending up to 5cm to one resection margin, with a size of 4.5cm at the widest point. Few pseudodiverticula and slightly scarring peridiverticulitis present in the colon wall. Stage of the tumor is pT3 pNO (0/22) LO V0; G2 RO.

The pathology report describes a brain tumor consisting of irregular pieces of soft to firm cream tissue measuring 7x5x2mm and 19x10x6mm. Microscopic examination reveals brain tissue with focal areas of increased cellularity consisting of oligodendroglioma cells mixed with astrocytic cells. There is also a slight increase in cellularity in adjacent brain tissue. The report suggests a Grade III (WHO grading) mixed high-grade oligodendroglioma with the presence of astrocytoma. FISH testing for 1p and 19q deletions and 7/EGFR amplification was requested. The FISH testing results indicated loss of 1p36 and 19q13. The report references criteria for loss of 1p and 19p and amplification of EGFR/CEP 7. No additional information was provided.

The report describes the analysis of two specimens, one from the left lung and another from lymph nodes. The left lung specimen is a pneumonectomy with a moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma that fully obstructs a segmental bronchus, but not extending beyond the bronchial resection margin. The tumour does not involve the pleura except the hilar surface and the oblique fissure. The lymph nodes show no malignancy. The pathological stage is T2 N1. The lung distal to the tumour has extensive secondary obstructive changes with active airway inflammation and organizing pneumonia.

The pathology report describes a specimen labeled "cervical cone" received in formalin, showing large cell nonkeratinizing Grade 2 squamous cell carcinoma with stromal invasion involving the cervix circumferentially, deep and endocervical margins. The tumor measures at least 7.0 mm in depth and at least 10.0 mm in lateral extension, with vascular space invasion focally identified. The report also includes a specimen labeled "endocervical curettings" received in formalin, showing scant fragments of squamous cell carcinoma. The specimens are processed and entirely submitted in multiple cassettes, with CPT codes for cervical cone and endocervical biopsy and ICD-9 code of 180.9.

The pathology report pertains to a breast specimen which includes a non-sentinel lymph node, right breast, and left breast. The report diagnoses metastatic carcinoma in the lymph node, lobular carcinoma in situ in the right breast, and multiple invasive ductal carcinomas with DCIS and metastases in 2 of the 14 lymph nodes in the left breast. The tumors have a central location, are negative for necrosis, and show vascular/lymphatic invasion. Margins are clear of tumor in all specimens. The report also mentions other findings such as fibroadenomas, fibrocystic changes, and hyperplasia without atypia. ER/PR are positive, HER2 is negative. The patient's clinical history is not available.

The report describes a left upper lobectomy specimen weighing 180g, with a tumour nodule of 30 x 28 x 25 mm found in the superior lingular segment. The tumour has caused puckering of the overlying pleura, but no pleural surface involvement is seen macroscopically. Microscopically, the sections show a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma which abuts but does not directly invade the pleura, with lymphatic permeation involving pleural lymphatics. No vascular invasion or lymph node metastasis is seen, and peribronchial lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy. The pathological stage is T2 NO. A subpleural nodule in the anterior segment is identified as a silicotic nodule, and a larger nodule in the lingular segment has a similar appearance with extensive central necrosis. Special stains show no evidence of infective organisms.

The pathology report describes a case of invasive squamous cell carcinoma in a female patient. The tumor was located in the right tongue, with a maximal diameter of 2.5 cm and a depth of invasion of 0.6 cm. The patient underwent neck dissection, which revealed no metastatic carcinoma in eight lymph nodes (0/8) in the right neck levels 2, 3, 4, and 5, but one out of three lymph nodes (1/3) in the right level 1A had metastatic carcinoma. There was no viable extracapsular extension of tumor, and no tumor was identified in the submandibular gland and soft tissue margins. The tumor had lymphovascular space invasion and carcinoma in situ. The perineural invasion was not identified. The final pTNM stage was pT2 N1. Therefore, the report concludes that the patient has moderately differentiated (G2) invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the right tongue with lymph node involvement.

Diagnosis: Left kidney nephrectomy due to renal cell carcinoma, chromophobe subtype, with a tumor size of 5.0 cm. The tumor was unifocal and did not invade nearby organs, lymph nodes, or vessels. There were no sarcomatoid features identified, and surgical margins were negative for tumor involvement. The AJCC staging was pT1b. The remainder of the kidney appeared homogeneous without cysts or other lesions. Six tissue blocks were submitted for evaluation, including tumor and adjacent parenchyma, calyces, and blue inked capsule.

The pathology report relates to the diagnosis of breast cancer in a patient. The report identifies an invasive lobular carcinoma, classical type, with modified Black's nuclear grades 1 and 2, covering an area of approximately 3 cm, with lymphovascular invasion. Lobular carcinoma in situ, intraductal papilloma, fibrocystic changes including duct epithelial hyperplasia without atypia, apocrine metaplasia, radial scar, and cyst. The report also mentions metastatic carcinoma in one of twelve lymph nodes, with extranodal extension up to 3.0 mm present. Finally, the addendum section provides immunohistochemistry results for HER2 overexpression, which are negative.

The pathology report describes a surgical procedure carried out on the patient's left breast due to the discovery of a mass. The report reveals that a segmental mastectomy was performed, during which a 3.2 cm infiltrating moderately differentiated ductal carcinoma and a 0.7 cm intraductal carcinoma were identified. The report indicates that tumor-associated microcalcifications were also found. The infiltrating carcinoma was determined to be within 1mm of the inked superior and deep margins, but the new superior margin biopsy results were benign. The report additionally includes results from an immunoperioxidase identification, which confirmed a positive estrogen receptor (90%) and negative progesterone receptor (not identified) status. The HER-2/neu results were negative (score 1+).

Diagnosis: Endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the uterus (corpus, fundus and lower uterine segment) with myometrial invasion (0.5 cm) and a tumor size of 7.7 cm. Histological grade: Grade 1 (well-differentiated). No lymphovascular invasion identified. Leiomyoma (0.7 cm) present. Cervix with Nabothian cysts and ovaries with epithelial inclusion cysts. No evidence of malignancy in pelvic lymph nodes. Soft tissue pelvic nodule identified as fat necrosis with dystrophic calcification. Pathological stage: pT1b, pNO.

Specimens received were Left upper lobe wedge resection, Left upper lobectomy, Level 10 and Level 5. The pre-operative diagnosis was squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx. Intraoperative consultation diagnosis of Left upper lobe wedge resection showed Non-small cell carcinoma (favor squamous cell. carcinoma). Grossly, Left upper lobe wedge resection measured 8.0 X 5.0 x 3.0 cm with a partly anthracotic hemorrhagic firm mass measuring 1.5 x1.0x 1.0. Left upper lobectomy shows congestion with no identifiable tumor focus. Moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma was detected in Left upper lobe wedge resection. The size of the tumor was 1.5 X 1.0 cm with congestion and focal emphysematous change. The Left upper lobectomy shows congestion, focal emphysematous change, five peribronchial lymph nodes negative for tumor (0/5), bronchial margins of resection were negative for tumor, negative for residual carcinoma. Level 10 lymph node showed three lymph nodes negative for tumor (0/3). Level 5 lymph node showed one lymph node negative for tumor (0/1). Immunostain for TTF1 (A3) is negative. It is difficult to say for sure if the current lung lesion is a primary or metastatic tumor. All tests were developed and their performance characteristics were determined by the Department of Pathology.

The pathology report describes a case of metastatic poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the lung, with lymph node involvement and angiolymphatic invasion. The tumor has invaded the bronchial margin, but not the pleural tissue. The AJCC stage is T1N2MX, stage IIA. The report also mentions a history of breast carcinoma, which is excluded in this report. The report includes macroscopic and microscopic descriptions of specimens, including lymph nodes and lung tissue. The lung tissue contains an infiltrating tumor composed of neoplastic cells with pleomorphic and hyperchromatic nuclei. The tumor has a mild response, is poorly differentiated, and may favor an adenocarcinoma diagnosis. A lymph node bordering the suspected lymph node is also identified with metastasis. The report notes the absence of acid-fast and fungal stains in non-caseating granulomata.

This pathology report pertains to a sample of tissue labeled as "tumour" or "buffy," with a diagnosis of adenocarcinoma. The patient's age and the year of diagnosis are not specified. The tumor is located in the right upper lobe of the lung. The histological grade, pathological stage, and clinical stage are provided as I, T2,N0,M0. The tumor size is reported as 2.50 cm. A link to a slide image of the tissue is also provided.

The pathology report describes the specimens received from a post-menopausal woman with abnormal screening mammogram and bilateral breast neoplasia. The report reveals the presence of metastatic carcinoma in the sentinel lymph nodes of both axillae, invasion of lobular and ductal carcinoma in the left and right breast, respectively, and numerous lymph nodes. Surgical resection margins were negative for tumor, and biomarkers were ordered to investigate the breast tumors' characteristics further. The report emphasizes the tumor size, grade, and localization and provides additional details on the surgical procedures and tissue preparation.

Filtered report: The pathology report indicates a rectosigmoidal junction adenocarcinoma of histopathological differentiation grade G2 to 3. The tumor has ulceration and peritumorous chronic recurrent secondary inflammation with an acute inflammatory flare. Carcinomatous lymphangitis and regional lymph node metastasis (1/14) are present, but there are tumor-free overview slices from all other resection material portions described. The tumor stage is pT3, pN1 (1/14), MX, L1, R0, and the tumor classification code is ICDO-DA M8140/3, G2 to 3.

The patient underwent a left parietal excision biopsy for a tumor, which was identified as gliosarcoma (WHO grade IV) upon examination. MGMT promoter methylation analysis was negative for the presence of methylated MGMT promoter sequences. There were areas of pleomorphic atypical cells, spindle cells in streaming fascicles, and whorl formation. Focal and geographic necrosis was also present. The tumor was positive for vimentin, GFAP, and pan-cytokeratin (CK), but negative for CK7, CK20, TTF1, and HMB45. Mitotic figures were frequent.

Diagnosis: Papillary carcinoma, oncocytic variant, 1.4 cm, right lobe of thyroid. The tumor is unifocal and located in the right lobe, with a size of 1.4 cm x 1.3 cm x 1.2 cm. Margins are uninvolved, and the tumor is totally encapsulated with minimal invasion of the tumor capsule. No lymph-vascular or perineural invasion is identified, and there is no extrathyroidal extension. Pathologic staging is pT1b. No additional pathologic findings are identified.

Summary: The pathology report is for a male patient with mesothelioma who underwent left thoracotomy, pleurectomy, PDT, and bronchoscopy. Multiple lymph nodes were examined, and metastatic mesothelioma was found in several of them. Additionally, biphasic malignant mesothelioma was found in the pleura and pericardial mass. Immunostains confirmed the diagnosis. The report provides detailed information on the location and size of the specimens submitted for analysis. The final pathologic staging was pT3N2Mx.

Diagnosis: Carcinosarcoma with serous carcinoma and homologous sarcomatous components involving the anterior and posterior endometrium and lower uterine segment, with myometrial invasion and cervical involvement. Lymphovascular space invasion present. One pelvic lymph node positive for metastatic serous carcinoma. Mild acute and chronic cervicitis, Nabothian cysts, tubal metaplasia, peri-neural invasion, atrophic endometrium with chronic endometritis, and vessels with medial calcification also observed. AJCC Pathologic Stage: pT2pN1. Immunohistochemistry stains pending on sarcomatous component, but previous biopsy results consistent with the same diagnosis.

Pathology report of a biopsy of the right temporal lobe shows the presence of an anaplastic glioma with a mix of astrocytoma and oligodendroglioma. Frozen section diagnosis confirmed glioma. The specimen shows multiple fragments of friable brain tissue with scattered calcification. Mitotic figures and vascular proliferation are present, more frequent in the astrocytoma component. The MIB-1 labeling index is about 15%. Tumor necrosis is not seen in the sections.

The pathology report pertains to a lobectomy of the right middle lobe lung which reveals invasive adenocarcinoma with visceral pleura invasion but no involvement of the bronchial margin. Lymph nodes from different regions were biopsied and some were found to have metastatic carcinoma while others had no tumor found. The synoptic worksheet provides further information on tumor size and type, as well as the involvement of lymph nodes. The gross description notes the presence of a grey firm tumor measuring 4.5x4x3.4 cm, and the specimen received includes labeled samples of lung tissue, lymph nodes, and fat. Frozen section results confirmed no tumor in the bronchial margin.

A right radical nephrectomy was performed due to a 5.0 x 3.6 x 4.0 cm well-circumscribed yellow to grayish-brown tumor mass with foci of hemorrhage and cyst formation located in the upper pole of the kidney. The mass was identified as a clear cell carcinoma with some papillary features. The tumor was confined to the kidney and was well demarcated from the adjacent unaffected renal tissue. No renal vein invasion or adrenal gland involvement was identified, and the margins were not involved. The final diagnosis is renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type with calcification and foci of papillary change, confined to the kidney. The nuclear grade is II.

The pathology report describes a case of papillary thyroid carcinoma with lymph node metastasis. The report indicates the presence of a unifocal tumor measuring 8.2 cm in the greatest dimension. The tumor is identified as a classical type papillary carcinoma with well-differentiated histological grade. The margins are uninvolved by the carcinoma, but there is presence of tumor capsular invasion and extrathyroidal extension. Pathological staging identifies pT3 and pN1B stages, with 40 of 77 examined lymph nodes involved in the carcinoma. The report also notes soft tissue extensions of the carcinoma, identified in the right paratracheal neck, left paratracheal neck, and right neck radial dissection. The report concludes that the patient has papillary thyroid cancer with metastatic spread to lymph nodes in various locations.

Specimen A is an adrenalectomy measuring 14 x 11.5 x 4 cm and weighing 175 grams, containing a tumor mass measuring 5.5 x 5 x 2.5 cm. The adrenal gland appears normal. A periaortic lymph node measuring 0.7 x 0.6 x 0.5 cm is also present. Chromogranin A and synaptophysin stains are positive, while inhibin-alpha and S-100 stains are negative, suggesting a pheochromocytoma. Capsular invasion and extension into peri-adrenal adipose tissue are also noted. A lymph node is negative for tumor. Although the histomorphologic score suggests a benign clinical behavior, clinical and radiologic correlation is necessary to exclude malignancy.

Report Summary: The histopathological examination of a multiple organ resection procedure on a female patient showed a 27 cm length of large intestine with periintestinal fat tissue sized 24 X 5 x 4 cm and an ulcerous tumor sized 1.8 x. 1.5 x 0.7 cm in the mucosa. The microscopic examination revealed Mucinous adenocarcinoma with infiltration of the muscular layer of the colon and pericolonic adipose tissue. The lymph nodes were reactive and free of neoplastic lesions. The final diagnosis was Mucinous adenocarcinoma of the colon (pT3, pNO).

The pathology report indicates the presence of an ulcerated, poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the stomach, diffuse type. The tumor has invaded into the subserosa, but lymphatic and venous invasion are not specified. Ten examined lymph nodes from the greater and lesser curvatures demonstrate reactive hyperplasia and lipomatosis, and there is no evidence of metastasis. Margins are uninvolved and there is no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment.

The histopathology report describes six specimens received, including a fragment of tissue and multiple lymph nodes. The report confirms the frozen section diagnosis of no evidence of malignancy but also identifies a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma forming a polypoid endobronchial mass and invading adjacent lung and hilar fibroadipose tissue. The tumour is well clear of the bronchial resection margin but close to the hilar soft tissue margin. There is perineural permeation present, no blood vessel or lymphatic invasion identified, and evidence of obstructive pneumonitis with mild bronchiectasis. Peribronchial lymph nodes within the region of the tumour show metastases, while lymph nodes elsewhere show reactive changes only. Non-neoplastic lung findings include emphysema and mild respiratory bronchiolitis. A supplementary report notes that no microorganisms are identified within lymph node granulomata and that further examination confirms the tumour to be confined to the bronchus in the sectioned area with no involvement of the hilar margin. The final diagnosis is T3N1 squamous cell carcinoma.

Pathology report summary:
- Right breast needle-localized segmental mastectomy: invasive ductal carcinoma with central sclerosis, intermediate.
- Nuclear grade, Nottingham histologic grade 2. Invasive carcinoma measures 1.8 cm in largest dimension.
- Lymphovascular invasion present. Metastatic carcinoma in one of twelve axillary lymph nodes.
- Focal adjacent atypical ductal hyperplasia, atypical lobular hyperplasia, columnar cell change present.
- Tumor did not approach final surgical margins.
- Tumor marker studies previously reported.
- Various tissue samples were taken and examined.
- Clinical history is right breast cancer.

The report describes the results of a left orchidectomy that was performed on a patient. The sample size, shape, weight, reference, treatment plan, patient name, doctor name, and hospital name have been omitted. The report shows that the patient had a seminoma with a diameter of 4 cm. The tumor was confined to the testis in the available slides, and angio-invasion was present. However, there was no invasion observed in the rete testis. The report was prepared by a pathologist on the date of the orchidectomy.

Clinical history: The patient has a right thyroid nodule with two FNA tests, which shows atypical cells and suspicious for neoplasm respectively. One specimen is submitted for testing. 

Diagnosis: The specimen is a well-circumscribed nodule, consisting of papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, with oncocytic features. The tumor size is 3 cm, and it is located in the right lobe, encapsulated, not invading the capsule or extrathyroid tissues but with two foci of blood vessel invasion. The surgical margins are free of the tumor, and the tumor is not multicentric. Additionally, the non-neoplastic thyroid tissue exhibits nodular hyperplasia. 

Gross description: The specimen weighing 15 g is a thyroid lobe measuring 5 x 3.5 x 2 cm and an isthmus measuring 1.5 x 0.5 x 0.5 with a well-circumscribed, thinly encapsulated, tan nodule dimension of 3 x 2.7 x 2 cm. 

Intraoperative consultation: The frozen section diagnosis shows a Hurthle cell neoplasm, which is different from the permanent diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, with oncocytic features.

The report describes the gross and microscopic examination of tissue samples from a patient with endometrial cancer. The uterus and cervix have a large papilliferous lesion occupying the entire endometrial canal, with extensive myometrial invasion. The cervical surgical margin is not unequivocally involved but malignancy extends to within <0.1 cm of the posterior cervical inked and cauterized margin. No other organ involvement or lymphovascular space invasion is identified. Lymph node excisions show reactive hyperplasia without metastatic carcinoma, with a total of 25 nodes received. The malignancy is determined to be an endometrioid carcinoma of grade III histologic grade with no convincing papillary serous component identified. No prior biopsy material for comparison is identified.

Histologic diagnosis: High grade muscle invasive urothelial cell carcinoma covering most of the bladder wall. T3aG3 NO M0. 

Anatomic site and laterality: Bladder wall NOS. 

Tumor size: 5.5cm diameter. 

Lymph node status: A total of 18 lymph nodes all without tumor localization.

The pathology report describes four specimens received from a patient with a left upper lobe bronchial cancer. The largest specimen contains a tumour mass invading visceral and parietal pleura and measures 91mm in maximum diameter. The tumour is moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with extensive necrosis and acinar and papillary patterns. The report also mentions the absence of metastatic adenocarcinoma in the lymph nodes submitted, except for focal involvement of hilar soft tissue margin, resulting in R1 residual tumour status. Adjacent non-neoplastic lung tissue shows lipoid pneumonia, pulmonary oedema, and moderate emphysematous change. The pathological stage is pT3N0.

The pathology report is for a total thyroidectomy and right central neck lymph nodes received for surgical pathology. The diagnosis for the total thyroidectomy shows two foci of papillary thyroid carcinoma in the right lobe, one focus in the left lobe, and chronic thyroiditis. The diagnosis for the right central neck lymph nodes is that four lymph nodes are negative for malignancy, with benign thymic tissue and parathyroid tissue. The tumor foci are multifocal bilateral, with the dominant tumor located in the right lobe, and the greatest dimension is 1.6 cm. The margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, and no lymphovascular invasion is identified. The pathologic stage is pT3 NO MX. The exact operative procedures and clinical stage are not included in the report. The case is reviewed by a pathologist.

Specimens submitted:
1. Radical hysterectomy: uterus, cervix, bilateral tubes, and ovaries 
2. Right pelvic lymph node
3. Right obturator lymph node 
4. Right hypogastric lymph nodes 
5. Left obturator lymph node 
6. Left external iliac lymph node 

Diagnosis: 
1. Radical hysterectomy: 
- Invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma detected, measuring 3.7 x 3.4 x 3.2 cm
- Tumor invades cervical stroma to a depth of 19 mm in an area that measures 20 mm in dimension 
- Tumor is present within 1.0 mm of anterior and posterior soft tissue margins 
- Cin III detected
- Suspicious foci for lymphovascular invasion detected 
- Perineural invasion is absent 
- Uterine corpus extension is absent 
- All margins are negative for invasive carcinoma 
- Weakly proliferative endometrium and unremarkable myometrium detected 
- Bilateral ovaries present with stromal hyperplasia 
- Benign bilateral fallopian tubes 
- Eight parametrial lymph nodes negative for tumor (0/8) 

2. Right pelvic lymph node: one benign lymph node negative for tumor (0/1) 
3. Right obturator lymph node: one benign lymph node negative for tumor (0/1) 
4. Right hypogastric lymph nodes: two benign lymph nodes negative for tumor (0/2) 
5. Left obturator lymph node: one benign lymph node negative for tumor (0/1) 
6. Left external iliac lymph node: four benign lymph nodes negative for tumor (0/2) 

The consensus conference concluded that the left parametrium is not involved by carcinoma.

Specimen: Left kidney with moderate perirenal adipose tissue and a yellow-orange adrenal gland.
Gross description: 5x5x4.5 cm tumor mass confined by renal capsule and several adjacent serous fluid-filled cysts.
Microscopic description: Mixed papillary renal cell carcinoma and clear cell renal cell carcinoma with a grade II histologic type. CK7, EMA, RCC, and PAX2 immunohistochemical stains confirm the presence of two tumor types. Chronic interstitial inflammation and benign cysts are also present in non-neoplastic kidney tissues.
Diagnosis: Renal cell carcinoma, mixed clear cell and papillary type with Fuhrman nuclear grade 2. Tumor size 5 cm with no extension beyond kidney identified (pT1b). Negative margins for tumor. Adrenal gland negative for tumor.

Summary: The report describes a total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy performed on a patient with endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type with villoglandular features, FIGO grade 2. The tumor forms a polypoid mass that invades 1.3 cm into the myometrium. No lymphovascular invasion is observed, and the cervix is uninvolved. The bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes are without diagnostic abnormality. Multiple lymph node excisions are performed, and all nodes are negative for tumor. The excised left and right gonadal vessels are negative for tumor.

The pathology report indicates the presence of papillary thyroid carcinoma in a total thyroidectomy specimen, with two foci of the tumor measuring 1.2 cm and 0.5 cm and extrathyroidal extension. Chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis is also present. The report notes metastatic carcinoma in two out of six examined lymph nodes, without extranodal extension. The primary tumor is categorized as pT3a N1 with a margin uninvolved by carcinoma and lymph-vascular invasion present. No information is provided regarding the patient's medical history or the clinical question prompting this diagnosis.

The pathology report describes a specimen from a right hemicolectomy, which includes the terminal ileum, cecum, appendix, and ascending colon. A moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the ascending colon has been identified, measuring 4.5 cm in greatest dimension and extending through the bowel wall into the subserosal fat, with presence of lymph-vascular invasion. Three discontinuous tumor deposits in subserosal tissue and metastatic adenocarcinoma in 4 of 33 subserosal lymph nodes have been observed. The surgical margins of resection are free of tumor with the closest surgical margin radial distance measuring 5 cm. The histologic grade is low-grade, and perineural invasion is not identified. The tumor penetrates to the surface of the visceral peritoneum, and there is one grossly enlarged subserosal lymph node containing hard white tissue with central necrosis. A fine needle aspirate cytology of the liver is consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma of colonic primary origin, and a CT-guided needle biopsy of the liver also shows metastatic adenocarcinoma consistent with colonic primary.

Final Pathologic Diagnosis: Invasive lobular carcinoma, SBR grade II, with associated lobular carcinoma in situ, classic type, and metastatic carcinoma in 13/15 lymph nodes. ER-positive (80%), PR-negative, and non-amplified HER2. The excisional biopsy margins are widely (>1cm) free of tumor, and blood vessel and lymphatic invasion are absent. Nipple and skin are unremarkable. The pTNM (AJCC, 7th edition, 2010) staging is pT3, N3, MX. The patient is a female with breast cancer undergoing left breast modified radical mastectomy. The tumor exhibits 20% cellularity and extensive hyalinization. The specimen consists of a modified radical mastectomy with a 8.5 X 6.5 X 4.2 cm mass in slices 5-13 and metastatic lymph nodes from 0.6 X 0.4 X 0.4-2 X 0.9 x 0.5 cm in greatest dimension. Block summary is provided.

The pathology report describes specimens submitted for examination, which include various nodes, tissues, and organs identified by numbers. The diagnosis reveals various levels of metastatic high-grade serous carcinoma involving different areas throughout the body, including lymph nodes, small and large bowels, liver surface, gallbladder, umbilicus, and soft tissues. Some benign tissues were also identified in several areas. One lymph node specimen was lost during processing.
