The report concludes with a statement from the examiner attesting to the diagnosis and personal examination of the slides/materials.

Specimens were submitted from various areas for testing. The report shows that in the right para-aortic lymph nodes, one out of four lymph nodes had metastatic adenocarcinoma. The uterus, cervix, fallopian tubes, and ovaries showed endometrioid adenocarcinoma with architectural grade II, nuclear grade 2, and PIGO grade 2. The myometrial invasion measured 9mm, and myometrium thickness was 26mm in the area of maximal tumor invasion. Complex hyperplasia with atypia was seen in the endometrium, with multiple leiomyomata present in the myometrium. Benign ovaries and fallopian tubes were found. One benign lymph node was found in each of the sentinel lymph nodes taken from the left and right external iliac regions. The subaortic lymph nodes and left para-aortic lymph nodes also showed benign results. However, the left uterosacral nodule and rectoserosal nodule had metastatic adenocarcinoma. The rectoserosal nodule #2 contained benign fibroadipose tissue with focal calcification. Additional H/E stained sections and immunohistochemical stains showed no evidence of metastatic tumor in the sentinel lymph nodes on the right and left external iliac regions. Furthermore, the immunohistochemical staining for the tested DNA mismatch repair proteins is retained in the tumor.

The pathology report is for a total thyroidectomy specimen from a patient with a pre-operative diagnosis of multinodular goiter. The report confirms the presence of a papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, measuring 5cm, in the right lobe of the thyroid gland. The surgical resection margins are negative for tumor, and only one lymph node was examined and found negative for metastases. The left lobe of the thyroid gland has squamous metaplasia, and the parathyroid gland has no specific pathologic changes. The specimen is grossly described as an intact total thyroidectomy specimen with serially sectioned lobes and an inked anterior and posterior aspect. The report also includes synoptic information and a note confirming the diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, variant 8260/3, follicular variant, with no vascular invasion or additional pathologic findings identified. The final diagnosis is pT 3 N 0 M x based on AJCC Cancer Staging Manual, 7th edition.

MR#: ACCT#: LOC: DOCTOR: ADDENDUM NEUROPATHOLOGY REPORT. ADDENDUM DISCUSSION: The neoplastic cells express IDH1 but are negative for p53. Numerous MIB-1 reactive cells are present with a labeling index of 12.48. ADDENDUM DIAGNOSIS: 1-3. Right parietal tumor, including enhancing nodule, biopsy resection: Anaplastic astrocytoma (grade III) -- MIB-1 LI - 12.4%. ADDENDUM CPT codes: ACCESSION#: NEUROPATHOLOGY REPORT. SPECIMEN SOURCE: 1. Right parietal tumor FS. 2. Enhancing nodule FS. 3. Right parietal tumor perm. CLINICAL DIAGNOSIS: Brain tumor. GROSS DESCRIPTION: 1. Received fresh for frozen section, labeled with the patient's name and "right parietal tumor," is an irregular portion of tan-white and hemorrhagic soft tissue measuring 1.5 x 1.5 x 0.5 cm. A smear is performed and the entire specimen is frozen as F1A. Frozen section diagnosis: Infiltrating glioma, favor high grade. The tissue block is subsequently submitted for permanent sectioning. DATE COLLECTED: PAGE: 1. DATE RECEIVED: CONTINUED. ANATOMIC PATHOLOGY REPORT. MR#: ACCT#: LOC: DOCTOR: NEUROPATHOLOGY REPORT. GROSS DESCRIPTION: 2. Received fresh for frozen section, labeled with the patient's name and "enhancing nodule," is a polypoid portion of tan-orange soft tissue measuring 0.7 x 0.5 x 0.5 cm. A smear is performed, and the entire specimen is frozen as F2A. Frozen section diagnosis: High-grade glioma. The tissue block is subsequently submitted for permanent sectioning. 3. Received in formalin, labeled with the patient's name and "right parietal tumor perm," are multiple irregular fragments of tan-white to red soft tissue measuring in aggregate to 3.0 x 2.0 x 0.6 cm. The entire specimen is submitted in cassettes 3A to 3B. MICROSCOPIC DESCRIPTION: 1-3. Sections demonstrate a diffusely infiltrative astrocytic neoplasm. Atypia ranges from mild to marked. Cellularity has a similar range. Most of the tumor cells resemble fibrillary or gemistocytic astrocytes. Some cells lack obvious processes, and there is a suggestion of perinuclear halos, but the overall phenotype of the tumor appears to be astrocytoma. Microvascular proliferation and necrosis are not seen. Unfortunately, specimens one and two are the most cellular. These demonstrate only an occasional mitosis, and the frozen section artifact makes identification difficult. DIAGNOSIS: (Provisional) 1-3. Right parietal tumor, including enhancing nodule, biopsy, and resection: Consistent with anaplastic astrocytoma, pending additional studies. CPT. CPT. DATE COLLECTED: PAGE: 2. DATE RECEIVED: - END OF REPORT -.

Diagnosis: Right parietal brain tumor. Oligoastrocyoma, grade Il. Microscopic Description: Diffusely infiltrating glioma with proliferation of cells demonstrating mild to moderate cytologic atypia and occasional foci of microcystic change. No necrosis or microvascular proliferation seen. Consistent with low grade oligoastrocytoma. Final diagnosis pending review of special stains.

The pathology report describes the diagnosis of a patient who underwent surgery for left lobe hepatocellular carcinoma. The tumor nodules range from 0.5 cm to 3.5 cm in diameter and comprise approximately 50% of the specimen volume. Necrosis is present, and venous invasion is extensively present in both large portal vein branches and extensive microscopic intravascular tumor foci throughout the specimen. The surgical margins are positive, with hepatocellular carcinoma present in multiple portal vein branches. The report suggests that there is no evidence of cirrhosis, moderate fibrosis, and moderate mixed micro and macro steatosis. The gallbladder is diagnosed with chronic cholecystitis with cholelithiasis, and a portal lymph node excision shows no tumor present. A comprehensive review of all available information is recommended to determine the final staging.

The pathology report describes a Whipple procedure specimen comprised of stomach, duodenum, and pancreatic head. The pancreas displays characteristics of chronic pancreatitis along with the presence of a large mucinous mass, approximately 5.5cm, mostly cystic with some solid papillary areas, encapsulated within the pancreatic duct. Invasive ductal adenocarcinoma, poorly to moderately differentiated, and arising in IPMN with low to high-grade dysplasia, present. Multifocal perineural invasion and angiolymphatic invasion is seen with cauterized tumor present close to the pancreatic neck margin of excision and perineural/angiolymphatic invasion. The report also describes the involvement of the portal vein muscular media, common bile duct adventitia, and duodenal mucosa by the tumor, positive metastasis in regional lymph nodes, and uninvolved margins.

Final Diagnosis: Left breast tissue excisional biopsy reveals infiltrating ductal carcinoma, poorly differentiated (Nottingham grade III/III, Nottingham score 8/9). Tumor size measures 3.1 cm with no necrosis, microcalcifications, or lymphovascular invasion. Margins are negative, and less than 25% intraductal component with prominent cancerization is present. Two lymph nodes, one sentinel, and one with the breast biopsy, are negative for malignancy. Estrogen receptors are positive, progesterone receptors are negative, and HER 2 neu is positive. Pathologic stage is pT2 NO MX, and AJCC stage in the absence of metastases is IIA.

Filtered report:

Malignant melanoma of skin tissue was identified in a surgically resected tumor measuring 3 x 3 x 1 cm. The tumor was ulcerated and pigmented and had poorly differentiated malignant melanoma cells. One out of ten right inguinal lymph nodes was positive for metastasis. Breslow depth was 10mm. No other significant pathologic findings were reported.

The report describes a left upper lobectomy specimen labeled incorrectly as right upper lobe. The specimen displays a moderately to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with extensive central necrosis and invasion of the pleura and vascular invasion but not of the overlying chest wall fat. The soft tissue resection margins are clear of malignancy, and no lymphatic or perineural invasion is found. No lymph metastases are evident, and the bronchial resection margin shows no evidence of squamous metaplasia or dysplasia. The pathological stage is T2 NO. The distant lung parenchyma shows emphysema, while lung parenchyma adjacent to the tumor displays obstructive pneumonitis.

The pathology report describes the findings of a ventral and dorsal surface of the tongue, not otherwise specified (NOS), subtotal glossectomy with left level 1 neck dissection. The report indicates the presence of an invasive moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma, 5.2 cm in size, of the tongue, with no perineural invasion and negative surgical margins. Additionally, the report states that no malignancy was seen in various lymph nodes, nerves, arteries, muscles, and other tissues. The histological type of the tumor is squamous cell carcinoma, conventional, with a histologic grade of G2 (moderately differentiated). The tumor is staged as PT3 (tumor more than 4 cm in greatest dimension) with no regional lymph node metastasis (pNO). The report includes descriptions of the size, shape, and orientation of the specimen, as well as the number of lymph nodes examined and involved. Finally, the report describes the processing and examination of various tissue samples, including lymph nodes, nerves, and muscles.

Pathological diagnosis:

A. Brain, right frontal, excisional biopsies: Glioma with atypical features.
B. Brain, right frontal, excision: Mixed oligoastrocytoma, anaplastic. MIB-1 proliferation index 38.

Gross pathology:
Received fresh, three fragments, 1.5 cm across in aggregate. Soft, mucinous, grayish-pink. #1-5.

Comment:
In part A, there is a glial neoplastic proliferation, probably mixed oligoastrocytic but predominantly astrocytic, that has undergone focal anaplastic transformation (WHO grade III). Microvascular proliferation and mitoses in the WHO classifications of astrocytomas merit a grade IV category.

In part B, there are focal areas of a similar neoplasia with zones of tumor necrosis and microvascular cellular proliferation. 

Immunohistochemistry:
GFAP demonstrates sparse gliofibrilogenesis by neoplastic cells. CD34 depicts the rich vascularity within the neoplasm. About 5% of cells over-express the p53 antigen. With the MIB-1, a proliferation index of 3% is determined in the more cellular areas.

Tissue committee code: ICD9: 191.

The pathology report describes two specimens received labeled "omentum" and "terminal ileum, cecum, appendix and omentum", both with a diagnosis of metastatic poorly differentiated serous carcinoma, FIGO grade 3, with lymphatic space invasion. The omentum specimen consists of a 17 x 9 X 1.5 cm firm rubbery piece of tan to pink tissue consistent with omental cake. No normal omental fat is present. The terminal ileum, cecum, appendix, and omentum specimen is a right colon and portion of omentum with a yellow lobular cut surface showing possible tumor present, and tumor makes up approximately 40% of the specimen grossly. Additionally, the specimen shows a portion of small bowel which is 30 cm, and the mucosa of the specimen shows pink-tan smooth glistening mucosa. The appendix is identified adherent to the fat measuring 5 X 0.3 cm and is studded with tumor nodules. The diagnosis recommends clinical correlation in regard to any further distant metastases that have not been sampled at the time of the procedure.

The pathology report pertains to a left radical nephrectomy, which was performed due to renal cell carcinoma - conventional (clear cell) type. The tumor size was 12.0 cm, and it involved the renal sinus fal and penetrated through the renal capsule into perirenal fat. Surgical margins were free of tumor, and the non-neoplastic kidney showed mild interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy. The adrenal gland was not involved, and no lymph nodes were identified in the perinephric fat. Lymph nodes from para-aortic, suprahilar, and interaortacaval regions were negative for neoplastic involvement. The report contains gross descriptions, special stains, and a summary of sections for each specimen submitted.

Examination: Histopathological examination of a multiple organ resection including the caecum and right half of colon with distal part of ileum. Clinical diagnosis: Cancer of the caecum and right half of colon with distal part of ileum. Macroscopic description: A 30 cm length of the large intestine with a fragment of mesentery, a 9 cm segment of the small intestine, and an appendix, with a cauliflower-shaped, ulcerous tumor in the mucosa measuring 4.5 x 4 x 1 cm. The lesion surrounds 100% of the intestine circumference, located 12 cm from proximal cut line and 20 cm from distal cut line, and invades periintestinal tissue. Minimum side margin is 4 cm. Microscopic description: Adenocarcinoma tubulare (G2) with infiltratio carcinomatosa tunicae muscularis priopriae. Lymphonodulitis reactiva No XV. Examination result: Adenocarcinoma tubulare coli. Tubularadenocarcinoma of the colon (G2, Dukes A, Astler-Coller B1, pT2, pNO). Histopathological diagnosis: Mucocellular and partially tubular and mucinous invasive adenocarcinoma of the stomach with cancer metastases of the lymph nodes (No. XVII/XX, pN3).

The pathology report describes a left breast mastectomy with axillary lymph node sampling. The tumor is located in the upper outer quadrant, with a size of 2.8 cm in the greatest dimension and invasive ductal carcinoma histologic type. There is no duct in situ component or microcalcifications identified. The tumor has invaded up to 6 out of 23 axillary lymph nodes tested, with margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma and a distance of 1.0 cm to the nearest margin. Venous/lymphatic invasion is present. The pathologic stage is pT2N2aMXG3, with pending immunohistochemical stains for estrogen and progesterone receptors and HER2.

The pathology report describes a pancreaticoduodenectomy specimen received, which includes duodenum, pancreas, and peripancreatic fat. The duodenum shows dusky brown mucosa in the distal one-third of the specimen, a granular, red-tan lesion adjacent to the ampullae, and several punctate hemorrhages. The common bile duct and the main pancreatic ducts have two separate ampullae. The pancreas shows an ill-defined, indurated, yellow-white mass that focally abuts the black-inked radial margin and grossly extends into the peripancreatic fat, 0.6 cm from the pancreatic neck margin and 0.5 cm from the ampulla. Invasive pancreatic adenocarcinoma, grade 3 of 4, with a maximum dimension of 3.8 cm is diagnosed. Surgical margins, including superior mesenteric artery margin, portal vein groove, and deep radial margins are negative for malignancy (tumor extends to 0.2 cm from portal vein groove). Metastatic adenocarcinoma is present in one of twelve lymph nodes. The overall stage is pT3 N1 Mx.

Stomach cancer (poorly differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma, invasive to surrounding tissue with lymphatic and perineural invasion, and metastasis to lymph nodes) was detected in a total gastrectomy sample. Surgical margins were free of cancer. The spleen had fibrous nodules but was uninvolved by cancer, and the gallbladder had chronic inflammation but was cancer-free. The esophageal margin was free of cancer.

The pathology report describes the results of biopsies taken from multiple lymph nodes, a partial omentectomy, and a total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. The lymph nodes were negative for metastatic carcinoma, as was the omentum. However, the uterine corpus had uterine serous carcinoma involving the endometrium and endometrial polyp with invasion into polyp stroma, along with cervical stromal involvement by the serous adenocarcinoma. Myometrial invasion was not identified, and there were no metastases found in the regional lymph nodes. The gross description describes the physical characteristics of the specimens received, including the size and appearance of the lymph nodes, the absence of abnormalities in the fallopian tubes, ovaries, and omentum, and the presence of a fibroid on the anterior uterine wall.

The report pertains to a patient who had a left renal mass and underwent a partial nephrectomy. The tumor is identified as conventional (clear cell) type renal cell carcinoma with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of II/IV. The greatest diameter of the tumor is 4.2 cm, and there is no local invasion or renal vein invasion identified. The surgical margins are free of tumor, and the non-neoplastic kidney is unremarkable. The adrenal gland and lymph nodes are not identified. The staging for renal cell carcinoma/oncocytoma is pT1, indicating a tumor size of <=7.0 cm in greatest dimension limited to the kidney. Frozen section diagnosis shows renal cortical carcinoma, and the margin at the deep aspect is benign. The report includes details about the size, shape, and sections of the specimen without mentioning patient, doctor or hospital names, or any treatment plans.

Diagnosis: Adenocarcinoma of the prostate with 85% involvement. Gleason score of 8/10 (primary pattern: 4/5, secondary pattern: 4/5). Lymphovascular space invasion and high-grade PIN are present. Adenocarcinoma present at the inked margin of the base of the prostate gland. Bilateral pelvic lymph nodes examined, with one lymph node containing metastatic carcinoma measuring less than 0.1 cm confined to the subcapsular sinus. pTNM Stage: pT2c, N1, MX. Two specimens received: A) 51.3 g prostate gland with attached bilateral adnexa, B) aggregate of yellow-tan lobulated fibroadipose tissue containing multiple lymph nodes, which are entirely submitted for examination.

val.report: Diagnosis: Prostate cancer (prostatic adenocarcinoma) with tumor grade 7 (3+4), involving about 5% of the prostate. Histologic assessment shows focal glandular atrophy and benign prostatic hypertrophy. The tumor is confined within the prostate capsule and no invasion of the muscular wall of the seminal vesicles is identified. Surgical margins are focally positive <1mm in right apex (A1, A13) and apical/mid right prostate. AJCC staging is pT2C. Lymph nodes were not submitted. The specimen received for robotic-assisted laparoscopic prostatectomy measures 4.2 x 4.0 x 3.5 cm and weighs 37 grams. The right seminal vesicle measures 4.5 x 2.1 x 0.5 cm, the right vas deferens measures 2.6 x 0.4 x 0.3 cm, the left seminal vesicle measures 3.7 x 2.2 x 0.5 cm, and the left vas deferens measures 2.9 x 0.7 x 0.2 cm. The prostate consists of tan/white fibrous tissue with yellowish discoloration in focal areas throughout the prostate. A total of 26 blocks were obtained of the right and left prostates, right and left seminal vesicles, right and left vas deferens margins, and bladder neck margins.

A total nephrectomy of the left kidney was performed due to a renal cell carcinoma - conventional (clear cell) type with focal sercomatoid features of nuclear grade IV/IV. The tumor measured 5.6 cm in diameter and showed no local invasion or renal vein invasion. The surgical margins were free of tumor, and non-neoplastic kidney tissue showed benign cortical cysts, papillary edenomas, and mild arteriosclerotic changes. The adrenal gland and lymph nodes were not identified. The perinephric fat showed benign fibroadipose tissue. Intraoperative consultation confirmed the diagnosis of renal cortical carcinoma, which was confirmed by permanent sections.
Summary: The whole slide image is of a brain tumor diagnosed as Diffuse Astrocytoma of Grade II with moderate nuclear polymorphism and Ki-67 focally up to 7%.

The pathology report describes a case of papillary thyroid carcinoma with secondary cystic changes. The total thyroidectomy specimen reveals a low-grade tumor with a size of 3.5 x 3.0 x 2.5 cm located in the left lobe. A microscopic focus of papillary carcinoma with a diameter of 2 mm is present in the right lobe. There is no capsular or lymphovascular invasion, but microscopic subcapsular foci of metastatic papillary carcinoma are present in small perithyroidal lymph nodes (4/4). Additionally, lymph node (1/1) with cystic metastasis of papillary carcinoma is found in the excised parathyroid. The report complies with the guidelines of the College of American Pathologists and the Association of Directors of Anatomic and Surgical Pathology for the reporting of cancer specimens.

The pathology report describes a biopsy of a primary invasive carcinoma of the breast in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. The tumor size is 1.3 cm in the greatest dimension, with no definite lymphatic invasion. The tumor is diagnosed as ductal adenocarcinoma, with a Nottingham score of 9/9 and a grade of 3/3. There is no involvement of surgical margins or lymph nodes. The report also notes fibrocystic changes, columnar cell change, and pseudoangiomatous stromal hyperplasia. No information is available regarding estrogen receptors, progesterone receptors, or HER2/neu.

Specimen includes thymoma (A), superior mediastinal lymph node (B), and left sided thymus tissue (C). Final diagnosis indicates thymic epithelial neoplasm with features of both thymic carcinoma and thymoma, with tumor invading the capsule, measuring 5.5 x 3.5 x 2.2 cm. No neoplasm detected in the excised lymph node or left sided thymus. Immunohistochemical stain performed and the tumor cells are strongly positive for CD5. Gross description indicates well circumscribed tan mass with cystic areas and yellow fluid in the thymoma tissue. Representative sections submitted in multiple cassettes. Margins are negative according to intraoperative consult diagnosis.

Clinical history: Patient with right occipital cerebellar lesion presented for cleaning and resection.

Specimens received: 
A. Tumor - Fresh specimen consisting of 0.5 x 0.3 X 0.3 cm portion of tan to beige soft tissue. Frozen section diagnosis is "Malignant glioma". Remaining tissue submitted in cassette A2.
B. Tumor #2 - Fresh specimen consisting of 1.8 x 1.2 x 0.8 cm aggregate of beige to gray-tan soft tissue pieces. 

Diagnosis: 
A. "Tumor": Glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV astrocytoma)
B. "Tumor #2": Glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV astrocytoma)

Note: The report confirms the presence of malignant gliomas in both tissue specimens received from the patient.

The pathology report describes the examination of a radical nephrectomy specimen and an excised lymph node specimen. The left kidney specimen shows a dominant, well-circumscribed, multinodular, tan-gray, rubbery tumor measuring 3 cm in greatest diameter, which is diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma- papillary type with sarcomatoid component. High nuclear grade and local invasion through renal capsule but confined within Gerota's fascia with renal sinus fat involvement is identified. Renal vein invasion is present but surgical margins are free of tumor, and non-neoplastic kidney is unremarkable. One out of one examined lymph node shows metastasis, with perinodal extracapsular extension identified. The largest metastatic node measures 3 cm in greatest diameter. Staging for renal cell carcinoma/oncocytoma is pT3a.

The pathology report describes a case of renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney, adrenal gland, and periaortic mass with papillary type 2 and Fuhrman's nuclear grade 4. The tumor has invaded the perirenal soft tissue, and there is presence of lymphovascular invasion and metastasis to the perirenal soft tissue. No tumor was present in the margins of resection (renal artery, renal vein, ureter, perinephric soft tissue) or the adrenal gland. Four lymph nodes in the anterior aorta and inter-aortocaval region did not have any tumors present. The gross description indicates the tumor is well-circumscribed, tan-white, and homogeneous, measuring 4.5 x 4.0 x 3.0 cm, and extends to perinephric fat. The uninvolved kidney and adrenal gland are grossly unremarkable. The report mentions the clinical history is unknown.

Gender: F. Material: Partial organ resection - left breast, inner upper quadrant. Macroscopic description: Part of the breast sized 6.6 x 5.3 x 1.9 cm removed with a skin flap of 5.8 x 3.3 cm, marked typically, with an X-ray image. Tumour in cross-section sized 0.9 x 0.8 x 1.7 cm. Radiogram showing a shadowing of 1.4 x 1.4 cm, skin injected with blue dye. Microscopic description: Invasive ductal and in part mucinous carcinoma of the left breast with normal tissue margins as in macroscopic description. Surgical specimen texture outside tumour showing mastopathia fibrosa partim lipomatosis. Histopathology Diagnosis: Carcinoma ductale partim mucinosum invasivum mammae sinistrae N1IG2, pTlc.

Resection material from the right lower lobe reveals a locally advanced, poorly differentiated, adenosquamous carcinoma with extensive pleural infiltration and penetration of S6. The excision does not extend into the healthy tissue and there are tongue-shaped extensions in the peribronchial, hilar fatty connective tissue with lymph node metastases displaying necrotic destruction. Additionally, there is multifocal invasion of the blood vessels. Complete removal of the carcinoma is not definite. Tumor classification: M-8140/3, G3, pT3, pV1, pN1, pMx, stage III A. R2.

Summary: The report describes a left adrenalectomy performed on a patient with a clinical history of left pheochromocytoma. The adrenal tumor was completely encapsulated, measuring 5.5x4.5x4.5 cm with some hemorrhagic areas and a large fibrous scar. There was no necrosis or mitosis observed, and no vascular invasion was detected. The samples taken from the normal adrenal cortex showed no nodulation, indicating a normal homogeneous cortex. The conclusion of the pathology report was left adrenal paraganglioma or pheochromocytoma with a PASS score of 1.

Filtered Report:

SPECIMEN(S) RECEIVED: 1. left kidney.

FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 
PART 1: KIDNEY, LEFT, RADICAL NEPHRECTOMY-. A. PAPILLARY RENAL CELL CARCINOMA, TYPE 2 WITH CLEAR CELL FEATURES. B. FUHRMAN GRADE 3/4. C. TUMOR MEASURES 4.5X4.0X3.5CM. D. TUMOR INVADES THE PERI-RENAL ADIPOSE TISSUE. E. TUMOR DOES NOT INVOLVE THE GEROTA'S FASCIA. F. ALL MARGINS ARE NEGATIVE. G. TUMOR TO CLOSEST INKED PARENCHYMAL MARGIN IS LESS THAN 0.1 CM. H. NO VASCULAR INVASION IS IDENTIFIED. I. PATHOLOGIC STAGE pT3a Nx Mx.

IMMUNOSTAINING: The neoplastic cells show positive results for racemase, CK7, CA9 (focal), and CD10 (focal). These immunostaining results are consistent with papillary renal cell carcinoma with clear cell features.

COMMENT: Pending immunostaining further characterization of the tumor.

Clinical Diagnosis: Right renal mass. Diagnosis: The right kidney has been removed. The kidney showed renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, nuclear grade 1/IV. The pattern of growth is acinar, and the tumor's greatest diameter is 5.5 cm. The tumor extends into the renal pelvis, but no invasion of the renal vein is identified, and all surgical margins are tumor-free. The non-neoplastic kidney shows benign simple cortical cyst and an incidental angiomyolipoma, size 0.2 cm. The lymph nodes, which were excised, are benign (0/2). The tumor does not infiltrate through the renal capsule although it abuts it. The tumor is to renal pelvis, and the capsule is bulging.

A male patient provided three specimens: left and right pelvic lymph nodes and prostate with seminal vesicles. The lymph nodes were examined, and no tumor was found in any of the six. The prostate and seminal vesicles weighed 46 grams, and a radical prostatectomy was performed. Histologically, prostatic adenocarcinoma was detected, and it was present in both prostatic lobes. The Gleason score was 3+3=6, with about 35% of the tissue having carcinoma. There was no lymphovascular invasion or extraprostatic extension observed. In addition, margins were negative for carcinoma, and there was no tumor seen in the seminal vesicles and vasa deferentia.

The pathology report describes metastases of a poorly differentiated carcinoma in the liver (I) and lymph nodes (II), and invasive carcinoma in gastric resection material (III) with lymph node metastases. The immediate resection margins near the mucosa were tumor-free. The tumor classification is ICDO-DA M. 8140/3, with a classification of pT3, pN2, L1, V1, pM1.

Liver segments II and III (380g, 18.3 x 10.8 x 4.8 cm) were subjected to partial hepatectomy due to a 4.2 x 3.8 x 3.2cm mass of grade 2 hepatocellular carcinoma, usual type. The tumor is partially encapsulated and located in segments II and III with the hepatic capsule being involved but adjacent organs were spared. Surgical margins indicate no presence of tumor and clearance of 2.5cm. There is no extratumoral vascular invasion. The non-neoplastic liver is observed to have end-stage micronodular cirrhosis with steatosis and chronic inflammation. The tumor is classified as T2NX.

Report Summary: 

The specimen is a total thyroidectomy from the patient's right lobe. The histologic type of the tumor is papillary carcinoma, with a size of 2 cm and unifocal. Metastasis to 20 out of 27 lymph nodes is confirmed. The primary tumor is limited to the thyroid, and the nodal metastasis is to level VI nodes. No venous/lymphatic invasion is detected, but an unremarkable parathyroid gland is found in the left inferior.

Microscopic diagnosis: Adenocarcinoma, intestinal type, poorly differentiated, 12x9x2.5 cm tumor in the stomach fundus. 11/11 lymph nodes (intraabdominal) are positive for metastasis, with mets to the liver and HER2NEU 2+. Margins are uninvolved. No evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment.

Summary: The pathology report describes a case of sarcoma located in the abdominal wall of the patient. The tumor has invaded the skeletal muscle, subcutaneous adipose tissue, and costal cartilages. The tumor appears to have fibrous structures and the surgical margins are clear, consistent with Desmoid sarcoma.

The pathology report describes a sample collection relating to a case of stomach cancer. The patient's age and sample size are not mentioned. The tumor is found on the stomach and is categorized as adenocarcinoma, mucinous type, with a pathological stage of T2b. The macroscopic tumor configuration is identified as Borrmann type I and type I (protruded and polypoid). Multiple nodules of the tumor are found within perigastric fat, and the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes with N3 staging. No mention of treatment is given. A slide URL is provided for further examination. The report does not include any patient or doctor identification and ends with histology comments.

Report Summary:

Breast, left, wide local excision:
- Infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade II (of III), forming a 1.5 x 1.4 x 1.2 cm mass (AJCC pTlc).
- Associated ductal carcinoma in situ, intermediate nuclear grade, constitutes about 20% of the tumor.
- Resection margins and separately submitted lateral, deep, inferior and superior margins are free of tumor.

Lymph nodes, left axillary sentinel Nos. 1, 2, and 3, excision:
- Three axillary sentinel lymph nodes without blue dye are negative for tumor.
- Immunohistochemical cytokeratin stain confirms the H&E impression.

Location: Left oral tongue. Description: 2.5x2x2cm ulcerated and protruded soft white-gray tumor. Microscopic: Tumor tissue arranged in groups/sheets with keratinized pearls, enlarged nuclei, and mitotic figures; invading lower muscle propria with inflammatory cell stroma. Diagnosis: Squamous cell carcinoma Grade II infiltrating muscle propria. Details: Moderately differentiated - grade 2, lymph node involvement, left laterality, uninvolved margins, lymphovascular invasion present, perineural invasion absent.

The patient had a left nephrectomy for a 14 cm high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma involving the upper pole of the kidney. The tumor focally invades through the renal capsule to involve perinephric fat and is very close to the Gerota's fascia/perinephric fat margin. The tumor also abuts the adrenal gland and involves the medulla of the adrenal gland through direct extension. The differential diagnosis includes dedifferentiated liposarcoma and pleomorphic leiomyosarcoma. The tumor is positive for desmin, CD34, CD10, and vimentin. Referral testing for MDM2 gene amplification testing is being requested, and the results will be reported in an addendum. The adrenal gland is involved by tumor through direct extension. The FISH results show an MDM2 amplification with an MDM2/SE12 ratio of 2.71. Gene amplification in this tumor suggests that this tumor has lipocytic differentiation.

The pathology report describes three tumors in the patient's right kidney. The first tumor is diagnosed as a renal cyst and the other two tumors are diagnosed as clear cell renal cell carcinoma with Furhman nuclear grade 2. The patient has Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and this is noted in the clinical information. Gross description of the specimens is provided, and each specimen is submitted for permanent processing. No consultants were involved.

Diagnosis: Highly differentiated invasive gastric adenocarcinoma of the intestinal type with infiltration of all wall layers of the attached colon loop, colon segment, organ capsule of pancreas with perineural tumor growth, pericolic and peripancreatic lymph node metastasis with tumor-free resection margins, and tumor-free hepatic and splenic parenchyma. Tumor classification: M 8140/3, pT4, pNo.

Final Diagnosis: Invasive well-differentiated endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade 1, with tumor invasion of 0.1 cm of 1.5 cm myometrium (6%). Lymphovascular invasion is not identified. The cervix is free of tumor. Extensive complex atypical hyperplasia and adenocarcinoma involve adenomyosis. Leiomyomata and adenomyosis are present. Bilateral adnexa are free of tumor, and bilateral ovaries have surface epithelial inclusions. One lymph node is negative for metastatic carcinoma (0/1). The tumor size is 5.2 cm, with less than 1/2 thickness of myometrium invaded. Complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia is also present. The pathological stage is T1b, and FIGO stage is IB.

A stomach segment with a tumor is identified as adenocarcinoma, 7.5 cm in its largest dimension, with whole wall and adjacent tissue invasion, perineural invasion and positive lymph nodes. The tumor is poorly differentiated and ulcerated. Margins are uninvolved and venous invasion is absent. No evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment or lymphatic invasion. The spleen demonstrates hyperemia and anaemia of the red pulp.

The pathology report describes a surgical resection of an abdominal pannus and a hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. The uterus contained a 10.7 x 7.8 x 2.1 cm exophytic mass of invasive endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade I (of III), invading 0.6 cm into the myometrium. No lymphovascular space invasion was identified, and all surgical resection margins were negative for tumor. Multiple lymph nodes from the right and left pelvic lymphadenectomy were negative for tumor, and additional right pelvic lymph nodes were also negative for tumor.

Summary: The pathology report describes a surgical specimen from a patient with breast cancer. The specimen includes a resected right deep margin, left breast tissue, and axillary lymph nodes. The left breast tissue shows infiltrating lobular carcinoma, while the right breast shows moderately differentiated intraductal and infiltrating ductal carcinoma with mucinous differentiation. One axillary lymph node is positive for metastatic carcinoma. The report includes receptor and prognostic factor determination on one of the blocks, which shows positive estrogen receptor and negative progesterone receptor and Her-2/neu. The report does not include patient, doctor, or hospital names, reference, treatment plan, or sample size, shape, and weight.

The pathology report concerns a partial or total resection of the left kidney due to renal cell carcinoma (5 cm) of the clear cell type, Fuhrman Grade III/IV, with tumor invasion into the renal vein. The ureter, renal artery, and renal vein margins were negative for tumor. There was a separate fibrotic nodule (6 cm) consistent with prior cryoablation with no residual viable tumor identified. The adrenal gland showed no significant pathologic changes. The non-neoplastic kidney was evaluated and found to have moderately advanced chronic changes of the kidney parenchyma, including focal global and segmental glomerulosclerosis, tubular atrophy and interstitial fibrosis, and arterial and arteriolar sclerosis with hyalinosis. The glomeruli showed diffuse sclerosis of the mesangial areas with focal nodule formation, most likely representing early diabetic changes with a superimposed primary vascular injury. The sample was further evaluated using immunofluorescence microscopy and there was minimal granular deposition of IgA in the mesangial areas, and diffuse linear deposition of albumin and IgG along all basement membranes. The cytogenetic analysis revealed that nine out of ten metaphases from the specimen labeled T2 contained a loss of the Y chromosome, which can be seen in nonneoplastic cells in older men, and is not characteristic of any particular type of tumor.

The specimen submitted includes omentum (partial omentectomy), left and right adnexa salpingo-oophorectomy specimens, uterus (total abdominal hysterectomy), soft tissue on the left pelvic sidewall, soft tissue in the falciform ligament, omentum #2 (partial omentectomy), distal pancreatectomy, segment transverse colon resection, ileocecal valve, and rectosigmoid epiploica excision. Metastatic papillary serous carcinoma is present in all sites, exhibiting high-grade features in all sites with growth patterns including papillary, cystic, solid, and glandular formations. There is lymphovascular invasion by carcinoma. No evidence of metastatic carcinoma involving uterus or uterine cervix is present. No residual normal lymph node tissue is identified. In certain specimens, sections of benign epithelium and cysts are present, as well as reactive lymphoid aggregates and fibrosis. The preliminary pathologic findings were discussed with the doctor.

A male patient with clinical diagnosis of melanoma presented with surgical resection of skin from the right hand. Microscopic examination revealed an ulcerated pigment epithelioid melanoma with Clark's level III and Breslow depth of 3mm. The stage was identified as 2B with Grade 3 and T3, NO, MO. The final diagnosis was Epithelioid Melanoma.

Breast, left, modified radical mastectomy: Infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade II (of. III) forming a mass (2.8 x 2.3 x 2.1. cm) located in the retroareolar region of the breast. Ductal carcinoma in situ is absent. Angiolymphatic invasion and calcifications are not seen. Tumor involves the overlying skin [AJCC pT4]. A single left axillary mid/low lymph node is positive for metastatic carcinoma with extranodal extension. Lymph nodes, left high axillary, excision: Multiple (2) left high axillary lymph nodes are negative for tumor. All surgical resection margins, including the skin and deep margins, are negative for tumor (minimum tumor free margin, 1.1 cm, anterior superior margin).

The pathology report describes a 9cm right renal mass with renal vein thrombus into the inferior vena cava. The kidney, adrenal gland, lymph nodes are excised and examined for diagnosis. The tumor type is classified as unclassified type of renal cell carcinoma with clear and papillary cell features. The tumor shows foci of lympho-vascular invasion, and tumor cells are noted in the section of renal vein margin. The surgical margins show clear margins other than the renal vein margin. The lymph nodes are free of tumor. The adrenal gland is benign and no lymphoid tissue is identified. The report also includes gross descriptions and summary of sections for each part of the specimen.

Diagnosis: Endometrioid adenocarcinoma with greater than 50% invasion into myometrium, involving uterus, right and left fallopian tubes, right ovary, left ovary, and bilateral pelvic lymph nodes. No involvement of cervix or other organs. Margins were uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. Lymphovascular invasion was present. No evidence of metastatic carcinoma involving ovaries or fallopian tubes. Histologic grade was G2. Tumor size was 5cm in greatest dimension. Pathologic staging was pT1c [IC]: Tumor invades one-half or more of the myometrium. Regional lymph nodes involvement was absent.

Summary: The rectal resection material shows a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located in the distal rectum, with infiltration of the perirectal fatty tissue. The lymph nodes in the pericolic fatty tissue bordering the tumor were prepared and three metastatic infiltrations of the adenocarcinoma and colon carcinoma were identified. The stage is established as pT3 pN1 (3/34).

Type: Adenocarcinoma. 
Grade: Moderately differentiated. 
Extent: Muscularis propria. 
Lymph nodes: 0/12 positive for metastasis. 
Tumor site: Fundus. 
Tumor size: 6x5x4cm.

Filtered pathology report: Moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colorectal type with infiltration of pericolic fatty tissue and two regional lymph node metastases found in colon resection material. Tumor-free colon resection margins observed. Tumor stage determined as pT3 pN1 (2/13) pM1 (clinically liver metastases); G2, L1, V0, clinically R2.

The pathology report summarizes the findings of various tests performed on a rectosigmoid colon tumor and a liver biopsy. The report indicates that the tumor is a metastatic adenocarcinoma consistent with colon primary. The immunohistochemical study for DNA mismatch repair gene expression revealed normal expression of hMLH1, hMSH2, hMSH6 and hPMS2 in the tumor. The report also includes the results of mutation analysis for KRAS, NRAS, and PIK3CA genes, as well as results for the microsatellite instability (MSI) panel. The KRAS gene mutation analysis was positive for K-Ras codon 12 GGT>GTT (G12V) mutant. The MSI panel showed a microsatellite stable pattern (MSS) in all five markers tested. No mutations were detected in the PIK3CA gene. The report mentions that additional testing for MSI on the resected tumor will be performed. The report provides information on the gross description of the specimens, including the size and location of the tumor and possible lymph nodes. The final pathological diagnosis is a low-grade/moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the rectosigmoid colon. The report also includes procedural demographics and clinical history of the patient.

Summarized report: The report indicates a high-grade malignant neoplasm consistent with leiomyosarcoma measuring 18 cm involving the lower uterine segment and cervix. The tumor contains up to 90 mitotic figures per 10 high power fields with significant cytologic atypia and coagulative tumor necrosis. The tumor is estrogen receptor and progesterone receptor positive and shows significant smooth muscle differentiation. No tumor is seen in the bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes, except for one ovary with a hemorrhagic corpus luteum. Adenomyosis and leiomyomata are present along with benign secretory phase endometrium. An intraoperative consultation was requested, and representative sections were submitted for analysis.

Histopathological examination of a segment of the large intestine, including a 4.7 x 4 x 1.2 cm ulcerous tumour in the mucosa, revealed adenocarcinoma tubuloapapillare (G1) with infiltration of tunicae muscularis propriae et telae adiposae pericolicae and minimum side margin of 5 cm. The lesion is identified as tubulopapillary adenocarcinoma of the colon (G1; Dukes B, Astler-Coller B2; pT3; pNO), and there are no neoplastic lesions on incision lines. Reactiva lymphonodorum (No XIX) lymphonoditis was observed.

A left nephrectomy and left adrenal mass resection were performed on a male patient. The adrenal mass measured 19 x 17 x 12.4 cm, had a heterogeneous cut surface, and contained areas of necrosis. The left kidney was displaced but showed no macroscopic changes. Green Indian ink was used to stain the surgical margins. The final diagnosis was adrenocortical carcinoma with a largest diameter of 19 cm, Fuhrman nuclear grade of 4, diffuse architectural pattern, clear cells in < 25% of the neoplasm, areas of necrosis, mitotic count of 28 in 10 H.P.F., atypical mitosis, capsular invasion, and venous invasion. The Weiss score was 8, and neoplastic infiltration was not detected in the renal parenchyma.

Patient with prior history of PSA value 19.3 and biopsy revealing Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 4+3=7 in the left and right apex, mid, and base with Perineural invasion, underwent Radical prostatectomy. Final diagnosis reveals invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+4=7 involving both lobes of the prostate with extracapsular extension seen in the posterior right apex, mid and base and posterior left mid regions. Bilateral seminal vesicles, all examined surgical resection margins, and lymph nodes all free of carcinoma. Benign prostatic hypertrophy is noted. Pathologic TNM stage is pT3a NO MX with a histologic grade of G3. High-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia is identified.

A brain tumor was received for frozen section and subsequent analysis. The specimen consisted of three separate aggregates of soft tissue. The frozen section diagnoses of all three specimens were "Diffuse infiltrating glioma, suspect malignant glioma". The final diagnoses for all three specimens were Glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV astrocytoma). The tumor is highly infiltrative and shows areas of low to intermediate-grade histology with increased cellularity, pleomorphism, vascular proliferation, and necrosis. The GFAP staining and ki-67 labeling index support the diagnosis.

Histomorphology of the sample shows features consistent with oligodendroglial cells, with the presence of single mitoses. There is also a focal increase in proliferation up to 10%. The diagnosis of the sample is an Oligodendroglioma of World Health Organization Grade II.

Specimens received for analysis include left upper lobe nodule, station 8, 10, and 11 lymph nodes, left upper lobectomy, and station 6, 5, and 7 lymph nodes. The diagnosis for the left upper lobe nodule and lobectomy is lepidic-predominant adenocarcinoma, with one lymph node testing negative for carcinoma out of a total of 11 examined. Additional molecular testing has been performed, detecting a KRAS gene mutation, which may correlate with poor prognosis and resistance to tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapies in non-small cell lung cancer patients with a smoking history. No mutations were detected in exon 18-21 of the EGFR tyrosine kinase domain.

test.report: The pathology report pertains to a male patient who underwent a lobectomy with lymph node staging and immediate frozen section diagnosis for right upper lobe lung cancer. The final diagnosis reveals invasive squamous cell carcinoma, keratinizing type, poorly differentiated, with no angiolymphatic invasion and no involvement of visceral pleura. The resection margins are free with tumor closest to the bronchial margin. A total of 12 lymph nodes were examined, and all were negative for metastatic carcinoma. An additional finding of obstructive pneumonia and emphysema in the uninvolved lung was noted. No malignancy was found in any of the examined lymph nodes or in a lung wedge biopsy of the right middle/lower lobe. The specimen cassettes were labeled as such: A - lymph node, station 7, B - lymph node, station 7, C - lymph node, 10 R, D - lymph node, 12 R #2, E - lymph node station 10 R, F - lymph node, 10 R #3, G - lung, right upper lobe bronchial margin, H - lymph node station 4 R, I - lung wedge biopsy, right middle/lower. The report concludes that permanent sections confirm the frozen section diagnoses.

A left renal mass was resected, and three specimens were submitted: 1) left kidney and adrena, 2) portion of left 11th rib, and 3) left para-aortic lymph node. The diagnosis of left kidney resection is renal cell carcinoma, chromophobe cell type, with a solid growth pattern, 15.8 cm in diameter, confined within the renal capsule, no invasion of renal vein, and free tumor margins. The non-neoplastic kidney is unremarkable, and no adrenal gland is identified. The rib biopsy is grossly unremarkable, and the sections are not yet ready due to the need for decalcification. The left para-aortic lymph node biopsy is benign fibroadipose tissue. No obvious palpable lymph nodes are present within the perinephric adipose tissue. Representative sections of each specimen are submitted, and additional slides are recut for H&E staining. The frozen section diagnosis favor oncocytoma is given, but the final diagnosis is consistent with the previous report.

The pathology report describes the results of a total abdominal hysterectomy and unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy for primary uterine adenocarcinoma. The carcinoma is predominantly endometrioid-type with associated secretory, eosinophilic, and squamoid changes, FIGO grade III, and involves greater than 50% of the uterine wall thickness in the deepest area of invasion. Myometrial invasion by carcinoma is also present, and lymphovascular invasion by carcinoma is present. Adenomyosis with and without secondary involvement by carcinoma is noted. No evidence of metastatic carcinoma is identified in the lymph nodes or adnexa. The report also mentions the presence of benign cysts, leiomyomas, and other minor changes in the uterus and cervix.

A pathology report was obtained for a patient with breast cancer. The report indicates that there was a focus of invasive lobular carcinoma in the axillary breast tissue with a positive lymph node for micrometastasis. The right breast had invasive lobular carcinoma measuring 3.5 cm and was designated as Stage IIB. The report includes details of lymph node sampling, integrity, and margins. The left breast was benign. The gross description includes information on the various specimens submitted, their labeling, and representative sections submitted. The updated report reflects a correction in the classification of one of the lymph nodes from SLN #2 to multiple micrometastases.

Diagnosis: Moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the sigmoid colon with G2 differentiation, inner tumor surface erosions, chronic inflammation, infiltration of parietal layers, chronic lymphadenitis of tumor-free lymph nodes (0/12), and tumor stage of pT2, pNo, MX, R0.

The pathology report describes the results of a hysterectomy and node dissection for a patient with malignant neocorpus uteri. A benign simple cyst is present in both the right and left ovaries. The endometrium is affected by a diffuse endometrioid adenocarcinoma (FIGO grade 3) measuring approximately 8.5 x 5.5 cm, with a maximum depth of myometrial invasion of 1.4 cm in a 2.3 cm thick wall. Lymphatic/vascular invasion is absent, and adjacent non-neoplastic endometrium and remaining myometrium are without specific pathology. The cervix and serosa are negative for tumor, and specimen margins are not involved. Metastasis is found in one of five right obturator lymph nodes (maximum size of metastases: 8 mm), while all other lymph nodes (pelvic, aortic, and left obturator) are negative for carcinoma. The report also notes that the current tissue specimen alone determines the pathology stage and does not incorporate past pathology or clinical findings.

The pathology report describes a kidney mass excision in a female patient with a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma, chromophobe type, Fuhrman nuclear Grade 2. The specimen is a 4 x 3.5 x 3 cm circular red mass that is bisected to reveal a homogeneous, soft, fleshy to spongy cut surface that is pale yellow to tan in color. The half of the specimen is sent to pathology for analysis, and no margins are necessary as per the surgeon's report. The report includes no further information on the patient's history, treatment plan or surgical procedure.

The pathology report summarizes a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme, grade IV (WHO), supported by findings of marked hypercellularity, nuclear atypia, microvascular proliferation, and tumor necrosis. Immunoperoxidase stains were positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein and negative for keratin. The report also includes a brief description of the received specimen, clinical history of the patient, and notes that the diagnosis was made by an attending pathologist following review of all pathology slides. The report does not include any irrelevant information such as patient name, doctor name, hospital name, or treatment plan. Additionally, it is noted that the laboratory is certified under the Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments of (CLIA) as qualified to perform high-complexity clinical testing.

Female diagnosed with combined hepatocellular and cholangiocarcinoma, grade 4, in the left lobe and segment VI of the liver. The resected mass measured 5.8 x 5.3 x 4.0 cm, with no evidence of microvascular invasion or vein invasion. A single lymph node was negative for tumor, and all surgical margins were negative for tumor (minimum tumor-free margin, 0.1 cm). The non-neoplastic hepatic parenchyma appeared unremarkable. One lymph node each from the hepatic artery and paracaval regions were negative for tumor. [AJCC pT1NWOMX].

The pathology report describes a case of a male patient who experienced a seizure and left facial droop. Imaging revealed a benign brain tumor in the medial and superior temporal lobe extending into the insula with uncal herniation. Biopsy revealed an oligodendroglioma with a proliferation index of 3%. Loss of heterozygosity assay showed allelic loss on chromosome arm 19q, but not on 1p. MGMT promoter methylation test was negative. Intra-operative consultation noted astrocytic proliferation with atypical and undifferentiated cells with crushed and touch preparations. GFAP demonstrated gliofibrillary background with numerous reactive astrocytes. One-fourth of neoplastic nuclei overexpressed strongly the p53 protein with a proliferation index of about 1.5%. The neoplasm has an oligodendroglial origin, is WHO grade II, with no mitotic activity, microvascular proliferation, or necrosis.

The pathology report describes a lung mass and lymph nodes specimens. The right upper lobe of the lung contains a 3.2 cm poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, which invades and ulcerates a major bronchus. The margins of resection, regional lymph nodes, and pleural surfaces are negative for tumor, whereas two nonspecific small areas of fibrosis are noted in a subpleural location. Multiple reactive lymph nodes are negative for metastatic disease. Two adjacent soft, blackened lymph nodes measuring up to 1.1 cm in greatest dimension are found in the hilar area.

Diagnosis: Radical prostatectomy - Adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+4, involving approximately 10% of the examined tissue and focally extending to resection margin. High-grade PIN and perineural invasion present. Prostatic fat is involved, but there is no involvement of bladder neck or lymph nodes. The tumor involves both lobes of the prostate. One focus extends to the resection margin at a linear distance of 1.1mm. No clinical history provided.

Left kidney radical nephrectomy reveals infiltrating renal carcinoma with the following characteristics: papillary (chromophil) renal cell carcinoma, oncocylic variant, with extensive degenerative changes and necrosis. The tumor involves perinephric adipose tissue and focally infiltrates through the renal capsule. Soft tissue, ureteral, and vascular margins are negative for tumor. No lymph nodes are identified. pTNM stage is T3a NX MX, stage III. The adrenal gland is not identified. The specimen consists of a kidney with a 5.2 x 4.5 x 4.1 cm focally cystic tan red to orange mass, which diffusely involves the adipose tissue and abuts the inked perinephric fat. The patient had a left renal mass, and the postoperative diagnosis is infiltrating renal carcinoma. Two orange cassettes labeled A and C and one green and yellow cassette are received for genomic research study.

The report describes the excision of various lymph nodes and lung tissue from a male patient with lung cancer in the left upper lobe who is a current everyday smoker. Pathological analysis shows that most lymph nodes are negative for malignancy (0/1 or 0/2), except for one lymph node that tests positive for squamous cell carcinoma, moderately differentiated, measuring 4 cm in maximum dimension. The lung tissue also shows marked interstitial fibrosis, scattered lymphoid aggregates, and mild medial hypertrophy of medium-sized arteries. Gross description indicates a mass measuring 4.0 x 3.5 x 3.5 cm at the apex of the lung lobe, located 1.8 cm away from the nearest surgical margin, with an irregular deep contour. Microscopically, the tumor is identified as a unifocal squamous cell carcinoma that measures 4 cm, invading the visceral pleura. No lymph node metastasis or distant metastasis is observed, and there is no evidence of invasion in the bronchial margin or vascular margin.

Patient presents with hoarseness and biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma in right-sided laryngeal lesion, with T4 lesion invading thyroid cartilage. Total laryngectomy and bilateral neck dissection was performed, and final diagnosis indicates invasive moderately differentiated transglottic squamous cell carcinoma with no perineural or angiolymphatic invasion, free tumor resection margins, and lymph nodes free of tumor. Pathological stage is pT4a, NO, MX. The gross description details the size and location of the tumor and demonstrates lymph nodes of various sizes being submitted for tissue banking. Intraoperative consultation confirms benign status and free margins in anterior soft tissue margin. Histological summary confirms the presence of squamous cell carcinoma invading various structures, with no lymph node involvement and free margins.

Microscopic diagnosis indicates well differentiated papillary adenocarcinoma with lymph node metastasis in a lung lobectomy specimen. Tumor extent, other tumor nodules, lymphatic invasion, venous invasion, margins, and evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment are not specified. The tumor size is 4 x 3 x 6 cm and there are 3/8 lymph nodes positive for metastasis (Hilar 3/8). No additional pathologic findings are reported.

The pathology report describes a case of moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma of the left mandible with invasion of bone, perineurial invasion, and angiolymphatic invasion. The report also includes details about lymph node involvement, lymph node metastasis, and status of surgical margins. The frozen section diagnoses were confirmed, and the patient was staged as pT4a pN2c. Additional results of immunohistochemistry and HPV in situ hybridization were negative. The report provides extensive detail about various specimens submitted, including lymph nodes and teeth, and corresponding block summaries. Addendum includes negative results for anterior mandible bone margin and p16 immunohistochemistry and HPV in situ hybridization.

Uterus, bilateral ovaries, and fallopian tubes were removed due to high grade papillary serous carcinoma. Invasive tumor extends into the myometrium within the lower uterine segment. A separate non-invasive, high grade papillary serous carcinoma forming a mass is identified. Multiple benign leiomyomata and calcified nodules are identified. Omentum and lymph nodes are negative for tumor. The report is based on gross/macroscopic examination and frozen section histologic evaluation of the specimen(s).

A biopsy of the left and additional left ureteral margins showed chronic inflammation and denudation of surface epithelium, with no malignancy. The right ureteral margin biopsy showed no tumor. The urinary bladder resection revealed invasive high grade transitional cell carcinoma measuring 1.5 cm in diameter, invading through muscular propria into underlying perivesical soft tissue, with no evidence of lymphovascular invasion. The urethral margin was negative, and the right pelvic lymph nodes excision showed six benign lymph nodes with no evidence of metastatic neoplasm. The appendix resection was negative, and left pelvic lymph nodes excision showed two benign lymph nodes with no evidence of metastatic neoplasm. The AJCC pathologic stage was T3a, NO. Frozen section diagnoses of the left and right ureteral margins showed no malignancy. The left ureteral margin biopsy showed predominantly denuded epithelium with a small attached portion of carcinoma in situ, without invasive components. The clinical information indicated bladder cancer.

The report describes a left upper pole renal mass that was partially removed through a partial nephrectomy. The tumor is identified as renal cell carcinoma, conventional and clear cell type, nuclear grade II/IV, with a solid pattern of growth. Its greatest diameter is 4.0cm, and it extends through the renal capsule but is confined within Gerota's fascia. All surgical margins are free of the tumor, and the non-neoplastic kidney is unremarkable. The submitted deep margin sample shows benign renal tissue, and the excised portion of the left eleventh rib appears grossly unremarkable. Intraoperative consultation confirms the presence of a renal cortical neoplasm, but the margins are negative.

Summary:
Poorly differentiated invasive breast carcinoma with focal in situ spread. (tumor diameter: 2.2 cm). Neuroendocrine characteristics present. Tumor classification: NOS, G III, pT2N0(sn)LOVORO.

Summary: The pathology report describes a lymphoepithelial proliferation in the anterior mediastinum and contiguous lung mass with polygonal large cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm, oval nucleus, and clear nucleoli. Cytonuclear atypia are observed, but necrosis is less than 10%, and margins are negative. Distant lung parenchyma shows emphysema and vascular congestion, and interlobar, aorto-pulmonary lymph nodes do not show invasion. A nodule of the parietal pleura shows fibrosis and inflammation, but no tumor. The final diagnosis is anaplastic type B3 thymoma, complete resection, stage IVA with no lymph node invasion.

Surgical Pathology: Final. Ccc#. CLINICAL HISTORY: Not provided. GROSS EXAMINATION: A. "Brain tumor (AF1, AF2)" received fresh for frozen section. A 1.0 x 0.8 x 0.4 cm aggregate of soft white-tan tissue was entirely received for frozen sectioning. A fragment of the tissue was submitted for frozen sectioning AF1, and the frozen section remnant is submitted in toto in a mesh bag in block A1. Two more tissue fragments were submitted for frozen sectioning AF2, and the frozen section remnant is submitted in toto in a mesh bag in block A2. The remainder of the tissue is submitted in toto in a mesh bag in block A3. B. "Brain tumor (BF1)" received fresh for frozen sectioning. A 1.5 x 1.0 x 0.3 cm aggregate of soft white-tan tissue was received for frozen sectioning. A fragment of the tissue was submitted for frozen sectioning in BF1, and the frozen section remnant is submitted in toto in a mesh bag in block B1. The remainder of the tissue is submitted in toto in a mesh bag in block B2. C. "Brain tumor" received fresh and placed in formalin. An 11.5 x 7.5 x 1.0 cm aggregate of soft yellow-tan tissue with a 1.3 x 1.0 x 0.5 cm dark and light red soft lesion is received. Representative sections are submitted in blocks C1-8. INTRAOPERATIVE CONSULTATION: A. "Brain tumor": AF1-AF2 - hypercellular brain. B. "Brain tumor?" BF1 - glioma. MICROSCOPIC EXAMINATION: Specimen in container A labeled "brain tumor AF1, AF2," in container B labeled "brain tumor BF1," and in container C labeled "brain tumor" consists of brain tissue that is infiltrated and replaced by a population of anaplastic astrocytes. The cells are very pleomorphic, and tumor giant cells are seen in many areas. Mitotic figures, including abnormal mitoses, are present. Endothelial proliferation is focally seen, but necrosis is not identified. DIAGNOSIS: A. "BRAIN TUMOR AF1, AF2": ANAPLASTIC ASTROCYTOMA. B. "BRAIN TUMOR BF1": ANAPLASTIC ASTROCYTOMA. C. "BRAIN TUMOR": ANAPLASTIC ASTROCYTOMA. I certify that I personally conducted the diagnostic evaluation of the above specimen(s) and have rendered the above diagnosis(es). 1 of 1.

SUMMARY: 

- The specimen submitted includes multiple soft red-black tissue fragments with anthracotic lymph nodes. 
- The well-differentiated adenocarcinoma with broncho-alveolar features in the right lower lobe measures 4cm in maximum dimension and extends to the pleural surface with pleural puckering but does not involve the visceral pleura. 
- Uninvolved pulmonary parenchyma shows small non-caseating granulomata, negative for pathogenic organisms and mild emphysematous changes. 
- All surgical margins are negative for tumor. 
- The lymph nodes are negative for tumor. 
- The pathological stage is pT2a NO MX.

The pathology report describes two specimens submitted for a right frontal brain tumor. The first part of the tumor is identified as an anaplastic oligodendrogliona with a WHO grade III, and the second part is identified as an anaplastic oligodendroglioma with a WHO grade III. Immunostaining for the R132H mutant of IDH1 is positive. Intraoperative consultation confirms the diagnosis of a glioma, favor oligodendroglioma. The report notes that certain immunohistochemistry and ISH tests were performed by the Department of Pathology and are used for clinical purposes. The report also states that the laboratory is certified under the Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments of 1988 (CLIA' '88) as qualified to perform high complexity clinical laboratory testing.

Diagnosis: Left kidney, partial nephrectomy due to a 5.1 cm unifocal renal cell carcinoma, chromophobe type, Fuhrman grade 3/4. No sarcomatoid features identified, and no extra-capsular invasion. The surgical margins are negative, but close at 1 mm to blue. No involvement of renal capsular margin or perinephric adipose tissue margin and no lymph node involvement. The adrenal gland was not received. Clinical history includes a left renal mass in a  year-old female. Light microscopic examination shows solid sheets of eosinophilic and clear cells with focal punched-out perinuclear clearing, consistent with the diagnosis of chromophobe carcinoma. Immunostains show reactivity for CK7, and no reactivity for c-Kit or RCC, supporting a diagnosis of chromophobe carcinoma.

The pathology report describes three specimens - two sentinel lymph nodes and a wide local excision from the left breast. Sentinel lymph nodes #1 and #2 show no presence of tumor. The wide local excision from the left breast reveals invasive and in-situ ductal carcinoma, SBR grade III/III with extensive necrosis and cancerization of lobules. The invasive tumor is ductal with a size of 2.5cm and a Scarff Bloom Richardson grade of III. The lymph nodes are negative with ER, PR, and HER2 still pending. Addendums reveal ER/PR/HER2 status determined by immunohistochemistry and fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) for Her-2 gene amplification, which is not amplified. The report concludes with a summary of the specimens and their dimensions and the pathological diagnosis made by the pathologist.

Laterality: NA. Procedure: Pancreaticoduodenectomy (partial pancreatectomy). Tumor location: Head. Tumor size: 4.5 cm. Histologic type: Ductal adenocarcinoma. Histologic grade: Moderately differentiated (50-95%). Microscopic tumor extension: Invades peripancreatic soft tissue. Surgical margins: Distal, Common bile duct, and Distal stomach/duodenum margins are free of neoplasm. Retroperitoneal margins: Uncinate groove is involved by neoplasm. Angiolymphatic spread: Yes. Perineural spread: Yes. Treatment effect: No prior treatment. TNM staging: Tumor extent (Pt3): Invasion beyond pancreas to peripancreatic adipose tissue. Lymph nodes (pN1): Peripancreatic, superior: 1 of 4 contains metastases, Peripancreatic, inferior: 0 of 10 contains metastases, Pancreaticoduodenal, anterior: 0 of 3 contains metastases, Pancreaticoduodenal, posterior: 2 of 10 contain metastases, and Hepatic artery lymph node (B): 0 of 1 contains metastases, Peripancreatic lymph node (D): 1 of 1 contains metastases.

Specimen type: Lobectomy. Tumor site: Lung. Tumor size: 8 x8x8cm. Histologic type: Squamous cell carcinoma. Histologic grade: Poorly differentiated. Tumor extent: Visceral pleura. Lymph nodes: 8/10 positive for metastasis (Intrathoracical 8/10). Right-lower Laterality.

Diagnosis: Left temporal brain tumor. Oligoastrocytoma, grade II. MIB-1 LI= 5.1%. The neoplastic cells are positive for IDH1, but negative for p53, most consistent with the oligodendroglia lineage. Microscopic Description: A moderately cellular diffusely infiltrating glial neoplasm is seen, which includes both classic oligodendroglioma and fibrillary astrocytoma phenotypes. No microvascular proliferation or necrosis are present.

The pathology report pertains to a male patient of unspecified ethnicity with a diagnosis of primary tumor in the left kidney identified as renal cell carcinoma. The report includes details related to the tissue specimen, container, amount, and format. It also mentions the TNM stage, histological grade, and cellular tumor percentage without providing any information about prior chemo, hormonal therapy, or radiation treatment. The report specifies that the blood sample was collected but does not provide any relevant information about it.

The pathology report relates to a radical nephrectomy specimen submitted fresh as "left kidney", including an attached adrenal gland and a segment of ureter. The isolated kidney measured 12.5 x 5.5 x 5 cm, and a pink tan granular surface interrupted by a serous cyst at the upper pole was observed. A 2.7 cm tumor, Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma (Fuhrman Nuclear Grade 2), was identified in the lower portion of the kidney's upper pole that protruded into the surrounding perirenal fat without grossly invading the subjacent pelvis. An adjacent 4 cm cortical cyst was also noted. Immunoperoxidase stains were performed, and the lesion was positive for RCC antigen but negative for TTF-1, confirming the renal origin. The remaining kidney shows scattered foci of interstitial chronic inflammation and mild arteriolosclerosis. The final diagnosis revealed PTNM Stage: pT1a NX MX, and the lymph nodes were uninvolved.

The pathology report concerns a  year-old male who underwent a cystoprostatectomy due to invasive urothelial carcinoma, with a high grade WHO classification. The tumor site was multifocal, involving the right lateral wall, left lateral wall, and dome of the bladder, and measuring 3.4 cm (mass A) and 1.2 cm (mass B). The tumor invaded through the muscularis propria, and angiolymphatic space invasion was present. Associated epithelial lesions included urothelial dysplasia in the left UVJ and carcinoma in situ within prostatic ducts. The report notes that the lymph nodes were negative for carcinoma, and there was no prostatic stromal invasion identified. The AJCC Pathologic TNM Stage was pT3 pNO. Two lymph nodes were negative for carcinoma in the left pelvic, regional node dissection, and six lymph nodes were negative for carcinoma in the right pelvic, regional node dissection. The report also included details regarding the gross description and orientation of the specimens received for testing.

The report describes three specimens: A. Sentinel node #1 and #2, B. Right breast, C. Right axillary contents. In A, one of the two lymph nodes identifies the metastatic carcinoma measuring 8 mm with extranodal extension. In B, invasive ductal carcinoma is present along with ductal carcinoma in situ and other findings. In C, there are 34 lymph nodes identified, ranging from 0.1 to 2.5 cm, with no evidence of tumors grossly noted. The report also includes synoptic reports and notes on clinical history, pre-operative diagnosis, intraoperative consultation, and HER-2 testing results.

Summary: The pathology report confirms the diagnosis of high grade leiomyosarcoma in both intercostal biopsy and right paraspinal radical resection specimens. The tumor measures 6.6 cm in its greatest dimension and involves skeletal muscle and fibroadipose tissue, showing less than 5% necrosis. The tumor is 0.1 cm from anterior, 0.4 cm from posterior, and 0.2 cm from superior inked margin. Intraoperative consultation and permanent diagnosis show the same result. The details of specimen submission, gross description, and summary of sections are also provided.

The pathology report describes specimens of left and right pelvic lymph nodes and prostate obtained from a patient with a pre-operative diagnosis of prostate cancer. The intraoperative consultation diagnosis of the left and right pelvic lymph nodes revealed no evidence of tumor. The prostate gland, seminal vesicles, and vas deferentia were examined and found to have tumors limited to the prostate with less than 10% involvement of prostate tissue. Perineural invasion was identified, but no angiolymphatic invasion or extraprostatic extension was detected. Left and right seminal vesicles and vas deferens were negative for tumors. The prostate gland had multiple specimens submitted and was diagnosed with adenocarcinoma, with a Gleason score of 3 + 4 = 7. No clinical history was given.

The pathology report describes a case of invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the right hemiglossectomy specimen, with vascular and perineural invasion. Anterior, posterior, and deep tongue margins are free of carcinoma, but the carcinoma extends to the anterior and posterior floor of mouth margins. The final diagnosis is pT3 N2b. Re-resection of the anterior and posterior floor of mouth margins shows no tumors. However, the medial posterior floor of mouth/tongue biopsy reveals invasive squamous cell carcinoma. The new posterior margin and deep muscle margin show no tumors. A right neck dissection shows metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in 5 out of 24 lymph nodes and extranodal extension with vascular invasion. The patient's clinical question was about margins and nodes. There is no prior malignancy, chemoradiation therapy, organ transplant, or immunosuppression. The report includes a detailed description of the specimen received, ink codes, and cassette codes. The tissue was fixed for a minimum of 2 to a maximum of 84 hours.

The tumor is located in the sulobes 5, 7, and 8, and appears as solid, firm, gray-white masses with moderate margins, measuring 6x4x4cm in size. Microscopically, the tumor cells exhibit trabecular, nodular, or sheet-like patterns, invading the fibrous stroma. The cells exhibit features of poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma with irregularly large and hyperchromatic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, abundant basophilic or clear cytoplasm, and present mitoses. The stroma is marked fibrous and hyaline. The specimen is a wedge resection or lobectomy without additional pathologic findings.

The pathology report describes several excisions of tumors in a patient's kidney. The first excision shows a benign cyst. The second to fifth excisions show conventional clear cell renal cell carcinoma with cystic changes, with different sizes, Fuhrman nuclear grades, and TNM stages. The sixth excision, a radical nephrectomy, shows a large clear cell renal cell carcinoma with hemorrhage, extensive necrosis, sarcomatoid features, and rhabdoid morphology at some foci, with Fuhrman nuclear grade of IV of IV. No invasion of the renal vein is identified, but foci suspicious for angiolymphatic invasion are found. All surgical margins are free of the neoplasm, and the non-neoplastic kidney and left adrenal show no significant pathologic changes.

The pathology report indicates the presence of an adenocarcinoma of the colon, with poor differentiation and extensive necrosis. The tumor has penetrated all parietal layers and shows vascular infiltration. There are three lymph node metastases. Tumor classification is ICDO-DA-M, G3, pT3, L1, V1, and pN1. Diverticular formations were also observed.

The pathology report describes the analysis of multiple specimens received from a patient with thyroid carcinoma. The report reveals that the metastatic lesion in the lymph nodes displays features of papillary carcinoma, while the infiltrative tumor in the trachea is consistent with papillary carcinoma. The dominant left lobe tumor is an angioinvasive and widely invasive classical variant papillary carcinoma with focal dedifferentiation and tall cell change involving surgical margins. Additionally, a medullary carcinoma is identified in the right lobe, which stains positive for calcitonin, CEA, chromogranin, and TTF1, and negative for thyroglobulin. The report provides additional details such as tumor laterality, size, margins, and lymph node involvement. Ancillary studies and gross descriptions are also included in the report. The report concludes that the patient has thyroid carcinoma, and the staging is based on the AJCC/UICC TNM 7th Edition criteria.

The pathology report confirms the presence of invasive poorly differentiated squamous carcinoma in the laryngopharyngectomy right neck dissection, involving the mid supraglottic and extending to the right and left. The margins of the glottis are free of invasive carcinoma. Four of 29 lymph nodes (upper mid and lower jugular lymph nodes) contain metastatic carcinoma with extranodal extension. There is focal mild dysplasia and detached fragments with dysplasia/atypia present in the esophageal margin, but it cannot be graded since it is not full thickness. The superior laryngeal nerve, right side, contains no tumor growth. The superior pharyngeal margin consists of mucosa, submucosa, muscle, and no severe dysplasia or invasive carcinoma. However, it cannot rule out focal mild dysplasia since it is too cauterized for evaluation. Lastly, five unremarkable teeth are present.

Left lung pneumonectomy reveals moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma within upper lobe, measuring 4.5 cm in maximum gross dimension. Bronchial margins of surgical resection are free, and the pleural surface over the neoplasm is clear. Hilar lymph node dissection shows metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in two (2) out of six (6) lymph nodes, corresponding to pathological AJCC stage of T2a, N1. No other masses or lesions are identified in the remainder of the lung. The lymph nodes are dissected and submitted for further diagnosis.

The pathology report describes three specimens taken from a patient. The first two, A and B, are pelvic lymph nodes, with no malignancies found in either specimen. The third specimen, C, is a 44-gram resected prostate gland with adenocarcinoma, specifically a conventional type comprising approximately 25% of the gland and with a Gleason grade 3+4=7/10. The adenocarcinoma is multifocal and involves both the right and left lobes but has no extraprostatic extension. The seminal vesicles are negative for tumor and all margins are negative for tumor. Focal angiolymphatic invasion is present in the right lobe and perineural invasion is present in both the right and left lobes.
