Additionally, extensive high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia is present. No other pathologic findings are identified. The pathological staging is pTNM T2c, Mx. No clinical history is given, but the pre-operative diagnosis is prostate cancer.

Stomach adenocarcinoma was detected in the antrum with a tubular histologic pattern and moderately differentiated grade II. The tumor was of the intestinal Lauren classification, 5.0 cm in size, and showed ulceration with infiltrative invasion to adjacent fat tissue. Moderate inflammatory response was observed, but perivisceral fat implant was not detected. Neoplasia was absent at the proximal and distal margins and neural invasion was not observed. Lymphatic invasion was present, while blood vessel invasion was not detected. Neoplasia was found in 2 out of 19 lymph nodes, both located in the greater curvature. The lesser curvature was uninvolved. The greater omentum was free of neoplasia.

The pathology report pertains to a right orchiectomy specimen received for a patient with a history of a right testicular mass. Gross examination revealed a testicular mass measuring 7.5 cm, with multiple white-tan fleshy nodules and necrosis. Microscopic examination identified classic type seminoma, with no intratubular germ cell neoplasia identified. The tumor was limited to the testis and did not involve rete testis, epididymis, spermatic cord, tunica vaginalis, or scrotal wall. The remaining testicular tissue showed fibrosis and chronic inflammation. The final pathologic tumor stage was pT1NXMX (Stage IA). The spermatic cord margin was negative.

The report describes various specimens received for analysis, including sentinel lymph nodes, a needle-localized wide local excision of the left breast, and a superior margin. The sentinel lymph nodes and superior margin are negative for tumor, while the breast excision shows invasive ductal carcinoma with a size of 1.5 x 1.5 x 1.0 cm, SBR grade 2, and negative margins. The synoptic report includes information on tumor size, site, margins, and ER/PR positivity, and a HER2 analysis was performed. The lymph node status is negative, and no neoplastic areas are identified, with involutional changes observed. The report was reviewed by multiple pathologists.

The pathology report pertains to a male patient who underwent radical prostatectomy due to carcinoma present in the prostate gland. The tumor size was 5-10% with a Gleason grade of 7/10. Perineural invasion was present, but extraprostatic extension and seminal vesicle involvement were not identified. High-grade PIN was present with uninvolved margins. Lymph node dissection showed four benign nodes with no metastatic carcinoma. The patient was diagnosed with pT2c NO stage prostate cancer. No other significant findings were noted.
Cervical biopsy shows invasive squamous cell carcinoma.

The report describes the gross and microscopic findings of a liver specimen with a 5.5 cm tumor in the left lobe diagnosed as predominantly moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), with some cholangiocytic differentiation and partial fibrous capsule formation. The tumor is surrounded by dystrophic calcification and shows invasion of the portal vein but not the bile duct. There is also precirrhotic fibrosis and minimal chronic hepatitis of unknown cause in non-tumor liver parenchyma. There is no evidence of dysplastic nodules or intrahepatic metastasis. Special stains reveal the arrangement of tumor cells and fibrotic septa.

The pathology report describes the examination of various samples, including lymph nodes and prostate tissue, from a patient with prostate cancer. Analysis of the lymph nodes showed no evidence of cancer. However, examination of the left peri-prostatic tissue revealed a small focus of adenocarcinoma. The prostate was removed and found to contain adenocarcinoma with invasion of bilateral seminal vesicles and extraprostatic soft tissue. The Gleason score was 8/10, and the tumor had a severity extent of 5/5. Lymphatic invasion was suspected. Perineural invasion was present, and positive inked margins were observed in bilateral soft tissues around seminal vesicles. No tumor was seen in other specimen margins. The sample size, shape and weight, as well as the treatment plan and other related details, were excluded from the report.

The pathology report refers to a radical nephrectomy specimen on a right kidney with a 10 cm maximum dimension renal cell carcinoma, conventional type. The tumor has invaded into the renal pelvicaliceal system, with Fuhrman nuclear grade 3 and multifocal tumor necrosis present. However, the perinephric adipose tissue, renal sinus adipose tissue, and renal vein are free of tumor. The uninvolved renal parenchyma has foci of linear hemorrhages in the cortico-medullary junction. The report includes SNOMED codes T-71000 and M-83123.

The pathology report pertains to a right adrenal specimen for a patient diagnosed with a pheochromocytoma. The adrenalectomy diagnosis confirms the presence of the tumor, with microscopic foci of vascular invasion noted. The report warns that the biologic behavior of pheochromocytoma can be difficult to predict from the histology, and the presence of foci of vascular invasion is worrisome, requiring close clinical follow-up. The gross description of the specimen indicates that it is a 97-gram, yellow-tan adipose tissue containing an intact adrenal gland, with a soft, mottled, red-purple to brown mass measuring 6.0 x 5.3 x 4.3 cm present within the medulla. Representative sections were submitted for histological examination. No charge codes are associated with this case, and the report is currently in process.

Diagnosis: Moderately differentiated invasive hepatocellular carcinoma, tumor size 12 cm, extending through the capsule, suggestive of thrombosis with recanalization. Cholecystectomy shows cholesterolosis, no cholelithiasis, and no tumor seen in 2 lymph nodes. Gross examination reveals a well-circumscribed white soft tumor with scattered areas of black char-like pigment and areas of questionable necrosis. The tumor appears to be less than 0.1 cm from the inked margin and focally may extend to the margin. The remainder of the liver is tan/brown with a somewhat micronodular pattern. Representative sections submitted per block summary. Gallbladder measurements: 9.2 x 3.1 x 1.4 cm, with numerous yellow/tan nodules on the external surface ranging in size. Wall thickness: 0.2 cm. Mucosa: green velvety with cholesterolosis, no identified stones. Block B1: Cystic duct margin and representative section of lymph node located at the cystic duct as well as nodules at the proximal portion of the gallbladder. B2: Representative sections of the body of the gallbladder and distal portion of gallbladder at the site of nodules.

A pathology report indicates that a patient has been diagnosed with endometrial adenocarcinoma, an adenomyosis, and multiple myomas. The tumor is 3.8 cm in size and has invaded over 50% of the myometrial thickness with lympho/vascular invasion present. The cervix and adnexa show no signs of involvement. Lymph node samples from different areas of the body, including the left pelvic and aortic lymph nodes, are negative for metastasis. The report provides details on the gross and microscopic features of the tumor and lymph nodes but does not include any information about the patient's identity, treatment plan, or attending physicians.

Diagnosis: Infiltrates of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the prostate on both sides with a maximum tumor diameter of 3.5 cm and perineural tumor infiltration. Extraprostatic tumor growth in the right rectolateral region without identifiable invasion of vessels and tumor-free seminal vesicles. Four tumor-free lymph nodes (0/4) and two tumor-free lymph nodes (0/3). Tumor classification: pT3a, L0, V0, pNO (0/7); Gleason 4+3-7 (approx. 40% Gleason 4). The tumor extends to within less than 0.5 mm of the preparation margin in several points, but there is no evidence of indirect contact with the color labeling.

The pathology report describes a surgical case of a male patient with squamous cell carcinoma in several lymph nodes from the right supraomohyoid neck dissection specimen. There was also atrophy, fibrosis, and chronic inflammation of the salivary gland, but no tumor present. In the gingival labial margin and mucosal tongue margin, only benign squamous mucosa was identified, and no tumor was present in the deep tongue margin. The anterior floor of the mouth showed invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, but the margin of resection was free of tumor. Thirteen teeth were received, and there were no sections taken. Overall, the report suggests the presence of cancer in the patient's lymph nodes and mouth, but no other significant findings were reported.

Final Diagnosis:

- PART 1: Three pelvic lymph nodes negative for metastatic carcinoma (0/3).
- PART 2: Two pelvic lymph nodes negative for metastatic carcinoma (0/2).
- PART 3: One left common iliac lymph node negative for metastatic carcinoma (0/1).
- PART 4: One periaortic lymph node negative for metastatic carcinoma (0/1).
- PART 5: Radical hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy:
  * Invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the uterine cervix, moderately to poorly differentiated, with a tumor size of 2.0 x 2.0 cm.
  * Lymphovascular space invasion is present.
  * No evidence of tumor multicentricity is identified.
  * Surgical margins are free of tumor.
  * The endometrium is weakly proliferative, and the myometrium is unremarkable.
  * No vaginal extension is identified.
  * The right ovary shows a benign serous cyst, and the left ovary shows epithelial inclusion glands and physiological changes.
  * Bilateral benign fallopian tubes with paratubal cysts.
  * Parametrial tissues show a few vessels with thrombus, calcifications, and recanalization.
  * One lymph node in the right parametrial tissue is negative for metastatic carcinoma (0/1).
- PART 8: Liver biopsy negative for metastatic carcinoma.

Case Synopsis:

- Tumor type: primary uterine cervix tumors: hysterectomy and conization.
- Histologic grade: squamous cell carcinoma, poorly differentiated.
- Tumor size: 20 mm maximum dimension.
- Depth of invasion: ectocervix, endocervix, lower uterine segment, more than 90% of cervical stromal thickness.
- Margins of resection: greater than 2/3 of cervical thickness, negative vaginal margin, negative parametrium margin.
- Mitotic rate: not provided.
- Angiolymphatic Invasion: present.
- Lymph nodes positive: none of 8 examined lymph nodes have metastatic carcinoma.
- pT1b1, pNO, not applicable FIGO stage.
- Residual tumor: Rx.

The pathology report describes a case of endometrial adenocarcinoma of the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries in a patient who underwent hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. The tumor is identified as endometrioid type and formed a 2.8 x 1.5 x 0.9 cm mass in the fundus. It invades 0.1 cm into the myometrium, but not the endocervix, and does not show lymphovascular space invasion. The margins are negative for tumor. Multiple leiomyomata are present in the myometrium, but bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes are not involved, although they show mild hydrosalpinx. The final pathology report is based on the gross/macroscopic examination and the frozen section histologic evaluation of the specimen(s). Representative sections are submitted.

The liver partially removed exhibited a well-defined, expanding nodular mass, identified as a moderately differentiated trabecular hepatocellular carcinoma. The lesion did not invade the safety margin, serosa, portal vein, or show microvessel invasion, intrahepatic metastasis, or multicentric occurrence. The remaining liver parenchyma was cirrhotic. The report also includes information regarding the removal of the gallbladder due to chronic cholecystitis and the presence of tubular adenoma and adenocarcinoma in the large intestine and rectum.

A right upper lobectomy was performed due to carcinoma of the lung, with the tumor measuring 75mm in diameter and showing evidence of vascular invasion. Metastatic carcinoma was also found in one of the peribronchial lymph nodes. Sections showed a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with no definite bronchial origin identified. No evidence of pleural invasion was observed, and a separate pleural nodule was shown to represent a silicotic nodule within a pleural lymph node. The bronchial resection margin was clear of malignancy but showed a benign mucous gland adenoma. Pathological stage is T2 N1.

The pathology report describes the diagnosis of patient with JNG in the right upper lobe. The report confirms the presence of an invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with bronchioloalveolar carcinoma features, 1.5cm in size. The pleural area is free of tumor. The report indicates the presence of carcinoma at the inked staple margin. Several lymph node excisions were performed with no evidence of malignancy in most of them, although rare mucinous cells were identified in one lymph node (not considered diagnostic of malignancy). The gross description of the specimens is also provided. The synoptic report indicates adenocarcinoma, acinar (usual) type with moderately differentiated (G2) grade and no lymphatic or venous invasion. The tumor size is 1.5 cm, there is no arterial invasion, and pleural involvement is absent. The sampled specimen margins are uninvolved by tumor and no distant metastasis is observed. The pathologic stage is T1aNOMX.

The pathology report reveals an epiploic appendix with inflammatory reactive lesions and invasive adenocarcinoma of the colon in three areas. The adenocarcinoma is moderately differentiated with infiltration into muscles and vessels. However, there are free resection margins and lymph nodes. Tumor classification includes ICDO-DA M8140/3, G2, pT2, L1, V1, and pN0. The report suggests that the cancer has not spread beyond the local area.

The report describes a case of right hemicolectomy preparation with tumor-free oral and aboral resection margins and a hyperplastic polyp in the ascending colon. It also identifies an ulcerated adenocarcinoma in the cecum with extensive infiltration of the perimuscular fatty tissue (G3, pT3). After acetone clarification, 40 lymph nodes were analyzed and were found to be microscopically tumor-free throughout. The report concludes with a diagnosis of stage pT3 pNO (0/40) LO V0 R0.

The pathology report describes the findings of a total hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and lymph node dissection. The uterus shows endometrioid adenocarcinoma of FIGO grade 3/3 with invasion into the inner half of the myometrium and positive for cervix involvement. Lymphovascular space invasion is also observed. The right ovary, right fallopian tube, and left ovary are negative for tumors, while the left fallopian tube shows chronic salpingitis. Lymph node examination reveals no regional lymph node metastasis. The tumor within vascular spaces has undifferentiated morphology, while the glandular areas show positive staining for estrogen receptor and focally progesterone receptor. The report includes a detailed description of the gross specimen received for each organ.

The pathology report describes a hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy sample received for frozen section and subsequently placed in formalin. The uterus weighs 92 grams and measures 6.2 x 3.5 x 3.5 cm with a 2.5 cm diameter cervix with a patent os and unremarkable fallopian tubes and ovaries. The endometrial cavity is entirely filled with an exophytic, friable mass that appears to grossly involve the lower uterine segments, with invasion into a 1.3 cm thick myometrium. Lymph node dissections were also performed on the left external, left obturator, right pelvic, left aortic, and right aortic lymph nodes. The official diagnosis is a diffuse endometrioid adenocarcinoma with a FIGO grade of 3. The tumor measures 3.7 x 2.7 x 1.5 cm and invades less than half of the myometrial thickness with a maximum depth of 0.4 cm, in a 1.3 thick wall. Lymphovascular invasion is absent, and adjacent non-neoplastic endometrium is also absent. The specimen margins are not involved, and the lymph nodes examined from all dissected sites are negative for carcinoma.

Left-sided breast resection material shows a 1.8 cm moderately differentiated tubulolobular breast carcinoma with an equally sized component of intraductal tumor propagation of the lobular tumor component. The minimum margin is 5mm at 12 o'clock, over 10mm at 3 o'clock, and about 1mm at 6 o'clock (well over 10mm at 9 o'clock) without invasion of the lymph vessels. Tumor classification is M-8500/3, G2, pTlc, pLO, pSNO (0/2), pMx, stage I. R0.

Pathology Report-Summary: Material analyzed is a 16.0 X 13.0 X 6.5 cm right lower lobe lung tumor with a size of 8.5 X 6.5 x 5.0 cm. Diagnosis diagnosed as Squamous Cell Carcinoma, partially basaloid, with infiltration into pleura visceralis. Staged as pT2, pN2 (5/59), pMx, and graded as G3.

A surgical pathology report for a liver resection shows a 2.4 cm hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) arising in a background of micronodular cirrhosis. The tumor was completely excised, with negative margins and no evidence of vascular invasion. The adjacent liver shows moderate chronic inflammation, mixed hepatocellular steatosis, and micronodular cirrhosis. The tumor is classified as T1 stage with a histologic grade of 2 (by Edmundson and Steiner criteria) and 1 (by WHO criteria). A portion of the specimen is taken for research purposes.

The pathology report describes the analysis of four specimens, including three lymph nodes and a right upper lobe lobectomy. The lymph nodes were negative for tumor, while the lobectomy revealed a moderately differentiated non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma with a tumor size of 5.1 x 4.2 cm. The bronchial margins were uninvolved, and there was no lymph node involvement in the ipsilateral hilar, peribronchial, mediastinal, subcarinal, or contralateral mediastinal/hilar, scalene or supraclavicular regions. Non-neoplastic lung findings included emphysematous changes, subpleural fibrosis, and osseous metaplasia.

The pathology report pertains to a hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy specimen showing the presence of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type with FIGO grade I (of III). The tumor involves the endometrial cavity but not the endocervix and has invaded 0.8 cm into the myometrium with a total wall thickness of 1.4 cm. Lymphovascular space invasion is absent, and margins are negative for tumor. The bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes are unremarkable. Multiple excised lymph nodes from the right pelvic and left pelvic regions are negative for tumor. The gross examination reveals a mass (6.6 x 6.2 x 1.6 cm) from the fundus to lower uterine segment of the endometrial cavity with a 2.7 x 1.6 x 0.8 cm right ovary and a 2.7 x 1.4 x 0.7 cm left ovary. The report provides details of multiple excised lymph nodes from different pelvic regions and their respective locations.

Filtered Report: The pathology report indicates the presence of poorly differentiated invasive ductal right breast carcinoma, circumscribed ductal carcinoma in situ (high-grade DCIS with comedo necrosis), and lipomatous atrophy of the remaining breast tissue. The tumor measures up to 4.4 cm with a minimum dorsal margin of 2.9 cm in the ablated breast tissue. It is classified as M-8500/3, G 3, pT2, pNO (0/16), pMX, stage II A. However, there are no metastases in the sixteen right axillary lymph nodes. The nipple and skin are regular in appearance.

Final diagnosis: Right renal mass, resection - partial sparing nephrectomy. Histologic type: Papillary renal cell carcinoma; histologic grade: G2. Macroscopic extent of tumor: Confined to parenchyma. Microscopic tumor extension: Confined to kidney. Surgical margins: Gerota's fascial margin and renal parenchymal resection margin free of tumor. Pathological stage (pTNM): pT1b. Nonneoplastic kidney shows focal glomerulosclerosis, arterio- and arteriolonephrosclerosis, interstitial fibrosis, and chronic inflammation. No tumor necrosis identified. Images available in urology for further analysis.

The pathology report describes a biopsy and removal of a tumor in the right temporal lobe of the brain of a Caucasian female patient. The final diagnosis is oligodendroglioma of WHO grade II. An addendum is expected pending results of chromosome 1p and 19q deletion analyses. The case history involves a right frontal temporal brain mass. Multiple fragments of soft tissue were received and submitted for frozen section analysis. The specimens are labeled with the patient's name and hospital number. The report includes a gross description of the specimens submitted. The summary of cassettes indicates the specimen label and sites.

The pathology report is for a partial liver resection (Segments 5 and 6) with gallbladder and cystic duct. The report confirms the presence of Hepatocellular carcinoma, grade 2 of 3, forming an 11.5 cm mass. The background liver is without diagnostic abnormality, and the resection margins are free of tumor. The gallbladder and cystic duct are also without diagnostic abnormality. The tumor is confined to the liver without lymphatic/vascular invasion, and the hepatocellular prognostic index suggests a fair prognosis. Final TNM stage is pT1NXM0, stage I, which presumes no distant metastasis.

Final Diagnosis: Encapsulated papillary thyroid carcinoma, follicular variant, confined to the right thyroid lobe (3.0 cm), without invasion into tumor capsule and vascular invasion. C-cell hyperplasia is present, and molecular studies demonstrate PAX8/PPARg rearrangement and positive PPARg immunostain. Margins are free of carcinoma, and there are no additional pathologic findings. The tumor is unifocal, with a greatest dimension of 3 cm. Pathologic staging is pT2. Lymphatic/venous invasion is absent. Immunohistochemical stains for galectin-3, PAX8, and HBME-1 were done, with galectin-3 and PPAR gamma stains being focally positive and HBME-1 being negative. Positive calcitonin and CEA confirm the presence of C-cell hyperplasia. The laboratory is qualified to perform high-complexity clinical testing, and additional information is available upon request.

The decalcified sections from the right maxillectomy showed moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma infiltrating bone. No tumor was seen in the skeletal muscle and bone of the pterygoid. Metastatic squamous carcinoma was found in two out of ten lymph nodes in the right suprahoyd neck dissection. No tumor was present in the submandibular gland and muscle from nasal ala. Invasive squamous carcinoma was found in the connective tissue of the pterygoid margin and in the fibroconnective tissue, skeletal muscle, and mucosa of the pterygoid palate. The right middle turbinate was pending decalcification. Deeply invasive squamous carcinoma, moderately differentiated, was found in the right maxillectomy extending to bone and soft tissue. Skeletal muscle, adipose tissue, and minor salivary gland tissue were present in the right soft palate, and no tumor was found. The infraorbital nerve had fibrosis and inflammation, but no tumor was present. Buccal fat had adipose tissue and skeletal muscle with inflammation, but no tumor was present. Sinonasal mucosa and bone were present in the posterior floor ethmoid, but no tumor was present. The pterygoid had fibroconnective tissue, skeletal muscle, and bone, but no tumor was present. There was fibrosis and inflammation, but no tumor in the new pterygoid margin. Sixteen carious teeth were present, gross only.

Patient with left adrenal tumor: Diagnosis - Pheochromocytoma with degeneration. Gross description - adrenal gland distorted by a tumor measuring 6.5 x 6.5 x 4.2 cm, with a cyst measuring 4.0 cm and a pigmented area measuring 1.0 x 0.5 x 0.4 cm. Microscopic description - solid nesting "zellballen" architecture with polygonal cells, degeneration observed (focal hemorrhage, cystic change, and fatty degeneration), no frank invasion identified, resection margins not involved, no lymphovascular involvement or lymph node identification.

Summary: Gross examination of liver tissue shows a 5x4.5x4.2cm firm, solid, ill-margin tumor in a hepatic lobe that is yellow-white in color. Microscopic examination of the tumor tissue reveals trabecular, acinar, or sheet-shaped patterns of tumor cells with irregularly large, hyperchromatic nuclei and prominent nucleoli. The tumor is poorly-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma that has invaded lymphocytes. The tumor is a single tumor with vascular invasion and uninvolved margins. No evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings is noted.

Diagnosis: Poorly differentiated papillary serous carcinoma extensively involving the endometrium and myometrium, extending into the lower uterine segment, parametrial margins of excision, and right fallopian tube by direct extension with extensive lymphovascular space invasion. The left tube showed psammomatous calcifications and inflammation, while the omentum showed reactive mesothelial hyperplasia. No metastatic tumor was identified in the omentum. The histologic diagnosis is adenocarcinoma, serous papillary type with invasive tumor and involvement of the outer 1/3 of the myometrium to a depth of 14mm where the total myometrial wall thickness is 15mm. The tumor stage cannot be assigned due to insufficient data. Immunohistochemical stains, fluorescence in-situ hybridization tests, and immunophenotyping were performed in a high complexity laboratory under CLIA '88. The diagnosis is based on the examination of the slides and specimens without providing any additional information such as patient name, treatment plan, or reference.

The pathology report describes the findings of a male patient's cholecystectomy, gastrojejunostomy, and total gastrectomy. It reveals minimal chronic cholecystitis in the gallbladder and invasive signet ring cell carcinoma in the stomach, forming a 13.8 cm ulcerating mass. The tumor has invaded nearby tissues and lymph nodes but margins are negative, and metastatic carcinoma is identified in 15 out of 25 regional lymph nodes detected. The report also notes chronic gastritis and focal intestinal metaplasia in parts of the stomach and gastroesophageal junction. The tumor is poorly differentiated, classified as pT4b, and stage IIIC with present lymphovascular and perineural invasion. An immunostain for Helicobacter is negative.

Pathological diagnosis: Brain biopsy, right parieto-occipital lobe revealing Oligodendroglioma (grade B) with a MIB-1 index of 6%. Gross pathology: A 1.2 x 0.6 cm tissue fragment with focally hemorrhagic, gray-white soft brain parenchyma 1.5 x 1.2 x 1 cm in aggregate was observed. Microscopic analysis revealed a hypercellular oligodendroglioma involving both the cortex and the white matter, with areas of prominent nuclear pleomorphism and hyperchromasia, clusters of calcification, and focal areas of endothelial hyperplasia. No necrosis was identified. Tissue committee code: TC1. Clinical history and pre-op Dx were not provided.

A male patient underwent partial nephrectomy for a right renal mass, which was identified as papillary renal cell carcinoma type 2 with a size of 1.3 cm. The tumor was limited to the kidney, and margin evaluation did not show any invasive carcinoma. Lymphovascular invasion was not identified, and AJCC staging was pT1 pNX pM-. Additionally, the patient underwent a partial colectomy for a mucinous adenocarcinoma in the transverse colon with no macroscopic tumor perforation. The tumor was high grade and invaded the muscularis propria, but margins tested negative. Lymphovascular and perineural invasion were not identified, and the AJCC staging was pT2 pNO pM-. Biopsy showed a Type 1 and Type 2 mixture, and there was no necrosis or normal tissue present. The specimen weight ranged from 1-103 mg, and the study number was 2 with patient consent.

The pathology report relates to the diagnosis of a patient who underwent a partial pancreatectomy and splenectomy. The pancreatic tail was found to have an undifferentiated carcinoma with a sarcomatoid component, which extended beyond the pancreas and involved the peripancreatic soft tissue. However, surgical resection margins were negative for the tumor, and there was no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural invasion. Immunoperoxidase studies confirmed the diagnosis, and one regional lymph node tested positive for metastatic carcinoma. The adjacent non-neoplastic pancreatic parenchyma showed focal atrophy, and the spleen was unremarkable. Overall, the patient was diagnosed with AJCC stage pT3N1 carcinoma.

The report outlines the diagnosis of a multifocal Warthin's tumor with the largest tumor measuring 2.0 cm on the right parotid gland with three intraparotid/periparotid lymph nodes affected. There was evidence of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in one of forty-six lymph nodes, with a positive for focal extracapsular invasion. In addition, a squamous cell carcinoma moderately differentiated measuring 3.6 cm and maximum tumor thickness of 2.0 cm was found. The deep margin was close (0.5.cm) to the tumor, but the margins are negative for the tumor, and no evidence of perineural or lymphovascular invasion was found. There was one lymph node negative for carcinoma, with a single ipsilateral lymph node showing metastasis that is 3 cm or less in greatest dimension. Finally, wide invasion of cortical and medullary bone by squamous cell carcinoma was found in decalcified sections of the mandible, and the right inferior and posterior bone margins tested positive for carcinoma.

The pathology report describes the examination of several tissue samples obtained from different locations within the respiratory system of a patient. Samples from various margins, lymph nodes, and lobes were analyzed, with the right lower lobe found to contain adenocarcinoma with a predominantly acinar and micropapillary growth pattern, along with AAH and centrilobular emphysema. Peribronchiolar lymph nodes had occasional yeast forms consistent with Histoplasma, with no evidence of malignancy present in any of the lymph node specimens. The tumor was found to be invading the mediastinal pleura but not vascular or lymphatic structures. The results also include details of individual specimens, such as size and color, with representative sections submitted for analysis. An EGFR mutational analysis will be performed, and the results will be reported later.

The pathology report describes a case of serous papillary carcinoma with a tumor size of 4 cm in the endometrium, with a myometrial invasion of 0.1 cm and lymphovascular invasion present. The report mentions the involvement of various organs, such as the sigmoid mesentery implant, sigmoid implant, mesentery nodule, sigmoid lesion, pelvic gutter lesion, omentum, appendix, bladder implant, and right periculdle gutter implant. The lymph node sampling shows 0/5 lymph nodes involved in the left pelvic lymph node and 0/6 in the right pelvic lymph node. The report also includes details on the surgical pathology cancer case summary, the gross description, and the received specimen(s)/processing information. Ancillary studies were performed, and immunostains were used to identify estrogen receptor and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 positivity, while progesterone receptor expression was negative. Moreover, the report shows the absence of metastasis in the regional lymph nodes.

A pathology report was conducted on various tissue samples from a patient. The right rib showed normal bone marrow with no tumor. The lymph node biopsies (levels 7, 8, and 9, and level 10R) revealed negative results for tumor, with calcified nodules indicating a past remote infection. The diaphragm, as well as the visceral and parietal pleura, were positive for malignant mesothelioma, with fibroadipose tissue invasion and skeletal muscle and tendon involvement in the diaphragm. The phrenic nerve biopsy was also positive for malignant mesothelioma with fibrous tissue invasion. The sample from the old port site showed chronic inflammation and scar with no tumor involvement.

The pathology report describes tissue samples from multiple areas of the lung, pleura, diaphragm, and mediastinal lymph node. The right middle lobe lung sample shows a Grade 3 adenocarcinoma forming a 3.0 x 2.5 x  2.0 cm subpleural mass with pleural invasion. The right lower lobe lung sample also shows a Grade 3 adenocarcinoma forming a 1.5 x 1.5 x 1.2 cm intraparenchymal mass with free tumor margins. However, the second right lower lobe wedge excision shows no carcinoma. The pleura and diaphragm biopsies both demonstrate invasive Grade 3 adenocarcinoma, while the mediastinal lymph node excision shows no tumors identified.

Final Pathologic Diagnosis: 
A. Prostate, right anterior bladder neck, biopsy: No tumor or benign prostatic gland. 
B. Prostate, right posterior base, biopsy: No tumor or benign prostatic gland. 
C. Prostate, right anterior apex, biopsy: 1. No tumor. 2. Benign crushed prostatic gland. 
D. Lymph nodes, right external iliac, dissection: Metastatic adenocarcinoma in one of two lymph nodes (1/2). 
E. Lymph nodes, right obturator, dissection: No tumor identified in seven lymph nodes (0/7). 
F. Lymph nodes, left pelvis, dissection: No tumor identified in seven lymph nodes (0/7). 
G. Prostate and bilateral seminal vesicles, robot-assisted radical prostatectomy: 1. Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+4 = 7, with extra-prostatic extension, negative margins. 2. Bilateral seminal vesicles with invasion by prostatic adenocarcinoma. 

Comment: Synoptic Comment for Prostate Tumors: Small acinar adenocarcinoma located in multiple areas of the prostate with estimated volume of 9 cc. Gleason score of 3+4; primary pattern 3, secondary pattern 4. Tumor invades capsule, present in peri-prostatic fat, and extensively in perineural infiltration. Only one (out of 16) lymph nodes is positive. AJCC/UICC stage: Stage 4 (pT3bN1MX). 

Addendum Diagnosis: No change in final diagnosis. Lymph node metastasis is microscopic (<1mm in diameter) and confined to lymph node. No extranodal extension is identified.

Specimens A and B consist of a right temporal brain tumor diagnosed as a Glioblastoma multiforme (Astrocytoma WHO Grade IV). The tumor is characterized by malignant astrocytic cells with hyperchromasia, nucleomegaly, frequent mitotic activity, neovascularity, and large geographic areas of necrosis. Both specimens are submitted entirely, with specimen A being a 1 x 0.5 x 0.5 cm portion of mucoid orange-red tissue, and specimen B being an aggregate of pink-tan irregular soft tissue fragments admixed with clotted blood, with an average measurement of 2 x 1.5 x 0.4 cm.

Summary: 
Tumor Type: Thymoma 
Material: Tumor (4.0 X 3.6 X 1.5 cm)
Diagnosis: Type A-Thymoma, pT2, pNx (0/5), Masaoka: II.2
Histology: Focal infiltration of capsule and fat tissue.
Immunohistochemistry: Positive for CK5/6 and KL1 in epithelial cells, negative for CD1a, CD5, CD117, CD99, CD56, NSE, synaptophysin, TTF1, and chromograninA. Some CD1a-, CD5-positive immature T-lymphocytes present.

The patient has endometrial cancer. Biopsies from lymph nodes in the pelvic and periaortic regions show no metastasis. However, the uterus, cervix, right tube, and ovary have endometrial adenocarcinoma, which is grade 1 and arose from an endometrial polyp. No myometrial invasion or lymphovascular invasion is observed, and other nearby organs, such as the ovaries and fallopian tubes, are not involved. Multiple intramural leiomyomas are also present. The tumor has a size of 5.0 cm and is located in the posterior portion of the uterine corpus. The report mentions the weight, size, and appearance of different specimens, including biopsies and organs, received for examination and notes that special studies are pending. The lymph nodes and peritoneal cytology are negative for metastasis. The report provides a detailed gross and microscopic description of each specimen.

Site: Indometrium C54.1. Diagnosis: Endometrial adenocarcinoma with squamous differentiation, FIGO grade III. The tumor invades through the myometrium to 1.5 cm depth. The lower uterine segment and cervix are also involved by tumor. The ovaries and fallopian tubes are without diagnostic abnormalities. Only a single right obturator and a single left external iliac pelvic lymph node are involved by metastatic carcinoma. Multiple right and left pelvic lymph nodes and para-aortic lymph nodes are negative for tumor. The gonadal vessels, sigmoid mesentery biopsy, and ileal mesentery biopsies are negative for tumor. Immunohistochemical stains and HPV in situ hybridization were performed on the paraffin-embedded uterine tissue to support an endometrial primary.

Left axillary sentinel lymph node biopsy shows carcinoma deposits in two lymph nodes (less than 2 mm), without extracapsular extension. Left breast total mastectomy reveals infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade 2 (nuclear grade 2, tubule score 3, mitotic activity score 2; total score 7/9), with tumor size of 4.5 cm, lymphovascular space invasion present, tumor located in lower inner quadrant, and negative margins for neoplasm with the closest margin 1.5 mm away. Fibrocystic changes observed, nipple skin negative for neoplasm, and pT2 pN1mi pMX stage. Multicentricity/multifocality cannot be determined. Two out of 6 lymph nodes examined are positive for carcinoma, without extracapsular extension, and the largest metastasis measures 1 mm. Hormone receptors are positive, and HER2/neu is 2+.
